COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE



§ 31.001  CREATION OF COMMITTEE.



   The Committee of the Whole of the City Council is hereby created as a
standing committee of the City Council.



(Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.002  MEETINGS; BUSINESS.



   The Committee of the Whole shall meet on the  fourth Tuesday of the
month beginning at 6:00 p.m. local time. Otherwise, the Mayor or any three of
the Alderman may call a meeting of the Committee of the Whole at any time.
Notice of each committee of the whole meeting shall be given by the city in
accordance with the Illinois Open Meetings Act. The Clerk shall promptly
notify all members of the City Council of a meeting of the Committee of the
Whole, except those scheduled for the fourth Tuesday of the month, by
delivering a written notice stating the time and place of such  Committee
meeting to each member personally or by leaving the notice at the member's
residence. At said Committee of the Whole meetings, the department
supervisors shall present their agenda items. Discussion may be had on same
and other city issues and the Committee may by motion to send items to the
Council for approval.



(Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011; Am. Ord. O-11-030, passed 12-14-2011)



§ 31.003  MEMBERSHIP; CHAIRPERSON.



   The Committee of the Whole is composed of the Mayor and the City
Council. The Mayor shall be the Chairperson of the Committee of the Whole. In
the absence of the Mayor from a meeting of the Committee of the Whole, the
members of the Committee of the Whole present at that meeting shall elect
from among themselves a person to serve as Chairperson for that meeting.



(Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.004  MEETINGS; PROCEDURES.



   All meetings of the Committee of the Whole must be conducted in
compliance with the requirements of the Illinois Open Meetings Act. The
procedures governing meetings of the Committee of the Whole generally shall
be the same as the procedures applicable to meetings of the City Council.



(Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.005  POWERS.



   The Committee of the Whole is generally advisory to the City Council
and generally shall not have the power to take final action on matters coming
before it.  Notwithstanding this limitation, the Committee of the Whole
shall have the power to approve any bills and financial obligations of the
city which come before it and are on its agenda.



(Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011; Ord. O-15-134, passed 3-10-2015)



BOARD OF POLICE COMMISSIONERS



§ 31.020  BOARD CREATION.



   There is hereby created a Board of Police Commissioners consisting of
three members, as provided by state statute.



(Prior Code, § 2-8-1)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.021  MEMBERS; TERM OF OFFICE; VACANCY.



   (A)   The Board of Police Commissioners shall be appointed by the
Mayor, by and with the consent of the City Council. The term of office of the
members of the Board of Police Commissioners shall be three years, and until
their respective successor shall be appointed and qualified; provided, that
no appointments shall be made by any Mayor within 30 days before the
expiration of his or her term of office; provided further, that the Mayor
shall appoint the first member of the Board, one of which is appointed to
serve until the end of the current municipal year in which the appointment is
made, another of which shall serve until the end of the municipal year next
ensuing, and the third of which shall serve until the end of the municipal
year second next ensuing; and provided, that each of the first members of the
Board shall serve until his or her successor is appointed and qualified.



   (B)   Vacancies on the Board shall be filled in the same manner as
the original appointment, and it is hereby declared proper and desirable that
members of the Board be reappointed where the reappointment is practicable,
all in furtherance of continuity of membership on the Board.



(Prior Code, § 2-8-2)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.022  COMPENSATION; EXPENSE REIMBURSEMENT.



   The Secretary of the Board of Police Commissioners shall serve without
compensation for his or her  services, and the members of the Board shall
serve without compensation.



(Prior Code, § 2-8-5)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.023  QUALIFICATIONS; OATH; REMOVAL.



   The members of the Board of Police Commissioners shall have the
qualifications as are now, or as may hereafter be, required of them by law.
Each member of the Board of Police Commissioners shall take oath or
affirmation of office. The members of the Board of Police Commissioners shall
be subject to removal from office as provided by state statute.



(Prior Code, § 2-8-3)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.024  DUTIES OF BOARD.



   The Board of Police Commissioners shall have the powers and duties as
are now, or as may hereafter be, given to it by state statute and by the City
Council.



(Prior Code, § 2-8-4)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.025  GOVERNING BODY.



   The Board of Police Commissioners shall be governed in its operation by
the provisions of the Illinois Compiled Statutes and additions or amendments
hereto as shall from time to time become applicable. The provisions of this
subchapter are intended to embody and conform with the statutes in all
respects.



(Prior Code, § 2-8-6)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.026  LEGAL COUNSEL.



   The Board of Police Commissioners shall be entitled to legal counsel
and representation, to be provided by or at the expense of the city, in any
case pertaining to or arising from the performance of the statutory duties of
the Commission.



(Prior Code, § 2-8-7)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



POLICE PENSION FUND BOARD OF TRUSTEES



§ 31.030  BOARD CREATION; JURISDICTION.



   There is hereby created and established, and shall hereafter be
maintained and shall function in and for the city, a Board of Trustees of the
Police Pension Fund. The Board shall be under the jurisdiction of the City
Council.



(Prior Code, § 2-9-1)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.031  MEMBERS; TERM OF OFFICE; VACANCY.



   (A)   The Board shall be known as the Board of Trustees of the
Police Pension Fund of the city. The Board shall consist of five members, a
majority of whom shall be residents of the city and who shall administer the
Pension Fund and designate the beneficiaries thereof. Two members of the
Board shall be appointed by the Mayor. The third and fourth members of the
Board shall be elected from the regular police force by the active members
thereof. The fifth member shall be elected by and from among the
beneficiaries of the Fund.



   (B)   The members of the Board holding office at the time this
subchapter becomes effective shall continue in office until the expiration of
their respective terms and until their respective successors are appointed or
elected and qualified, as the case may be. In a municipality which comes
within the provisions of this subchapter after the effective date of this
code, one of the Board members appointed by the Mayor shall serve for one
year beginning on the second Tuesday in May after the municipality comes
within the provisions thereof. The other appointed member shall serve for two
years beginning on the same date. The successors to any of the appointed
members of the Board shall serve for two years each or until their successors
are appointed and qualified.



   (C)   The election provided for in this subchapter for elected Board
members shall be held biennially  on the third Monday in April at the place
or places in the municipality and under the Australian ballot system, and
other regulations as shall be prescribed by the appointed members of the
Board. All members of the regular police force shall be entitled to vote only
for the police force members of the Board. All beneficiaries of legal age
shall be entitled to vote only for the member chosen from among the
beneficiaries. No person shall be entitled to cast more than one ballot at
the election. The members shall be elected for a term of two years beginning
on the second Tuesday of the first May after the election.



   (D)   Upon the death, resignation, or inability to act of any member
of the Board elected under this subchapter, his or her successor shall be
elected for the unexpired term at a special election, to be called by the
Board and conducted in the same manner as the regular biennial election.



(Prior Code, § 2-9-2)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.032  COMPENSATION; EXPENSE REIMBURSEMENT.



   Neither Alderpersons nor citizen members of the Board shall be
compensated. No member of the Board shall receive any benefits, emoluments,
or fees whatever for his or her services; provided, however, the actual
amounts paid out by any members for personal and traveling expenses while
engaged in business pertaining to duties of the Board shall be reimbursed by
the city.



(Prior Code, § 2-9-7)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.033  CONFLICT OF INTEREST.



   No member of the Board shall be interested, directly or indirectly, in
any contract or job for work, or material for any work, for themselves or
family, or the profits therefrom, or services to be furnished or performed in
the operation, maintenance, extension, or improvement of the Board functions.
No member of the Board shall accept any compensation, gratuity, bribe, or
other form of payment for his or her actions as a Board member except as
provided by this subchapter.



(Prior Code, § 2-9-8)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.034  OATH.



   Every member of the Board shall, before entering upon the duties of his
or her office, take the oath of affirmation prescribed by law for city
officers. The Mayor and the Alderpersons who are selected as Board members
need not take any other oaths than those taken by them as Mayor and
Alderperson, respectively.



(Prior Code, § 2-9-3)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.035  ORGANIZATION; MINUTES AND RECORDS.



   (A)   (1)   The Board shall hold regular quarterly meetings in
July, October, January, and April annually, and special meetings as called by
the president.



      (2)   At the regular July meeting, the Board shall select from
its members a President, Vice- President, Secretary, and Assistant Secretary
to serve for the period of one year, and until his or her respective
successor is elected and qualified. The Vice-President of the Board shall
perform the duties of President during any vacancy in that office, or during
time the President is absent from the municipality, or for any other reason
is disqualified, or by reason of illness or other cause is unable to perform
his or her duties. The Assistant Secretary shall act for the Secretary
whenever necessary to discharge the functions of the office.



(Prior Code, § 2-9-4)



   (B)   The Board shall keep full and accurate minutes of its
proceedings and regular systematic accounts of transactions. This
information, to be kept as aforesaid, shall be reported to the City Council,
in writing, as soon as possible following the Board meeting.



(Prior Code, § 2-9-6)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.036  DUTIES OF BOARD.



   (A)   The Board shall be responsible for the following:



      (1)   To control and manage exclusively the Pension Fund and
all moneys donated, paid, or assessed for the relief or pensioning of
disabled, superannuated, and retired members of the Police Department, their
widows, minor children, and dependent parents. All such moneys shall be
placed by the Treasurer of the municipality to the credit of the Fund,
subject to the order of the Board;



      (2)   To order and direct the payment of pensions and other
benefits provided by this subchapter and to issue certificates signed by its
President and Secretary to the person entitled thereto of the amount ordered
paid to the persons from the Fund, which certificates shall state the purpose
of the payment;



      (3)   To submit annually to the City Council, at the close of
the municipality’s fiscal year, a list of persons entitled to payments from
the Fund, stating the amount of the payments and their purpose, as ordered by
the Board. It shall also include items of income accrued to the Fund during
the fiscal year. The list shall be signed by the Secretary and President of
the Board and attested under oath. No resolution or order for the payment of
money shall be valid unless approved by a majority of the members of the
Board, and any order for payment shall be signed by the President and
Secretary of the Board;



      (4)   To draw pension funds from the Treasurer or other
officials of the municipality and invest any part thereof in the name of the
Board of the Police Pension Fund in:



         (a)   Interest bearing bonds or tax anticipation
warrants of the United States, of the state, or of any county, township, or
municipal corporation of the state;



         (b)   Insured withdrawable capital accounts of state
chartered savings and loan associations;



         (c)   Insured withdrawable capital accounts of federal
chartered savings and loan associations if the withdrawable capital accounts
are insured by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation;



         (d)   Insured investments in credit unions if the
investments are insured by the National Credit Union Administration; and



         (e)   Savings accounts or certificates of deposit of a
national or state bank.



      (5)   To compel witnesses to attend and testify before it upon
matters connected with the administration of this subchapter in the manner
provided by law for the taking of testimony before the Circuit Court. The
President or any member of the Board may administer oaths to the witnesses;



      (6)   To appoint a clerk and define his or her duties. No
person drawing a pension under this subchapter shall be employed by the Board;



      (7)   To provide for the payment from the Fund of all
necessary expenses, including clerk hiring, printing, and witness fees;



      (8)   To keep a public record of all its proceedings;



      (9)   To make necessary rules and regulations in conformity
with the provisions of this subchapter, which shall be published by the Board
and copies transmitted from time to time to all pensioners and contributors;
and



      (10)   Any and all other duties as set forth in the state
statutes.



   (B)   The Board shall report to the City Council of the municipality
on the condition of the Police Pension Fund. The report shall be made prior
to the meeting of the Council or Board held for the levying of taxes for the
year for which the report is made.



   (C)   The Board shall certify to the City Council of the
municipality:



      (1)   The assets in its custody at the time;



      (2)   The estimated receipts during the next succeeding
calendar year from deductions from the salaries of police officers and from
all other sources; and



      (3)   The estimated amount required during the calendar year
to:



         (a)   Pay all pensions and other obligations provided in
this subchapter; and



         (b)   Maintain the Reserve Fund provided in ILCS Ch. 40,
Act 5, § 3-127.



   (D)   All securities shall be deposited with the Treasurer of the
municipality and be subject to the order of the Board. Interest on the
investments shall be credited to the account of the Pension Fund.



   (E)   No bank or savings and loan association shall receive
investment funds as permitted by this subchapter unless it has complied with
the requirements established pursuant to ILCS Ch. 30, Act 235,§ 0.01-8. The
limitations set forth therein shall be applicable only at the time of
investment and shall not require the liquidation of any investment at any
time.



(Prior Code, § 2-9-5)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.037  REMOVAL OF MEMBER.



   Any member of the Board may be removed at any time by the City Council
by a majority vote of the Council members present whenever, in the opinion of
the Council, the interest of the city requires the removal. The Board may
recommend to the City Council the removal of any member of the Board for
excessive absenteeism. Excessive absenteeism shall be the missing of three of
the last four regularly scheduled Board meetings.



(Prior Code, § 2-9-9)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



ZONING BOARD OF APPEALS



§ 31.050  BOARD CREATION; JURISDICTION.



   There is hereby created and established and shall hereafter be
maintained and recognized in and for the city a Zoning Board of Appeals. The
Board shall be under the jurisdiction of the City Council.



(Prior Code, § 2-10-1)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.051  MEMBERS; TERM OF OFFICE; VACANCY.



   The Board shall consist of seven members as follows:



   (A)   The seven members of the Board shall be citizens of the city
who are not members of the City Council. The seven citizen members shall be
appointed by the Mayor and approved by the City Council. The members shall
serve for a term of five years each from the first City Council meeting after
election certification of the year they are appointed, or until their
successors take office. The term for which each member is appointed shall be
designated in his or her appointment. At the April Council meeting of each
year, the member shall be appointed for a five-year term to succeed the
member whose term has expired.



   (B)   Members shall be eligible for reappointment, and it is
desirable that members rendering good service be reappointed in order that
the Zoning Board of Appeals may have the benefit of their experience, and
that there may be a continuity policy. If any member should, during the term
of his or her office die move from the city, or for any reason be unable to
act, the vacancy created shall be filled in the same manner as an original
appointment, and shall be for the remainder of the unexpired term.



(Prior Code, § 2-10-2)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.052  OATH.



   All citizen members of the Board do not have to take any oaths.



(Prior Code, § 2-10-3)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.053  COMPENSATION.



   The member of the Board shall be compensated $20 per regular meeting
attended to be paid quarterly and shall be entitled to receive reimbursement
for any reasonable actual expenses incurred. Payments shall be from revenue
of the General Fund.



(Prior Code, § 2-10-8)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.054  CONFLICT OF INTEREST.



   No member of the Board shall be interested, directly or indirectly, in
any contract of job for work, or material for any work, for themselves or
family, or the profits therefrom, or services to be furnished or performed in
the carrying out of the City Zoning Ordinance.



(Prior Code, § 2-10-9)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.055  ORGANIZATION; MINUTES AND RECORDS.



   (A)   (1)   The Board shall organize as soon as practicable after
the appointment and qualification of its members by the election of one of
its members as Chairperson and a Vice-Chairperson, to be elected yearly by a
majority of Board members.



      (2)   All hearings conducted by the Board shall be open to the
public. The Board shall keep minutes of its proceedings showing the vote of
each member upon every question or, if absent or failing to vote, indicating
the fact, and shall also keep records of its hearings and other official
actions. Findings of fact shall be included in the minutes of each case and
the reasons for recommending approval or denial of the request shall be
specified. Every rule or regulation, every amendment or repeal thereof, and
every order, requirement, decision, or determination of the Board shall be
filed within ten days in the office of the City Clerk and shall be a public
record. The Board shall adopt its own rules and procedures not in conflict
with this subchapter or with the state statutes in such case made and
provided.



(Prior Code, § 2-10-4)



   (B)   The Board shall keep full and accurate minutes of its
proceedings. The City Clerk shall designate a member of his or her staff to
be present to take full and accurate minutes. All records of the Board shall
be kept at City Hall and shall be open to the public.



(Prior Code, § 2-10-7)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.056  DUTIES OF BOARD.



   (A)   The powers and duties of the Board are:



      (1)   To hold public hearings and recommend to the City
Council approval or denial of conditional use permits;



      (2)   To hold public hearings and grant variances and
expansions of nonconforming uses;



      (3)   To hold public hearings and decide upon request for
determination of the existence of a nonconforming use and request for the
extension of a nonconforming use;



      (4)   To hear and decide appeals where it is alleged there is
an error in an order, requirement, decision, or determination made by the
Building Inspector in the enforcement of the Zoning Ordinance or the Building
Code and fee schedule;



      (5)   To permit the extension of a district where the boundary
line of a district divides a lot held in a single ownership at the time of
passage of the Zoning Ordinance; and



      (6)   To interpret the provisions of the Zoning Ordinance in
such a way as to carry out the intent and purpose of the plan as shown upon
the map fixing the several districts, which is adopted by reference as if set
out in full in this subchapter, where the street layout on the ground varies
from the layout as shown on the map.



   (B)   The Board may grant the following variances:



      (1)   Vary the yard regulations where there is an exception of
unusual physical condition of a lot, which condition, if not generally
prevalent in the neighborhood, and, when related to the yard regulations of
this code, would prevent a reasonable or sensible arrangement of buildings on
the lot. Applicants for a side or rear yard variance must be able to show the
distance of the proposed improvement from the lot line by way of lot corner
stakes in the neighborhood. Notwithstanding the foregoing, a variance may be
granted for the parking or storage of recreational vehicles in side yards.
Before granting a variance, the Board shall consider such factors as the
closeness of neighboring buildings, adequate light, sunshine, airspace, and
fire hazard potential;



      (2)   Vary the parking regulations where an applicant
demonstrates conclusively that the specific use of a building would make
unnecessary the parking spaces required by this code, providing that a
reduction not be more than 50% of the usual requirement;



      (3)   Use of the premises for public utilities and railroad
purposes (other than track right-of-way) or for radio and television tower or
broadcasting station; and



      (4)   Vary the parking regulations for parking in R districts
for churches, temples, public schools, public libraries, community centers,
public parks, and public playgrounds. In the R districts, 20% of the required
front yard shall be reserved and devoted to permanent landscaping, and no
off-street parking spaces or off-street loading spaces shall be permitted
within this landscaping area.



   (C)   The Zoning Board of Appeals shall conduct public hearings and
make recommendation to the City Council upon applications for conditional use
permits specifically listed in the district regulations of this code.
Conditional uses of areas to be annexed shall be detailed in an annexation
agreement. A public hearing on the conditional use and annexation agreement
shall be conducted by the Community Development Board. In such cases, it
shall be the Community Development Board rather than the Zoning Board of
Appeals which shall make recommendation to the City Council. No
recommendation for a conditional use permit shall be forwarded to the City
Council within the same week as the public hearing is completed. Before
recommending approval of a conditional use permit, the Board shall satisfy
itself that the conditional use requested will meet conditions that will,
with the Board’s judgment, ensure that:



      (1)   The establishment, maintenance, or operation of a
conditional use will not be detrimental to or endanger the public health,
safety, morals, comfort, or general welfare;



      (2)   The conditional use will not be injurious to the use and
enjoyment of other property in the immediate vicinity for the purposes
already permitted, nor substantially diminish and impair property values
within the neighborhood;



      (3)   The establishment of the conditional use will not impede
the normal and orderly development and improvement of surrounding property
uses permitted in the district;



      (4)   Adequate utilities, access roads, drainage, and other
necessary facilities will be provided;



      (5)   Adequate measures will be taken to provide ingress and
egress so designed as to minimize traffic congestions in the public streets;
and



      (6)   Duration of conditional uses shall be for that period of
time as set forth.



   (D)   An appeal may be taken to the Zoning Board of Appeals by a
person or by an officer, department, board, or bureau of the city affected by
a decision of the Building Inspector. An appeal shall state all proceedings
in furtherance of the action appealed from unless the Building Inspector
certifies to the Zoning Board of Appeals, after the notice of appeal has been
filed with him or her, that by reason of facts stated in the certificate a
stay would, in his or her opinion, cause imminent peril to life or property,
in which case the proceedings shall not be stayed otherwise than by a
restraining order, which may be granted by the Zoning Board of Appeals or by
a court of record on application, on notice to the Building Inspector, and on
due cause shown.



   (E)   The Board shall select a reasonable time and place for the
hearing of the appeal, give 15 days notice thereof to the parties, and shall
render a decision on the appeal without unreasonable delay. Any person may
appeal and testify at the hearing either in person or by duly authorized
agent or attorney.



   (F)   Any review of the decisions of the Zoning Board of Appeals as
set forth in division (B) above shall be subject to the Illinois
Administrative Review Act.



(Prior Code, § 2-10-5)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.057  DUTIES OF CITY CLERK.



   (A)   For conditional uses, variances, extension, expansion of
nonconforming uses, or for the determination of the existence of a
nonconforming use, the City Clerk’s office shall:



      (1)   Obtain the name of property owners within a radius of
250 feet of the property of the stated case and notify each property owner of
the public hearing by a letter;



      (2)   Have the legal notice published in the official
newspaper 15 days prior to the public hearing.



   (B)   The City Clerk’s office shall receive a fee of $150 with the
application for conditional use, variance, and expansion of nonconforming
use. No fee shall be received with applications for other meetings or
hearings of the Zoning Board of Appeals.



(Prior Code, § 2-10-6)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.058  REMOVAL OF MEMBERS.



   Any member of the Board may be removed at any time by the Council by a
two-thirds vote of Council members present whenever, in the opinion of the
Council, the interest of the city requires removal. The Board may recommend
to the City Council the removal of any member for excessive absenteeism at
any regularly scheduled Board meeting. Excessive absenteeism shall be the
missing of any three of the last four regularly scheduled Board meetings.



(Prior Code, § 2-10-10)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



PLAN COMMISSION



§ 31.060  CREATION OF COMMISSION.



   There is hereby created a Plan Commission which shall be advisory to
the City Council.



(Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.061  INTENT AND PURPOSE.



   It shall be the intent and purpose of the Plan Commission to provide
for the continued comprehensive development of the city according to the most
recent copy of the comprehensive plan of the city and to review and recommend
changes in the comprehensive plan.



(Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.062  POWERS.



   The members of the Plan Commission shall have such powers as are now or
may hereafter be given to it by law.



(Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.063  COMMISSION MEMBERSHIP.



   (A)   Members.  The Plan Commission shall consist of five members,
each appointed by the Mayor with the advice and consent of the City Council.



   (B)   Terms.  Three Plan Commission members shall serve a two-year
term and two Plan Commission members shall serve a one-year term. Upon the
initial appointments, the Mayor shall designate which Plan Commission members
are serving which terms and said seat shall thereafter continue with that
same term.



   (C)   Removal.  A Commission member may be removed in accordance
with the law.



   (D)   Chairman.  The Plan Commission shall designate one of its own
to be Chairman.



(Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.064  MEETINGS.



   The Plan Commission shall determine and set the time of its meeting and
shall otherwise meet upon the call of its Chairman or any three members.



(Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.065  DUTIES.



   (A)   To review the comprehensive plan of the city, and to prepare
and recommend changes to the comprehensive plan to the City Council.



   (B)   To hold public hearings, make written findings of fact and
submit the same with recommendations to the City Council on those matters
identified by law or ordinance.



   (C)   To study the provisions of the text of the zoning code and
review the zoning map pursuant to the zoning code, from time to time but not
less frequently than annually, so that this chapter and the map pursuant
thereto may be duly filed and updated annually.



   (D)   To act on all matters referred to it by the City Council or
upon which it is required to act under the zoning code and subdivision
regulations code as may be amended from time to time.



(Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.066  REPORTS AND RECORDS.



   (A)   The Commission shall keep permanent records and minutes of its
meetings, showing the vote of each member upon each topic submitted to it.



   (B)   The Commission shall prepare and submit minutes of each
meeting to the City Clerk in a timely manner.



   (C)   The Commission shall submit all recommendations to the City
Council in writing.



   (D)   A minority report may be attached to the majority
recommendation.



(Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



PLUMBING INSPECTOR



§ 31.080  OFFICE CREATED; APPOINTMENT.



   (A)   The office of Plumbing Inspector is hereby created in
accordance with the City Charter, § 1, Article V, OF APPOINTMENTS.



(Prior Code, § 3-1-1)



   (B)   The Plumbing Inspector shall be appointed by the Mayor with
the advice and consent of the City Council. The confirmed appointee shall be
an officer of the city, and as such shall have the powers of a law
enforcement officer for the enforcement of duties and responsibilities
delegated by the City Charter, ordinances, resolutions, and motions of the
Council, and of statutes of the state. The officer shall be commissioned by
warrant under the corporate seal and signed by the Mayor and attested by the
City Clerk.



(Prior Code, § 3-1-2)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.081  QUALIFICATIONS.



   The Plumbing Inspector shall have a valid plumbing license from the
state, shall not be engaged in the occupation of plumbing or be interested
directly or indirectly in any firm or corporation engaged in the business of
plumbing during the term of office, and shall be licensed in cross-connection
control devices.



(Prior Code, § 3-1-3)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.082  COMPENSATION.



   (A)   The Plumbing Inspector shall be compensated for the purpose of
carrying out the assigned duties of the office and for expenses incurred for
attendance of Council meetings and City Board meetings.



   (B)   The Plumbing Inspector shall be compensated for actual
expenses incurred for attendance at workshops, seminars and the like, which
have been approved by the Mayor.



(Prior Code, § 3-1-5)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.083  ADMINISTRATIVE DUTIES.



   The Office of Plumbing Inspector shall function under the provisions of
the City Charter, ordinances, and the following provisions.



   (A)   The Plumbing Inspector shall attend City Council meetings and
Board meetings upon request, shall provide a monthly report of plumbing
permits issued and fees established to the City Council, and shall keep in
close contact with the work of the city, officers, and various city boards
and departments.



   (B)   The Plumbing Inspector shall make any recommendations to City
Council concerning ordinances, resolutions, policies, fees, rules, and
regulations relating to the duties of the office.



(Prior Code, § 3-1-6)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.084  ENFORCEMENT DUTIES.



   (A)   The Plumbing Inspector is hereby authorized and directed to
enforce all the provisions of the city’s adopted Code and other ordinances
which assign specific enforcement duties.



   (B)   The authorization shall include, but not be limited to:



      (1)   The right to retain technical assistance;



      (2)   The right of entry to make an inspection to enforce any
provisions of the city’s adopted Code;



      (3)   The right to issue stop orders;



      (4)   The right to request and receive, so far as is required
in the discharge of the duties, the assistance and cooperation of other
officials of the city;



      (5)   The right to issue a permit, deny a permit, revoke a
permit, or require modifications to correct plans before the issuance of a
permit;



      (6)   The right to order modification of all work, whether
installed or not;



      (7)   The right to issue discontinued use of building or
structure or equipment regulated by the city’s adopted Code;



      (8)   Review applications for permit and establish fees;



      (9)   Present to the designated city board any plans or
alternative materials and method of construction for interpretation prior to
the issuance of a permit; and



      (10)   Present to the designated city board any citizen
complaint or request for interpretation.



(Prior Code, § 3-1-7)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.085  INSPECTION OF PREMISES.



   The Plumbing Inspector shall, in the course of his or her duties and
inspections, make all reasonable efforts to obtain the consent of the owner
or occupant of the premises for inspection. If consent cannot be obtained and
the Plumbing Inspector has probable cause for the necessity of the
inspection, he or she shall contact the City Attorney for the purpose of
obtaining a search warrant to conduct the inspection.



(Prior Code, § 3-1-11)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.086  INSPECTION DUTIES.



   (A)   The Plumbing Inspector shall be responsible for verifying the
presence or absence of cross-connections. The Plumbing Inspector shall make a
report of cross-connections discovered and forward the report to the Water
and Sewer Superintendent.



(Prior Code, § 3-1-9)



   (B)   The Plumbing Inspector shall inspect:



      (1)   All plumbing work in the process of construction;



      (2)   All waste pipes in repair or replacement work;



      (3)   Construction of public sewers;



      (4)   Installation of water service taps and service piping;



      (5)   Connections to main sewers; and



      (6)   Water, sewer, and drainage piping work which comes
within the meaning of the term PLUMBING, as defined in the adopted Plumbing
Code.



(Prior Code, § 3-1-10)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.087  APPEAL OF PLUMBING INSPECTOR ORDERS.



   (A)   Orders by the Plumbing Inspector may be appealed to the Water
and Sewer Board within ten days from service of the order. Unless appealed,
orders shall become final in ten days.



   (B)   If the order is sustained by the Water and Sewer Board, the
order will become final within ten days from the date the Water and Sewer
Board sustains the order, unless an appeal is taken to the Circuit Court.



   (C)   If no administrative appeal is taken from the order issued by
the Plumbing Inspector pursuant to this subchapter, or if no appeal is taken
from an order of the Water and Sewer Board sustaining an order of the
Plumbing Inspector within the period fixed by this section, the party upon
whom the order was entered shall be deemed to have waived the right to have
the reasonableness or the lawfulness of the order reviewed by a court, and
there shall be no trial of those issues in any court in which suit may be
instituted for the penalty for failure to comply with the order.



   (D)   The Water and Sewer Board shall have jurisdiction to review
all appeals from the orders of the Plumbing Inspector. The Water and Sewer
Board may reverse or sustain, in whole or in part, any order of the Plumbing
Inspector, or may modify any order.



(Prior Code, § 3-1-8)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.088  REMOVAL FROM OFFICE; VACANCY.



   (A)   The City Council, at its pleasure, may remove the Plumbing
Inspector for misconduct or any other cause by two-thirds vote of Council.
The Mayor may remove the Plumbing Inspector and must report the reason for
removal within ten days to Council. The Council, by two-thirds vote, may
disapprove of the removal.



   (B)   Vacancies created by death, resignation, removal from office,
or any other reason shall be filled by the appointment process of § 31.080.



(Prior Code, § 3-1-4)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.089  LIMITATION OF LIABILITY.



   The city is not liable for, nor in any respect, bound or obligated by,
any actions including, but not limited to, the issuance of permits or
licenses of the Plumbing Inspector which are done or performed outside the
scope of the authority set forth in this subchapter.



(Prior Code, § 3-1-12)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



ELECTRICAL INSPECTOR



§ 31.100  OFFICE CREATED; APPOINTMENT.



   (A)   The office of Electrical Inspector is hereby created in
accordance with the City Charter, § 1, Article V, OF APPOINTMENTS.



(Prior Code, § 3-2-1)



   (B)   The Electrical Inspector shall be appointed by the Mayor with
the advice and consent of the City Council. The confirmed appointee shall be
an officer of the city and as such shall have the powers of a law enforcement
officer for the enforcement of duties and responsibilities delegated by the
City Charter, ordinances, resolutions, and motions of the Council, and of
statutes of the state. The officer shall be commissioned by warrant under the
corporate seal and signed by the Mayor and attested by the City Clerk.



(Prior Code, § 3-2-2)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.101  QUALIFICATIONS.



   The Electrical Inspector shall be knowledgeable with the methods of
electrical construction for safety to life and property as approved by this
subchapter, state law, and by rules and regulations made by the Electrical
Utility Board, pursuant to the city electrical ordinance and the National
Electric Code.



(Prior Code, § 3-2-3)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.102  COMPENSATION.



   (A)   The Electrical Inspector shall be compensated for the purpose
of carrying out the assigned duties of the office and for expenses incurred
for attendance of Council meetings and City Board meetings.



   (B)   The Electrical Inspector shall be compensated for actual
expenses incurred for attendance at workshops, seminars and the like, which
have been approved by the Mayor.



(Prior Code, § 3-2-5)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.103  ADMINISTRATIVE DUTIES.



   The Office of Electrical Inspector shall function under the provisions
of the City Charter, ordinances, and the following provisions.



   (A)   The Electrical Inspector shall attend City Council meetings
and Board meetings upon request, shall provide a monthly report of electric
permits issued and fees established to the City Council, and shall keep in
close contact with the work of the city, officers, and various city boards
and departments.



   (B)   The Electrical Inspector shall make any recommendations to
City Council concerning ordinances, resolutions, policies, fees, rules, and
regulations relating to the duties of the office.



   (C)   The Electrical Inspector shall administer the written
examination developed by the Electrical Utility Board to test the experience,
knowledge, and qualifications of applicants for electrical contractor’s or
electrical journeyman’s licenses.



(Prior Code, § 3-2-6)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.104  ENFORCEMENT DUTIES.



   (A)   The Electrical Inspector shall arrange for the issuance of
permits upon payment of permit fees required by this subchapter, inspect all
electrical wires, conduits, and apparatus, and administer enforcement of
laws, rules, and regulations relating to the installation of electrical wires
and apparatus in public and private buildings and on public and private
property.



   (B)   The Electrical Inspector shall make a periodic inspection of
all electrical equipment used within the city and shall inspect at reasonable
hours any premises, buildings, or other structures where electrical equipment
is used.



   (C)   The Electrical Inspector shall have the power to order
modifications of all electrical work, whether installed or not, so that the
work will be in conformance to this subchapter and to good electrical
practice, and shall have the power to enter into premises, buildings, or
other structures in the course of the exercise of that power only after
obtaining the necessary warrant or otherwise complying with all legal and
constitutional requirements. The Electrical Inspector shall further have the
power to cause the turning off of all electrical current and to cut or
disconnect wire in cases of emergency, where the electrical current is
dangerous to life or property.



   (D)   The Electrical Inspector shall interview applicants for
electrical licenses, receive their affidavits of experience, administer
electrical examinations to qualified applicants, and issue electrical
licenses to qualified applicants.



   (E)   The Electrical Inspector shall renew electrical licenses for
existing holders upon payment of license fees and proof that bonding and
insurance requirements have been complied with.



(Prior Code, § 3-2-7)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.105  INSPECTION OF PREMISES.



   The Electrical Inspector shall, in the course of his or her duties and
inspections, make all reasonable efforts to obtain the consent of the owner
or occupant of the premises for the inspection. If consent cannot be obtained
and the Electrical Inspector has probable cause for the necessity of
inspection, he or she shall contact the City Attorney for the purpose of
obtaining a search warrant to conduct the inspection.



(Prior Code, § 3-2-9)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.106  APPEAL OF ELECTRICAL INSPECTOR ORDERS.



   (A)   Orders by the Electrical Inspector may be appealed to the
Electrical Utility Board within ten days from service of the order. Unless
appealed, orders shall become final in ten days.



   (B)   If the order is sustained by the Electrical Utility Board, the
order will become final within ten days from the date the Electrical Utility
Board sustains the order, unless an appeal is taken to the Circuit Court.



   (C)   If no administrative appeal is taken from the order issued by
the Electrical Inspector pursuant to this subchapter, or if no appeal is
taken from an order of the Electrical Utility Board sustaining an order of
the Electrical Inspector within the period fixed by this section, the party
upon whom the order was entered shall be deemed to have waived the right to
have the reasonableness or the lawfulness of the order reviewed by a court
and there shall be no trial of those issues in any court in which suit may be
instituted for the penalty for failure to comply with the order.



   (D)   (1)   The Electrical Utility Board shall have jurisdiction
to review all appeals from the orders of the Electrical Inspector.



      (2)   The Electrical Utility Board may reverse or sustain, in
whole or in part, any order of the Electrical Inspector, or may modify any
order.



(Prior Code, § 3-2-8)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.107  REMOVAL FROM OFFICE; VACANCY.



   (A)   (1)   The City Council, at its pleasure, may remove the
Electrical Inspector for misconduct or any other cause by two-thirds vote of
Council. The Mayor may remove the Electrical Inspector and must report the
reason for the removal within ten days to Council.



      (2)   The Council, by two-thirds vote, may disapprove of the
removal.



   (B)   Vacancies created by death, resignation, removal from office,
or any other reason shall be filled by the appointment process of § 31.100.



(Prior Code, § 3-2-4)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.108  LIMITATION OF LIABILITY.



   The city is not liable for, nor in any respect, bound or obligated by,
any actions including, but not limited to, the issuance of permits or
licenses of the Electrical Inspector which are done or performed outside the
scope of the authority set forth in this subchapter.



(Prior Code, § 3-2-10)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



POLICE DEPARTMENT



§ 31.140  CREATION AND SUPERVISION OF DEPARTMENT.



   There is hereby created and established an executive department of the
municipal government of the city to be known as the Police Department, which
shall be under the supervision of the Mayor and the Public Safety Board of
the City Council.



(Prior Code, § 6-7-1)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.141  OFFICES.



   (A)   There are hereby created the following offices in the Police
Department, to wit: Chief of Police, lieutenants, special assistant (youth
and community affairs), sergeants, and police officers.



(Prior Code, § 6-7-2)



   (B)   The Police Department shall consist of the offices set forth
in division (A) above, as well as other offices as shall hereafter be created
by ordinance.



(Prior Code, § 6-7-3)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.142  CIVILIAN PERSONNEL.



   In addition to the offices referred to in § 31.141, the Police
Department may employ other personnel who shall be civilian employees,
holding no rank in the Police Department. Civilian employees may include, but
not be limited to, radio operators, auxiliary police officers, secretaries,
and crossing guards.



(Prior Code, § 6-7-4)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.143  CHIEF OF POLICE.



   The Chief Executive Office of the Police Department shall be the Chief
of Police, who shall be appointed by the City Council, as authorized by ILCS
Ch. 65, Act 5, § 10-2.1-4, the state, and by the City Charter. The Chief of
Police shall perform the duties imposed upon him or her by law or by
ordinance, as well as the duties prescribed by the City Marshal in the City
Charter to the extent that the Charter has not been superseded by the laws of
the state. The Chief of Police shall perform further duties as may from time
to time be assigned to him or her by the Mayor or the City Council. The Chief
of Police shall possess powers and authority as are prescribed for the City
Marshal in the City Charter, as well as further power and authority as are
given a police officer by ordinance or by the laws of the states. The Chief
of Police shall have the ability to appoint a deputy chief, subject to the
confirmation of the City Council.  In the event that the office of the Chief
of Police becomes vacant for any reason, the City Council shall appoint an
Acting Chief of Police and may appoint and ad hoc committee to screen
applicants for the office of Chief of Police and to bring recommendations for
appointment to the City Council.



(Prior Code, § 6-7-5)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011; Ord. O-18-04,
passed 3-27-2018)



§ 31.144  APPOINTMENTS; DISCHARGES.



   All appointments and promotions to the offices in the Police Department
described in § 31.141 shall be made by the Board of Fire and Police
Commissioners in accordance with the laws of the state pertaining thereto and
in accordance with the rules and regulations promulgated by the Board of Fire
and Police Commissioners. All actions of suspension, removal, discharge, or
reprimand or for offices in the Police Department described in §§ 31.141
and 31.143 shall be conducted by the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners
in accordance with the laws of the state pertaining thereto and in accordance
with the rules and regulations promulgated by the Board of Fire and Police
Commissioners.



(Prior Code, § 6-7-6)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.145  SALARIES.



   All officers and civilian employees of the Police Department of the
city shall receive the salary and compensation as shall be established from
time to time by the City Council.



(Prior Code, § 6-7-7)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.146  POWER TO ARREST.



   All police officers described in §§ 31.141 and 31.143 shall have the
power to arrest or cause to be arrested, with or without process, any
individual for the violation of any city ordinance or law of the state.



(Prior Code, § 6-7-8)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 31.147  RULES AND REGULATIONS EFFECTIVE UPON APPROVAL.



   Such rules and regulations as may be from time to time promulgated for
the direction and control of the members and personnel of the Police
Department shall be in full force and effect upon their approval by the City
Council.



(Prior Code, § 6-7-9)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



CHAPTER 32:  PURCHASING



Section




General Provisions




   32.01   Purpose of regulations



   32.02   Code of Ethics



   32.03   Conflict of interest



   32.04   Gifts and gratuities



   32.05   Approval of purchases required



   32.06   Purchases near end of fiscal year



   32.07   Energy purchases



   32.08   Change orders
