CHAPTER 50:  GARBAGE, BRUSH, AND YARD WASTE



Section




Garbage Collection




   50.01   Definitions



   50.02   Exclusive residential collection license



   50.03   Commercial collection



   50.04   Authority to collect



   50.05   Frequency of collection



   50.06   Containers provided by contractor



   50.07   Number of residential containers limited



   50.08   Care, placement and removal of containers



   50.09   Hazardous materials and hot ashes to be separated from other
garbage



   50.10   Failure to use container unlawful



   50.11   Wind blown accumulations unlawful



   50.12   Dropping of refuse from vehicle unlawful



   50.13   Dumping of refuse on property without owner’s consent
unlawful



   50.14   Unlicensed collector handling curbside recyclables unlawful



   50.15   Disposal of garbage other than in incinerator or landfill
unlawful



   50.16   Accumulation of offensive substance prohibited



   50.17   Prima facie evidence of responsibility




Brush and Yard Waste Pickup




   50.30   Definitions



   50.31   Yard waste pickup



   50.32   Brush pickup



   50.33   Full tree permit



   50.34   Special pickup



   50.35   City compost area use



 



   50.99   Penalty




GARBAGE COLLECTION




§ 50.01  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   ASHES.  Residue from fires used for cooking and for heating buildings,
and the residue from incinerators.



   COLLECTOR.  Any individual, firm, or corporation that shall go from
place to place within the city on any vehicle, mechanical or otherwise, for
the purpose of collecting garbage, refuse, ashes, or recyclables; or any
individual who shall engage in the business of collecting garbage, refuse,
ashes, or recyclables.



   GARBAGE.  Organic wastes resulting from the handling, preparation,
cooking, and consumption of food, as well as organic wastes from the
handling, storage, and sale of produce.



   RECYCLABLES.  Newspapers; corrugated cardboard; magazines; junk mail;
aluminum cans; steel tin cans; #1 and #2 plastics; clear, green and brown
glass; textiles; and other materials as determined by the label on the
recycling toter.



   REFUSE.  Combustible trash including, but not limited to, paper,
cartons, boxes, barrels, wood, excelsior, tree branches, yard trimmings, wood
furniture, bedding; noncombustible trash including, but not limited to,
metals, tin cans, metal furniture, dirt, small quantities of rock and pieces
of concrete, glass, crockery, other mineral wastes; street rubbish including,
but not limited to, street sweepings, dirt, leaves, catch basin dirt,
contents of litter receptacles; provided, REFUSE shall not include earth and
wastes from building operations, nor shall it include solid wastes resulting
from industrial processes and manufacturing operations such as food
processing wastes, boiler house cinders, lumber scraps and shavings.



(Prior Code, § 7-8-1)  (Ord. O-12-068, passed 12-11-2012)



§ 50.02  EXCLUSIVE RESIDENTIAL COLLECTION LICENSE.



   (A)   A single exclusive residential collection license shall be
issued by the City Clerk to the contract collector as determined after
competitive bidding has been conducted and a contractor has been selected by
the City Council. Exclusive residential garbage and refuse collection shall
be defined as all necessary garbage and refuse collection relating to
residential units of a four-plex or less.



   (B)   This contract shall specify a rate structure of collection,
and any other terms agreed upon between the parties. Violation of the rate
provisions of the contract shall be grounds for the city, in its discretion,
to revoke the residential collection therein.



   (C)   The terms of the contract between the city and the entity
holding the exclusive residential collection license are incorporated by
reference into this section, and shall be binding as if fully set forth
herein. A true and correct copy of the contract is filed at City Hall, 115
South Oakwood Avenue, Geneseo, Illinois, and is available for viewing by the
public. The terms of the contract shall be binding in the event of any
conflict with any other terms of Chapter 50.



(Prior Code, § 7-8-2)  (Ord. O-12-062, passed 9-25-2012; Ord. O-12-068,
passed 12-11-2012)



§ 50.03  COMMERCIAL COLLECTION.



   (A)   Collectors collecting commercial garbage, refuse, and brush
within the city limits shall register with the city by furnishing a
certificate of insurance showing comprehensive general liability insurance,
property damage insurance, and workers’ compensation insurance, sufficient
to cover the costs of potential liability that may arise out of or from the
discharge of the collector’s duties. The collector’s comprehensive
general liability insurance policy shall include an endorsement designating
the city as an additional insured.



   (B)   The collector shall indemnify and hold harmless the city, and
its officers and employees, from liabilities and related expenses of any kind
which may arise out of or from the discharge of the collector’s duties.



(Prior Code, § 7-8-3)  (Ord. O-12-068, passed 12-11-2012)



§ 50.04  AUTHORITY TO COLLECT.



   No person other than the officials or employees of the city, or the
person the city may have licensed or registered, shall collect garbage,
refuse, brush, recyclables or other trash or waste in the city for hire.



(Prior Code, § 7-8-16) (Ord. O-12-068, passed 12-11-2012)



§ 50.05  FREQUENCY OF COLLECTION.



   The collection of garbage and refuse from residential units shall be
made in accordance with the exclusive residential collection contract.



(Prior Code, § 7-8-11)



§ 50.06  CONTAINERS PROVIDED BY CONTRACTOR.



   (A)   It shall be the duty of every owner, or his or her agent, or
occupant of any house, building, flat, apartment, or tenement in the city
where persons reside, board, or lodge, or where animal or vegetable food is
prepared or served, or where garbage or refuse, as defined, is created, to
provide for the house, building, flat, apartment, or tenement, and at all
times to maintain in good order and repair, containers as hereinafter
specified.



   (B)   In the residential area, all containers shall not be of less
than 35-gallon nor more than 95-gallon capacity, and are the property of the
contractor. The exception is the yard waste toters; they are the property of
the owner. The containers shall be tightly covered, watertight, of rigid
construction, and provided with suitable handles at the sides. Liners or bags
of heavy duty plastic film may be used, but must be properly sealed at the
top of the liner or bag and must not be punctured or broken.



   (C)   The city, at its option, may require owners or agents
operating multiple dwelling structures of a four-plex or less to provide one
or more cubic yard containers for each multiple dwelling using the
residential collection service provided by the city.



   (D)   The city, at its option, may require the use of one or more
cubic yard containers for each business.



(Prior Code, § 7-8-13)  (Ord. O-12-068, passed 12-11-2012)



§ 50.07  NUMBER OF RESIDENTIAL CONTAINERS LIMITED.



   In residential areas, the number of containers per week per residential
unit shall be limited to the equivalent of one toter for refuse and one for
recycling, additional toters may be rented from the contractor.



(Prior Code, § 7-8-14)  (Ord. O-12-068, passed 12-11-2012)



§ 50.08  CARE, PLACEMENT AND REMOVAL OF CONTAINERS.



   (A)   It shall be the duty of every person requesting garbage or
refuse collection, either of the city or any person having a residential
contract with the city, or any private collector registered with the city, to
place or cause to be placed the containers referred to in this subchapter at
a convenient place upon the premises at the times and in the manner as may be
directed by the city or collection contractor. No container set out to be
collected, whether collected by the city, by a person having a contract with
the city, or by any other private collector, shall remain on the street
right-of-way for more than 24 hours.



(Prior Code, § 7-8-12)



   (B)   Each and every container for garbage or refuse shall be
maintained in a sanitary condition.



(Prior Code, § 7-8-15)



§ 50.09  HAZARDOUS MATERIALS AND HOT ASHES TO BE SEPARATED FROM OTHER
GARBAGE.



   Hot ashes or refuse which is explosive, toxic, or otherwise of
hazardous nature shall not be mixed or mingled with refuse that is to be
collected by the city or collected by any person having a contract for
collection with the city.



(Prior Code, § 7-8-10)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 50.10  FAILURE TO USE CONTAINER UNLAWFUL.



   It shall be unlawful to place or permit to remain anywhere in the city
any garbage or other material subject to decay, other than leaves or grass,
excepting in a tightly covered, watertight container of rigid construction.



(Prior Code, § 7-8-4)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 50.11  WIND BLOWN ACCUMULATIONS UNLAWFUL.



   It shall be unlawful to cause or permit to accumulate any dust, ashes,
refuse, or recyclables of a nature that it can be blown away by the wind,
anywhere in the city.



(Prior Code, § 7-8-6)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 50.12  DROPPING OF REFUSE FROM VEHICLE UNLAWFUL.



   It shall be unlawful to deposit, or permit to fall, from any vehicle
any garbage, refuse, ashes, manure, or offensive or nauseous substance on any
public street or alley in the city; provided, that this section shall not be
construed to prohibit placing garbage, refuse, ashes, or recyclables in a
container complying with the provisions of this subchapter, preparatory to
having the material collected and disposed of in the manner provided herein.



(Prior Code, § 7-8-7)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 50.13  DUMPING OF REFUSE ON PROPERTY WITHOUT OWNER’S CONSENT UNLAWFUL.



   It shall be unlawful to dump or place any garbage, refuse, ashes or
recyclables on any premises in the city without the consent of the owner of
the premises.



(Prior Code, § 7-8-8)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 50.14  UNLICENSED COLLECTOR HANDLING CURBSIDE RECYCLABLES UNLAWFUL.



   It shall be unlawful for any person other than a city collector, or a
collector licensed or registered with the city as herein provided, to remove,
displace, uncover, or otherwise disturb any recyclable materials placed at
the curb.



(Prior Code, § 7-8-9)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 50.15  DISPOSAL OF GARBAGE OTHER THAN IN INCINERATOR OR LANDFILL UNLAWFUL.



   It shall be unlawful to dispose of any garbage, refuse, brush, yard
waste or ashes anywhere in the city, excepting in an in-building incinerator
or other disposal device properly constructed and operated under local,
state, or federal law, or in a lawfully established landfill site. Material
not so properly disposed of shall be placed in containers for collection by
the city or licensed or registered collector.  Property owners or tenants of
residential units of a four-plex or less shall use the city's contracted
residential garbage collection service exclusively, and commercial and
industrial property owners shall use garbage collectors licensed or
registered by the city exclusively. All residential customers shall be billed
and shall pay for residential garbage collection in accordance with the
city's contract for garbage collection. In the event that the city is
required to take legal action to collect any fees provided in this section,
the city may add to the bill for collection its reasonable attorneys fees
incurred thereby.



(Prior Code, § 7-8-17)  (Ord. O-12-069, passed 12-11-2012; Ord. O-13-083,
passed 4-23-2013)   Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 50.16  ACCUMULATION OF OFFENSIVE SUBSTANCE PROHIBITED.



   No pile or deposit of manure, garbage, miscellaneous waste, refuse, of
any kind whatsoever, or accumulation of any offensive or nauseous substance,
shall be made within the limits of the city.



(Prior Code, § 7-8-5)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 50.17  PRIMA FACIE EVIDENCE OF RESPONSIBILITY.



   The fact that garbage, refuse, ashes, or recyclables remain on any
occupant’s premises in the city in violation of this subchapter shall be
prima facie evidence that the occupant of the premises is responsible for the
violation of this subchapter.



(Prior Code, § 7-8-19)




BRUSH AND YARD WASTE PICKUP




§ 50.30  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   BRUSH.  Brown-stemmed branches, tree trunks not to exceed 60 inches in
length and four inches in diameter, and shrub prunings with large diameter
stems.



   YARD WASTE.  Leaves, flowers, prunings of small diameter,
green-stemmed shrubs, plant stalks, garden waste, and grass clippings.



(Prior Code, § 6-10-1) (Ord. O-12-068, passed 12-11-2012)



§ 50.31  YARD WASTE PICKUP.



   (A)   All yard waste from residential dwelling units within the city
shall be picked up as provided by the city's hauling contract.



   (B)   Yard waste to be picked up must be placed in a separate
special 32-gallon biodegradable Kraft paper bag, or in a toter as may be
provided or permitted by the city's hauling contract.



(Prior Code, § 6-10-2)  (Ord. O-12-068, passed 12-11-2012; Ord. O-16-188,
passed 12-13-2016)



§ 50.32  BRUSH PICKUP.



   (A)   All brush, as defined in § 50.30 above, will be picked up
without charge as long as it is tied in bundles being no more than two feet
in diameter, five feet in length, and weighing not more than 50 pounds. Small
twigs may be placed in Kraft bags or toters. 



   (B)   Brush will be picked up as provided by the city's hauling
contract, and must be placed at the curb by 7:00 a.m. on the day of pick-up.



(Prior Code, § 6-10-3) (Ord. O-12-068, passed 12-11-2012; Ord. O-16-188,
passed 12-13-2016)



§ 50.33  FULL TREE PERMIT.



   (A)   Residents of the city who wish to remove a tree or trees from
their property may have the city haul away the debris by purchasing a full
tree pickup permit at City Hall for a minimum of $25. A separate permit is
required for each full tree cut down and placed parallel at the curb. If the
homeowner’s work is to take place over an extended period of time, a
separate permit is required for each date the city picks up debris from in
front of the resident’s property.



   (B)   Residents who choose to not bundle smaller piles of brush or
shrubs may have the city haul away the debris by purchasing a non-bundled
brush permit for $15.



   (C)   Full tree pickup permits will not be issued to residents who
contract the removal of trees and brush. Contractors who remove trees shall
be responsible for removal and disposal of trees and brush.



(Prior Code, § 6-10-4)



§ 50.34  SPECIAL PICKUP.



   (A)   The city will pick up Christmas trees and wreaths placed on
the curb during the months of December and January. Tree stands must be
removed. Long evergreen garlands must be bundled as described in § 50.32 of
this subchapter.



   (B)   Special pickups due to storms will be announced as needed and
at the authorization of the Public Works Director.



(Prior Code, § 6-10-5)  (Ord. O-12-068, passed 12-11-2012)



§ 50.35  CITY COMPOST AREA USE.



   (A)   City departments may deposit brush and tree limbs at the city
compost area.



   (B)   Any dumping at the city compost area, except that which is
expressly authorized under this section or at the authorization of the City
Public Service Superintendent, is prohibited, and shall be deemed in
violation of this section.



   (C)   Upon meeting the requirements set forth herein, any private
business may use the city burn pile for disposal of trees, brush, and
shrubbery.



      (1)   The applicant must provide a certificate of liability
insurance in good standing in the amount of $1,000,000 naming the city as
also insured. The certificate will be kept on file at City Hall.  The
applicant must maintain a valid certificate and update the certificate every
six months.



      (2)   The applicant must complete a burn pile access permit
application for each location and customer for which they provide service.
The property owner/customer must sign and date the permit once the job has
been completed. Permit fee is $50 per location. High use applicants may
choose an annual permit for $300 with a $100 key deposit.  The key can be
kept by the applicant for one year.  The burn pile access permit is
available and shall be filed at City Hall.



      (3)   Once the permit application is completed and the permit
fee has been paid, the applicant will be issued a gate key to the burn pile
area. The key must be returned to City Hall or the yellow utilities payment
drop-box in the City Hall parking lot at the completion of each permit job,
and no later than 48 hours after issuance.



      (4)   The location of the applicant’s work must be within
the corporate limits of the city, with no exception.



      (5)   The city will accept trees, brush, and shrubs. Tree
trunk sections shall be no more than six feet in length. Tree trunk sections
over 24 inches in diameter shall be no more than six feet in length. Wood
chips are permitted. Whole shrubs are permitted. Grubbed out tree stumps are
prohibited. Stump grindings are prohibited.



   (D)   Any person or applicant deemed in violation of the provisions
of this policy, as stated below, shall risk loss of burn pile access
privileges:



      (1)   Lapse or suspension of liability insurance coverage;



      (2)   Failure to obtain brush pile access permit for each
customer or location;



      (3)   Failure to pay permit fee or any other bill owed to the
city;



      (4)   Disposal of materials other than acceptable items as
stated above;



      (5)   Disposal of any materials from locations or job sites
outside of city limits;



      (6)   Copying of burn pile area gate key;



      (7)   Failure to return gate key within 48 hours;



      (8)   If use of the permit is by any other party other than
the contractor that was issued the permit.



   (E)   The first violation of the provisions in division (D) above
will result in a verbal warning issued by the Public Works Director and
documented in the contractor’s file. A second violation will result in a
written warning issued by the Public Works Director and placed in the
contractor’s file. A third violation will result in permanent revocation of
the contractor’s burn pile access privileges, and subject the contractor to
a fine, as described in this chapter.



(Prior Code, § 6-10-6) (Am. Ord. O-12-036, passed 3-13-2012)



§ 50.99  PENALTY.



   Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be fined not
less than $25 per day nor more than $750 per day.



(Ord. O-13-092, passed 8-13-2013)

GENERAL PROVISIONS




§ 51.001  USE OF PUBLIC SEWERS REQUIRED.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to place, deposit, or
permit to be deposited, in any unsanitary manner on public or private
property within the city, or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city,
any human or animal excrement, garbage, or other objectionable waste.



   (B)   It shall be unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within
the city, or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city, any sewage or
other polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has been provided in
accordance with subsequent provisions of this subchapter.



   (C)   Except as hereinafter provided, it shall be unlawful to
construct or maintain any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool, or other
facility intended or used for the disposal of sewage.



   (D)   The owner of all the houses, buildings, or properties used for
human occupancy, employment, recreation, or other purposes situated within
the city, and abutting on any street, alley, or right-of-way in which there
is now located or may in the future be located any public sanitary sewer of
the city, is hereby required, at the owner’s expense, to install suitable
toilet facilities therein and to connect the facilities directly with the
proper public sewer, in accordance with the provisions of this subchapter,
within 90 days after date of official notice to do so, provided that the
public sewer is within 100 feet of the property line.



   (E)   The owner of the property, the occupant thereof, and the user
of the service, shall be jointly and severally liable to pay for the service
to the property. The service is furnished to the property by the city only
upon the condition that the owner of the property, occupant, and user of the
service are jointly and severally liable therefore to the city. Property
owners shall be responsible for maintaining and repairing sewer service lines
to the main sewer line.



(Prior Code, § 6-4-1)  Penalty, see § 51.999



§ 51.002  PERMITTED AND NON-PERMITTED USES.



   (A)   No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any storm
water, surface water, ground water roof runoff, subsurface drainage,
uncontaminated cooling water, or unpolluted industrial process waters to any
sanitary sewer.



   (B)   Storm water and all other unpolluted drainage shall be
discharged to the sewers which are specifically designated as storm sewers,
or to a natural outlet approved by the Public Service Superintendent.



   (C)   Industrial cooling water or unpolluted process waters may be
discharged on approval of the Public Service Superintendent to a storm sewer
or natural outlet.



   (D)   No person shall discharge, or cause to be discharged, any of
the following described waters or wastes to any public sewers:



      (1)   Any gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil, or other
flammable or explosive liquid, solid, or gas;



      (2)   Any waters or wastes containing toxic or poisonous
solids, liquids, or gases in sufficient quantity, either singly or by
interaction with other wastes, to injure or interfere with any sewage
treatment process, constitute a hazard to humans or animals, create a public
nuisance, or create any hazard in the receiving waters of the sewage
treatment plant;



      (3)   Any waters or wastes having a pH lower than 5.5, or
having any other corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to
structures, equipment, and personnel of the sewage works; or



      (4)   Solid or viscous substances in quantities or of size
capable of causing obstruction to the flow in sewers or other interference
with the proper operation of the sewage works, such as, but not limited to,
ashes, cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers,
tar, plastics, wood, unground garbage, whole blood, paunch manure, hair, and
fleshings, entrails and paper dishes, cups, milk containers and the like,
either whole or ground by garbage grinders, grass clippings, weeds or other
vegetation.



   (E)   No person shall discharge, or cause to be discharged, the
following described substances, materials, waters, or wastes, if it appears
likely in the opinion of the Chief Wastewater Operator that the wastes can
harm either the sewers’ sewage treatment process or equipment, have an
adverse effect on the receiving stream, or can otherwise endanger life, limb,
public property, or constitute a nuisance.  In forming an opinion as to the
acceptability of these wastes, the Chief Wastewater Operator will give
consideration to factors such as the quantities of subject wastes in relation
to flows and velocities in the sewers, materials of construction of the
sewers, nature of the sewage treatment process, capacity of the sewage
treatment plant, degree of treatability of wastes in the sewage treatment
plant, and maximum limits established by regulatory agencies. The substances
prohibited are:



      (1)   Any liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than 150
° F;



      (2)   Any waters or wastes containing toxic or poisonous
materials, or oils, whether emulsified or not, in excess of 100 mg/l or
containing substances which may solidify or become viscous at temperatures
between 32 ° F and 150 ° F;



      (3)   Any garbage that has not been properly shredded. The
installation and operation of any garbage grinder equipped with a motor of
three-fourths horsepower (0.76 hp metric) or greater shall be subject to the
review and approval of the Plumbing Inspector;



      (4)   Any waters or wastes containing strong acid, iron
pickling wastes, or concentrated plating solution, whether neutralized or not;



      (5)   Any waters or wastes containing iron, chromium, copper,
zinc, or similar objectionable or toxic substances, or wastes exerting an
excessive chlorine requirement to the degree that any  material received in
the composite sewage at the sewage treatment works exceeds the limits
established by the Chief Wastewater Operator for the materials;



      (6)   Any waters or wastes containing phenols or other taste
or odor producing substances in concentrations exceeding limits which may be
established by the Chief Wastewater Operator, as necessary, after treatment
of the composite sewage, to meet the requirements of the state, federal, or
other public agencies of jurisdiction for the discharge to the receiving
waters;



      (7)   Any radioactive wastes or isotopes of half life or
concentration as may exceed limits established by the Chief Wastewater
Operator in compliance with applicable state or federal regulations;



      (8)   Any wastes or waters having a pH in excess of 9.5;



      (9)   Any mercury or any of its compounds in excess of 0.0005
mg/l as Hg at any time except as permitted by the Chief Wastewater Operator
in compliance with applicable state and federal regulations;



      (10)   Any cyanide in excess of .005 mg/l at any time except
as permitted by the Chief Wastewater Operator in compliance with applicable
state and federal regulations;



      (11)   Materials which exert or cause:



         (a)   Unusual concentrations of inert suspended solids
(such as, but not limited to, fullers earth, lime slurries, and lime
residues), or of dissolved solids (such as, but not limited to, sodium
chloride and sodium sulfate);



         (b)   Excessive discoloration (such as, but not limited
to, dye wastes and vegetable tanning solutions);



         (c)   Unusual BOD, chemical oxygen demand, or chlorine
requirements in quantities as to constitute a significant load on the sewage
treatment works; and



         (d)   Unusual volume of flow or concentration of wastes
constituting slugs. SLUG shall mean discharge of water, sewage, or industrial
waste which, in concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of low,
exceeds for any period of duration longer than 15 minutes and more than five
times the average 24-hour concentration of flows during normal operation.



      (12)   Waters or wastes containing substances which are not
amenable to treatment or reduction by the sewage treatment processes
employed, or are amenable to treatment only to the degree that the sewage
treatment plant effluent cannot meet the requirements of agencies having
jurisdiction over discharge to the receiving waters.



(Prior Code, § 6-4-2)  (Ord. O-13-076, passed 3-12-2013)   Penalty, see §
51.999



§ 51.003  AUTHORITY OF CHIEF WASTEWATER OPERATOR.



   (A)   If any waters or wastes are discharged, or are proposed to be
discharged, to the public sewers, which waters contain the substances or
possess the characteristics enumerated in § 51.002 and/or which are in
violation of the standards for pretreatment provided in 40 C.F.R. part 403,
June 26, 1978, and any amendments thereto, and which, in the judgment of the
Chief Wastewater Operator, may have a deleterious effect upon the sewage
works, processes, equipment, or receiving waters, or which otherwise create a
hazard to life or constitute a public nuisance, the Chief Wastewater Operator
may:



      (1)   Reject the wastes;



      (2)   Require pretreatment to an acceptable condition for
discharge to the public sewers;



      (3)   Require control over the quantities and rates of
discharge; and/or



      (4)   Require payment to cover the added costs of handling and
treating the wastes not covered by existing taxes or sewer charges, under the
provisions of this subchapter.



   (B)   If the Chief Wastewater Operator permits the pretreatment or
equalization of waste flows, the design and installation of the plants and
equipment shall be subject to the review and approval of the Chief Wastewater
Operator, and subject to the requirements of all applicable codes,
ordinances, and laws.



(Prior Code, § 6-4-3)



§ 51.004  UNLAWFUL TO DAMAGE SEWAGE WORKS.



   No unauthorized person shall maliciously, willfully, or negligently
break, damage, destroy, or tamper with any structure, appurtenance, or
equipment which is a part of the sewage works.



(Prior Code, § 6-4-12)  Penalty, see § 51.999



§ 51.005  ENFORCEMENT AND COMPLIANCE.



   (A)   The Water and Sewer Superintendent and the Plumbing Inspector,
and other duly authorized employees of the city, the State Environmental
Protection Agency, and the United States Environmental Protection Agency,
bearing proper credentials and identification, shall be permitted to enter
all properties for the purposes of inspection, observations, measurement,
sampling, and testing, in accordance with the provisions of this subchapter.



   (B)   The Water and Sewer Superintendent and the Plumbing Inspector,
or their representative, shall have no authority to inquire into any
processes, including metallurgical, chemical, oil refining, ceramic, paper,
or other industries, beyond that point having a direct bearing on the kind
and source of discharge to the sewers or waterways or facilities for waste
treatment.



   (C)   While performing the necessary work on private properties
referred to in this section, the Water and Sewer Superintendent and the
Plumbing Inspector, or duly authorized employees of the city, the State
Environmental Protection Agency, and the United States Environmental
Protection Agency, shall observe all safety rules applicable to the premises
established by the company, and the company shall be held harmless for injury
or death to the city employees, and the city shall indemnify the company
against liability claims and demands for personal injury or property damage
asserted against the company and growing out of the gauging and sampling
operating, except as may be caused by negligence or failure of the company to
maintain conditions as required in § 51.021.



   (D)   (1)   The Water and Sewer Superintendent and the Plumbing
Inspector, and other duly authorized employees of the city bearing proper
credentials and identification, shall be permitted to enter all private
properties through which the city holds a duly negotiated easement for the
purposes of, but not limited to, inspection, observation, measurement,
sampling, repair, and maintenance of any portion of the sewage works lying
within the easement.



      (2)   All entry and subsequent work, if any, on the easement
shall be done in full accordance with the terms of the duly negotiated
easement pertaining to the private property involved.



(Prior Code, § 6-4-13)




TESTING AND TREATMENT




§ 51.020  INTERCEPTORS, PRELIMINARY TREATMENT, AND CONTROL MANHOLE REQUIRED.



   (A)   Grease, oil, and sand interceptors shall be provided when, in
the opinion of the Water and Sewer Superintendent or the Plumbing Inspector,
they are necessary for the proper handling of liquid wastes containing grease
in excessive amounts, or any flammable wastes, sand, or other harmful
ingredients; except, that interceptors shall not be required for private
living quarters or dwelling units. All interceptors shall be of a type and
capacity approved by the Water and Sewer Superintendent or the Plumbing
Inspector, and shall be located as to be readily and easily accessible for
cleaning and inspection.



   (B)   Where preliminary treatment or flow-equalizing facilities are
provided, they shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory and effective
operation by the owner at the owner’s expense.



   (C)   Each industry shall be required to install a control manhole
and, when required by the Water and Sewer Superintendent or the Plumbing
Inspector, the  owner of any property serviced by a building sewer carrying
industrial wastes shall install a suitable control manhole together with the
necessary meters and other appurtenances in the building sewer to facilitate
observation, sampling, and measurement of the wastes. The manhole, when
required, shall be accessibly and safely located and shall be constructed in
accordance with plans approved by the Water and Sewer Superintendent or the
Plumbing Inspector. The manhole shall be installed by the owner at the
owner’s expense and shall be maintained by the owner so as to be safe and
accessible at all times.



(Prior Code, § 6-4-4)



§ 51.021  INDUSTRIAL WASTE TESTING REQUIRED.



   (A)   The owner of any property serviced by a building sewer
carrying industrial wastes shall provide laboratory measurements, tests, and
analyses of waters and wastes to illustrate compliance with this subchapter
and any special conditions for discharge established by the city or
regulatory agencies having jurisdiction over the discharge.



   (B)   The number, type, and frequency of laboratory analyses to be
performed by the owner shall be as stipulated by the city, but no less than
once per year, the industry must supply a complete analysis of the
constituents of the wastewater discharge to assure that compliance with
federal, state, and local standards are being met. The owner shall report the
results of measurements and laboratory analyses to the city at the times and
in the manner as prescribed by the city. The owner shall bear the expense of
all measurements, analyses, and reporting required by the city. At times as
deemed necessary, the city reserves the right to take measurements and
samples for analysis by an outside laboratory service.



   (C)   All measurements, tests, and analyses of the characteristics
of waters and wastes to which reference is made in this subchapter shall be
determined in accordance with the latest edition of IEPA Division of
Laboratories Manual of Laboratory Methods, and shall be determined at the
control manhole provided, or, upon suitable samples taken at the control
manhole. In the event that no special manhole has been required, the control
manhole shall be considered to be the nearest downstream manhole in the
public sewer to the point at which the building sewer is connected. Sampling
shall be carried out by customarily accepted methods to reflect the effect of
constituents upon the sewage works and to determine the existence of hazards
to life, limb, and property. The particular analyses involved will determine
whether a 24-hour composite of all out falls of a property is appropriate, or
whether a grab sample or samples should be taken. Normally, but not always,
BOD and suspended solids analyses are obtained from 24-hour composites of all
out falls, whereas pHs are determined from periodic grab samples.



   (D)   No statement contained in this section shall be construed as
preventing any special agreement or arrangement between the city and any
industrial concern, whereby an industrial waste of unusual strength or
character may be accepted by the city for treatment, subject to payment
therefore, in accordance with §§ 51.080 through 51.086 of this chapter, by
the industrial concern, provided the payments are in accordance with federal
and state guidelines for user charge system.



(Prior Code, § 6-4-5)




BUILDING SEWERS AND CONNECTIONS




§ 51.035  OWNER AND USER LIABILITY.



   (A)   The owner of property, the occupant thereof, and the user of
the service shall be jointly and severally liable to pay for the service to
the property. The service is furnished to the property by the city only upon
the condition that the owner of the property, occupant, and user of service
are jointly and severally liable therefore to the city. Property owners shall
be responsible for maintaining and repairing sewer service lines from the
sewer main, including the tap at the main.



   (B)   All disposals by any person into the sewer system are unlawful
except those discharges in compliance with federal standards promulgated
pursuant to the Federal Act, and more stringent state and local standards.



(Prior Code, § 6-4-6)



§ 51.036  PERMIT REQUIRED; FEE.



   (A)   No unauthorized person shall uncover, make any connections
with or opening into, use, alter, or disturb any public sewer or appurtenance
thereof, without first obtaining a written permit from the Plumbing Inspector
approved by the Water and Sewer Superintendent.



   (B)   (1)   There shall be two classes of sewer permits:



         (a)   For residential wastewater service; and



         (b)   For commercial, institutional/governmental, or
industrial wastewater service.



      (2)   In either case, the owner or owner’s agent shall make
application on a special form furnished by the Water and Sewer Superintendent.



   (C)   The permit application shall be supplemented by any plans,
specifications, or other information considered pertinent in the judgment of
the Water and Sewer Superintendent. Industrial entities must provide
information describing its wastewater constituents, characteristics, and type
of activity. A fee of $100 shall be paid to the city at the time an
application for either a Class A or Class B sanitary sewer connection permit
is submitted to the city.



   (D)   A building sewer permit will only be issued, and a sewer
connection shall only be allowed, if it can be demonstrated that the
downstream sewerage facilities, including sewers, pump stations, and
wastewater treatment facilities, have sufficient reserve capacity to
adequately and efficiently handle the additional anticipated waste load.



(Prior Code, § 6-4-6)



§ 51.037  INSTALLATION AND SAFETY SPECIFICATIONS.



   (A)   All costs and expenses incident to the installation and
connection of the building sewer shall be borne by the owner. The owner shall
indemnify the city from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be
occasioned by the installation of the building sewer.



   (B)   A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided
for every building, except where one building stands at the rear of another
on an interior lot and no private sewer is available or can be constructed to
the rear building through an adjoining alley, court, yard, or driveway, the
building sewer from the front building may be extended to the rear building
and the whole considered as one building sewer.



   (C)   Old building sewers may be used in connection with new
buildings only when they are found on examination and testing by the Water
and Sewer Superintendent to meet all requirements of this subchapter.



   (D)   The size, slope, alignment, materials of construction of a
building sewer, and the methods to be used in excavating, placing of the
pipe, jointing, testing, and backfilling the trench shall all conform to the
requirements of the Building and Plumbing Code, or other applicable rules and
regulations of the city. In the absence of code provisions or in
amplification thereof, the materials and procedures set forth in appropriate
specifications of the American Society of Testing Materials, Water Pollution
Control Federation Manual of Practice No. 9, and Standard Specifications for
Water and Sewer Main Construction in the state shall apply.



   (E)   Whenever possible, the building sewer shall be brought to the
building at an elevation below the basement floor. In all buildings in which
any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer,
sanitary sewage carried by the building drain shall be lifted by a means
which is approved in accordance with this section, and discharged to the
building sewer.



   (F)   No person(s) shall make connection of roof downspouts,
exterior foundation drains, areaway drains, or other sources of surface
runoff or groundwater to a building sewer or building drain which in turn is
connected directly or indirectly to a public sanitary sewer.



   (G)   The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer
shall conform to the requirements of the Building and Plumbing Code or other
applicable rules and regulations of the city or the procedures set forth in
appropriate specifications of the American Society of Testing Materials,
Water Pollution Control Federal Manual of Practice No. 9, and Standard
Specifications for Water and Sewer Main Construction in the state. All
connections shall be made gastight and watertight. Any deviation from the
prescribed procedures and materials must be approved by the Water and Sewer
Superintendent before installation.



   (H)   The applicant for the building sewer permit shall notify the
Water and Sewer Superintendent or the Plumbing Inspector when the building
sewer is ready for inspection and connection to the public sewer. The
connection shall be made under the supervision of the Plumbing Inspector, the
Water and Sewer Superintendent, or a designated representative.



   (I)   All excavations for building sewer installation shall be
adequately guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public
from hazard. Streets, sidewalks, parkways, and other public property
disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored in a manner
satisfactory to the city and in accordance to the city code of ordinances.



(Prior Code, § 6-4-6)



§ 51.037.5  SANITARY SEWER SYSTEM CONSTRUCTION.



   (A)   Designed to meet or exceed all regulations of the state
statutes, State Environmental Protection Agency, and United States
Environmental Protection Agency in regard to sanitary sewer construction.



   (B)   Minimum sewer main specifications shall be SDR 26 PVC pipe
equivalent or better.



   (C)   Lift station design and location must be approved by the Chief
Wastewater Operator and the Water and Sewer Superintendent. Lift stations
shall be designed and constructed to be no less than five feet in diameter
and contain only submersible pumps.



   (D)   Service line extends from the sanitary sewer system to the lot
line of each lot.



   (E)   Service lines of each lot are clearly marked after completion
of the improvements.



   (F)   Drawings and plans for the proposed collection system must be
approved by the Chief Wastewater Operator and the Water and Sewer
Superintendent prior to construction.



   (G)   Any sewer not meeting a minimum depth of three feet shall be
insulated.



(Prior Code, § 4-1-10)  (Ord. O-15-138, passed 8-11-2015)



§ 51.038  SEWAGE LIFT STATION.



   (A)   A sewage lift station may be constructed by a person for
connection to the sewerage system of the city. The sewage lift station shall
be designed and constructed in accordance with all regulations of the state
statutes, the State Environmental Protection Agency, and the United States
Environmental Protection Agency. An application must be submitted to the
Water and Sewer Board, and the Water and Sewer Board must accept the design
prior to installation.



   (B)   The application must furnish information showing the contract
installed price, engineering data, construction design, operation manual, and
any other information from which the number of units of capacity of the lift
station can be determined. The unit of capacity is established as follows:



      (1)   Individual dwelling:  one unit;



      (2)   Commercial establishments:  two units;



      (3)   Motel or hotel:  one-third unit per rental space plus
one unit per permanent residence; and



      (4)   New subdivisions:  one unit per residential lot; two
units per commercial lot.



   (C)   The lift station and any easements shall be dedicated to the
city prior to acceptance of wastewater. All expenses, including legal
expenses incurred prior to dedication, are not reimbursable by the city, nor
chargeable to the city.



(Prior Code, § 6-4-10)




SEWER SERVICE OUTSIDE CITY




§ 51.050  WHEN SERVICE PERMISSIBLE.



   Any property located outside the city limits which is currently
connected to and serviced by the city’s sewer system shall be allowed to
continue to be so serviced, subject to the rate provisions of §§ 51.080
through 51.086 of this chapter, and subject to all other applicable city
ordinances and regulations.



(Prior Code, § 6-4-11)



§ 51.051  PERMIT REQUIRED; FEE.



   (A)   Any property contiguous to but located outside the corporate
limits of the city which is not currently connected to and serviced by the
city’s sewer system shall not be allowed to receive sewer service unless
and until the property is annexed into the city.



   (B)   Notwithstanding this prohibition, the city may supply sewer
service to any property located outside the corporate limits, and not
contiguous therewith, provided that all of the following conditions apply:



      (1)   There are sewer service mains currently adjacent to the
property or within the proximity that, in the discretion of the Water and
Sewer Superintendent of the city, it is reasonable to connect sewer service
lines to the property;



      (2)   The owner requesting connection to the city’s sewer
system obtains a permit and pays for the cost of the extension and connection
and any permit fees required by the city; and



      (3)   The owners of the property enter into an agreement to
annex to the city at the time the property does become contiguous to the
city, which agreement shall run with the land.



   (C)   The fees herein above provided shall be in addition to any
charge for inspection as heretofore or hereafter provided. All connections,
installations, and repairs shall be inspected and are required to conform to
like standards, both as to material and manner of installation, as
connections made within the city shall apply with equal force to connections
made or continued by virtue of this subchapter.



(Prior Code, § 6-4-11)



§ 51.052  DISCONNECTION BY CITY PERMITTED.



   (A)   In the event that any owner of any property outside the limits
of the city, which property is presently or will be connected to the sewer
system of the city, fails to make application and be granted a permit, the
Water and Sewer Superintendent shall plug the sewer connection at the point
of entry to the city sewer system. The Water and Sewer Superintendent shall
also discontinue city’s water service.



   (B)   In the event that the Council determines at any time that the
sewer system is overloaded, the city may, and the right is reserved, upon
three months notice to the occupants of the property concerned, mailed to the
address to which bills are customarily addressed, close and disconnect from
the city sewer system any sewer serving property outside the limits of the
city. However, no disconnection for this reason shall be ordered for a period
of one year from and after the effective date of this subchapter.



   (C)   In the event any sewer improvement or replacement program is
undertaken by the city, either within the one-year period or after, the
financing of which is provided for either by a voluntary program or by the
levying of assessments upon property within the limits of the city, then
users of the sewer system outside the limits of the city shall be required to
pay a proportional share of the cost of the improvement or replacement
program, the share to be fixed as to each property serviced in a manner
substantially like the manner in which the amount assessed against property
within the limits of the city is fixed. However, in regard to property
outside the limits of the city, the determination of the Council of the city
as to the amounts payable from each property shall be final, and in the event
payment is not made in the manner and at the time fixed by the Council, water
and sewer service may be discontinued.



   (D)   In the event charges for sewage disposal are imposed within
the city, the charge as is provided shall automatically increase by the
amount of the charge made for like service within the city.



(Prior Code, § 6-4-11)



§ 51.053  OWNER RESPONSIBLE FOR EXPENSE AND MAINTENANCE.



   The city assumes no obligation for any sewer from the point of
connection with the city sewer system. All repairs, maintenance, easements,
connections, and extensions outside the limits of the city and including the
connection within the city limits necessary to connect to existing city’s
sewer system shall be at the expense of the owners of the properties served.



(Prior Code, § 6-4-11)




PRIVATE SEWAGE DISPOSAL




§ 51.065  PERMITTED IN ABSENCE OF PUBLIC SEWER.



   Where a public sanitary sewer is not available under § 51.001, the
building sewer shall be connected to a private sewage disposal system
complying with the provisions of § 51.066 of this subchapter.



(Prior Code, § 6-4-7)



§ 51.066  PERMIT REQUIRED; FEE; REQUIREMENTS.



   (A)   Before commencement of construction of a private sewage
disposal system, the owner shall first meet any and all requirements of the
county. The owner will also obtain a written permit signed by a County Health
Official. The application for the permit shall be made on a form furnished by
the city, which the applicant shall supplement by any plans, specifications,
and other information as deemed necessary by the Plumbing Inspector, the
Water and Sewer Superintendent, or a County Health Official.



   (B)   A permit for a private sewage disposal system shall not become
effective until the installation is completed to the satisfaction of the
County Health Official.



   (C)   The type, capacities, location, and layout of a private sewage
disposal system shall comply with all recommendations of the State Private
Sewage Disposal Licensing Act and Code, and with the State Environmental
Protection Agency. No permit shall be issued for any private sewage disposal
system employing subsurface soil absorption facilities where the area of the
lot is less than 7,500 square feet.  No septic tank or cesspool shall be
permitted to discharge to any natural outlet.



   (D)   The owner shall operate and maintain the private sewage
disposal facilities in a sanitary manner at all times and at no expense to
the city.



   (E)   No statement contained in this section shall be construed to
interfere with any additional requirements that may be imposed by the County
Health Department.



(Prior Code, § 6-4-8)



§ 51.067  DISCONTINUANCE OF USE REQUIRED.



   (A)   At such time as a public sewer becomes available to a property
served by a private sewage disposal system, a direct connection shall be made
to the public sewer in compliance with this subchapter.



   (B)   When a public sewer becomes available, the building sewer
shall be connected to the sewer within 60 days after notification by the
County Health Department that the private sewage disposal system is declared
nonfunctional. The private sewage disposal system shall be cleaned of sludge
and filled with clean bank run gravel or dirt.



(Prior Code, § 6-4-9)




SEWER SERVICE CHARGES




§ 51.080  WASTEWATER SERVICE CHARGES.



   The wastewater service charge for the use of and for service supplied
by the wastewater facilities of the city shall consist of a basic user
charge, a debt service charge, a capital improvement charge, and applicable
surcharges.



(Prior Code, § 6-5-1)



§ 51.081  BASIC USER CHARGE.



   (A)   The basic user charge is levied on all users to recover the
operation and maintenance plus replacement (O, M and R) costs, and shall be
based on water usage, as recorded by water meters or sewage meters, for
wastes having the following normal domestic concentrations:



      (1)   A five day, 20 ° C biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) of
240 mg/l; and



      (2)   A suspended solids content of 243 mg/l.



   (B)   A basic user charge shall be computed as follows:



      (1)   Estimate the annual wastewater volume, pounds of BOD,
and pounds of SS to be treated;



      (2)   Estimate the projected annual revenue required to
operate and maintain the wastewater facilities, including a replacement fund
for the year, for all works categories;



      (3)   Proportion the estimated O, M and R costs to each user
class by volume, BOD, and SS;



      (4)   Proportion the estimated O, M and R costs to wastewater
facility categories by volume, BOD, and SS;



      (5)   Compute costs per 1,000 gallons for normal domestic
strength sewage; and



      (6)   Compute surcharge costs per pound for BOD and SS
concentrations in excess of normal domestic strengths.



(Prior Code, § 6-5-2)



§ 51.082  DEBT SERVICE CHARGE.



   The debt service charge is computed by apportioning the annual debt
service as a fixed charge per billing period.



(Prior Code, § 6-5-3)



§ 51.083  CAPITAL IMPROVEMENT CHARGE.



   The capital improvement charge is levied on users to provide for
capital improvements, extensions, or reconstruction of the sewage treatment
works. The capital improvement charge is computed by apportioning the annual
amount to be accrued as a fixed charge per billing period.



(Prior Code, § 6-5-4)



§ 51.084  SURCHARGE.



   (A)   A surcharge will be levied to all users whose waters exceed
the normal domestic concentrations of BOD and SS, as recorded by water meters
or sewage meters, for all wastes which exceed the 240 mg/l and 243 mg/l
concentration for BOD and SS, respectively.



   (B)   The concentration of wastes used for computing surcharges
shall be established by waste sampling. Waste sampling shall be performed as
often as may be deemed necessary by the Chief Wastewater Operator and shall
be binding as a basis for surcharges.



(Prior Code, § 6-5-5)



§ 51.085  REVIEW OF CHARGE.



   The adequacy of the wastewater and water service charge will be
reviewed not less often than annually by the City Council during the annual
budget preparation for the city. The wastewater and water service charges
shall be revised periodically to reflect a change in local capital costs,
operation, maintenance, and replacement costs.



(Prior Code, § 6-5-6)  (Ord. O-12-054, passed 7-10-2012)



§ 51.086  MEASUREMENT OF FLOW.



   (A)   The volume of flow used for computing basic user charges and
surcharges shall be the metered water consumption read to the lowest
increments of ten gallons.



   (B)   If the person discharging wastes into the public sewers
procures any part, or all, of their water from sources other than the
city’s waterworks system, and all or part of which is discharged into the
public sewers, then the person shall install and maintain, at their expense,
a water meter approved by the Water and Sewer Superintendent for the purpose
of determining the volume of water obtained from these other sources.



   (C)   Devices for measuring the volume of waste discharges may be
required by the Water and Sewer Superintendent if these volumes cannot
otherwise be determined from the metered water consumption records.



   (D)   Metering devices for determining the volume of waste shall be
installed, owned, and maintained by the person. Following approval and
installation, the meters may not be removed, unless service is canceled,
without the consent of the Water and Sewer Superintendent.



(Prior Code, § 6-5-8)



§ 51.999  PENALTY.



   (A)   (1)   Any person found to be violating any provision of
§§ 51.001 through 51.067 of this chapter, except § 51.004, shall be served
by the city with written notice stating the nature of the violation and
providing a reasonable time limit for the satisfactory correction thereof.
The offender shall, within the period of time stated in the notice,
permanently cease all violations. The city may revoke any permit for sewage
disposal as a result of any violation of any provision of this chapter.



      (2)   Any person who shall continue any violation beyond the
time limit provided shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction
thereof, shall be fined not less than $100 nor more than $750 for each
violation. Each day in which any violation shall continue shall be deemed a
separate offense.



      (3)   Any person violating any of the provisions of this
chapter shall become liable to the city by reasons of the violation.



(Prior Code, 6-4-14)



   (B)   Any person violating § 51.004 shall be subject to immediate
arrest under charge of disorderly conduct.



(Prior Code, § 6-4-12)

(Prior Code, § 6-5-9)   (Ord. O-12-053, passed 7-10-2012; Ord. O-18-24,
passed 12-11-2018)

   A fixed charge associated with debt service charges and capital
improvement charge is hereby established per billing period.  The fixed
charges, copies of which are on file in the office of the City Clerk, are
adopted and incorporated as part of this code of ordinances as fully as if
set out at length herein.



(Prior Code, § 6-5-10)   (Ord. O-12-053, passed 7-10-2012; Ord. O-18-24,
passed 12-11-2018)



SCHEDULE III.  UNMETERED USER RATE.



   (A)   All non-metered residential users of the wastewater facilities
shall pay a flat rate charge.



   (B)   In the event use of the wastewater facilities is determined by
the Chief Water Operator to be in excess of 6,000 gallons per month, the
Chief Water Operator may require the flat rate user to install metering
devices on the water supply or sewer main to measure the amount of service
supplied.



   (C)    The non-metered rates, copies of which are on file in the
office of the City Clerk, are adopted and incorporated as part of this code
of ordinances as fully as if set out at length herein.



(Prior Code, § 6-5-11)  (Ord. O-12-053, passed 7-10-2012; Ord. O-18-24,
passed 12-11-2018)



SCHEDULE IV.  SURCHARGE RATES.



   The rates of surcharges for BOD and SS, copies of which are on file in
the office of the City Clerk, are adopted and incorporated as part of this
code of ordinances as fully as if set out at length herein.



(Prior Code, § 6-5-12)

GENERAL PROVISIONS




§ 52.01  FINANCIAL REPORTING SYSTEM.



   (A)   The City Treasurer shall establish a proper system of accounts
and shall keep proper books, records, and accounts in which complete and
current entries shall be made of all transactions relative to each of the
city’s public utility systems.



   (B)   The City Council shall cause to be made an audit by an
independent auditing firm of the books of the Municipal Electric Light and
Power Public Utility to show the receipts and disbursements of the Electric
Utility system. The audit shall be presented to the City Council within six
months of the end of the preceding fiscal year.



   (C)   The Water and Sewer Board shall cause to be made an audit by
an independent auditing firm of the books of the Waterworks System and
Sewerage System to show the receipts and disbursements of the waterworks
system and the sewerage system. The audit shall be presented to the City
Council within six months of the end of the preceding fiscal year.



   (D)   Audit reports shall be prepared in accordance with generally
accepted accounting principles for state and local government as provided in
the current edition of Governmental Accounting, Auditing, and Financial
Reporting, published by the Municipal Finance Officers Association.



   (E)   The State Environmental Protection Agency or the United States
Environmental Protection Agency, or their authorized representatives, shall
have access to any books, documents, papers, and records of the city which
are applicable to the city’s sewerage system user charges for the purpose
of making audit, examination, excerpts, and transcriptions thereof to insure
compliance with the special conditions relating to the city’s grant number
C172010-01.



(Prior Code, § 6-6-15)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 52.02  DEPOSIT OF REVENUE.



   (A)   All revenues and moneys derived from the operation of the
Municipal Electric Light and Power Public Utility shall be deposited in the
operating account of the Municipal Electric Light and Power Public Utility.



   (B)   All revenues and moneys derived from the operation of the
Waterworks System Utility shall be deposited in the operating account of the
Waterworks System Utility.



   (C)   All revenues and moneys derived from the operation of the
Sewerage System Utility shall be deposited in the operating account of the
Sewerage System Utility.



   (D)   All revenues and moneys shall be held by the City Treasurer
separate and apart from private funds and separate from all other funds of
the city, and all of the sum, without any deductions whatsoever, shall be
deposited into the respective accounts by the City Treasurer no later than
two days after receipt of the same.



   (E)   The treasurer shall administer the funds in every respect in
the manner provided by statute of the Revised Cities and Villages Act,
effective January, 1942.



(Prior Code, § 6-6-14)



§ 52.03  RESTRICTIONS ON WATER USE.



   (A)   The Mayor or Water and Sewer Superintendent shall have the
power whenever, in their opinion, the public good requires it, to proclaim
that no water from the waterworks system of the city shall be used for the
named purposes. It shall be unlawful for any person to use water from the
city waterworks system for the named purposed during the time when the Mayor
or the Water and Sewer Superintendent shall by proclamation have prohibited
its use.



   (B)   The Mayor or the Water and Sewer Superintendent of the city
may, whenever it is in the best interest of the city, shut off the water
either permanently or for the length of time as shall be deemed advisable.
When the city water is shut off, no damage shall be asked or claimed by
reason thereof by any user or heirs, assigns, tenants, or legal
representatives.



(Prior Code, § 6-6-5)




SERVICE AND BILLING




§ 52.15  APPLICATION FOR SERVICE.



   An application for initial electric or water service must be done in
person at the Municipal Utilities Office, 115 S. Oakwood Avenue. Service
shall be disconnected for lack of an application.



(Prior Code, § 6-6-1)  (Ord. 1936, passed 4-14-2009)



§ 52.16  DEPOSIT REQUIRED.



   (A)   Residential.  A deposit for electric service and a deposit
for water and sewer service shall be paid by a person requesting service at a
particular address in the city. The amount of each such deposit shall be such
amount as set by the utility payment policy then in force and effect at the
time of the request. The deposit is required of all persons requesting
service within the city. In addition, a such deposits shall be required for
all persons who currently receive utility service from the city and who fall
into one of the following categories:



      (1)   Have failed to pay a final utility bill at a prior
address;



      (2)   Have tendered payment of a utility bill that has been
dishonored or rejected for insufficient funds; or



      (3)   Have had a notice of shut-off physically delivered to
the property receiving service one or more times within the prior 12 months.
The deposit shall be paid in accordance with the utility payment policy then
in force and effect.



   (B)   Commercial.



      (1)   A deposit for electric service and a deposit for water
and sewer service shall be paid by all commercial or industrial customers
making an initial request for service from the city. The amount of the
deposit shall be such amount as set by the Utility Payment Policy then in
force and effect at the time of the request. The deposit is required from all
commercial and industrial customers and all deposit requirements must be
fulfilled within 120 days of commencing service.



      (2)   A deposit shall be required for all commercial customers
that began receiving service after December 31, 2013 and who have not made a
deposit with the city. The amount of the deposit shall be such amount as set
by the utility payment policy then in force and effect at the time of the
request.



      (3)   A deposit shall be required from any commercial
customers that began receiving service prior to January 1, 2014 that fall
into one of the following categories:



         (a)   Have failed to pay a final utility bill at a prior
address;



         (b)   Have delivered bad checks in payment of utility
bills; or



         (c)   Have had a notice of shut-off physically delivered
to the property receiving service. The amount of the deposit shall be such
amount as set by the utility payment policy then in force and effect at the
time of the request.



   (C)   Deposits.  All deposits provided for in this section shall be
deposited in interest-bearing accounts in accordance with city investment
policies. Refunds and adjustments to commercial deposits shall be made as per
the utility payment policy then in force and effect at the time of the
request.



   (D)   Representatives of the Municipal Utilities reserve the right
to investigate all requests for initial and reconnected service and shall
require a deposit as allowed in this subchapter.



(Prior Code, § 6-6-2)  (Ord. 1936, passed 4-14-2009; Ord. O-14-122, passed
11-11-2014; Ord. O-01-01, passed 2-14-2017; Ord. O-17-31, passed 12-12-2017)



§ 52.17  DISCONTINUATION OF SERVICE; NOTICE.



   Electric and water service shall be terminated if any of the following
conditions occur:



   (A)   A customer fails to pay a deposit when required under the
provisions of this subchapter;



   (B)   A customer fails to pay for past services more than eight days
in arrears;



   (C)   A deferred payment arrangement cannot be reached with the
customer and owner, or the customer does not adhere to the deferred payment
arrangement;



   (D)   Nonpayment for unmetered electric or water service;



   (E)   Failure, after written notice has been delivered mailed to the
customer’s address in which a non-operating or faulty meter is located, to
permit the city physical access to install a replacement meter or to repair a
meter;



   (F)   User’s property has been determined unsafe by any of the
city’s inspectors or the City Fire Chief;



   (G)   A customer obtains electric or water service by fraudulent
means or submitted an application which contained misrepresentation,
falsifications, or material omission of requested information of the
applicant; or



   (H)   Wherein any connection in violation of the provisions of this
subchapter is known to exist.



(Prior Code, § 6-6-3)  (Ord. 1936, passed 4-14-2009; Ord. O-14-122, passed
11-11-2014; Ord. O-17-03, passed 1-10-2017; Ord. O-17-31, passed 12-12-2017;
Ord. O-18-05, passed 6-12-2018)



§ 52.18  PROCESSING FEE.



   A processing fee for disconnection of service shall be charged when an
account reaches shut-off status as defined in the utility payment policy and
in such amounts as provided therein.



(Prior Code, § 6-6-4)  (Ord. 1936, passed 4-14-2009; Ord. O-17-31, passed
12-12-2017)



§ 52.19  RESTRICTIVE USE OF WATER.



   (A)   The Mayor or City Administrator shall have the power whenever,
in his or her opinion, the public good requires it to proclaim that no water
from the waterworks system of the city shall be used for the named purposes.
It shall be unlawful for any person to use water from the city waterworks
system for the named purposed during the time when the Mayor or the City
Administrator shall by proclamation have prohibited its use.



   (B)   The Mayor or the City Administrator of the city may, whenever
it is in the best interest of the city, shut off the water either permanently
or for a length of time as shall be deemed advisable. When the city water is
shut off no damage shall be asked or claimed by reason thereof by any user or
heirs, assigns, tenants, or legal representatives.



(Prior Code, § 6-6-5)  (Ord. O-17-31, passed 12-12-2017)



§ 52.20  DEFERRED PAYMENT ARRANGEMENT FOR DELINQUENT BILLS.



   Customers may request a deferred payment arrangement for delinquent
bills in accordance with the utility payment policy then in force and effect.



(Prior Code, § 6-6-6)  (Ord. 1936, passed 4-14-2009; Ord. O-17-31, passed
12-12-2017)



§ 52.21  LIABILITY FOR PAYMENT OF SERVICES.



   The owner of the premises, the occupant thereof, and the user of the
service shall each be jointly and severally liable to pay for the service to
the premises, and the service is furnished to the premises by the city only
upon the condition that the owner of the premises, occupant, and user of the
services are jointly and severally liable therefore to the city.



(Prior Code, § 6-6-7)  (Ord. O-17-31, passed 12-12-2017)



§ 52.22  BILLING CYCLE; MAILING OF BILLS.



   Charges for utility services and billing for utility services shall be
as per the utility payment policy then in force and effect.



(Prior Code, § 6-6-9)  (Ord. 1936, passed 4-14-2009; Ord. O-17-31, passed
12-12-2017)



§ 52.23  BILLS DUE; LATE CHARGE; EXCEPTION.



   (A)   A bill will be due and payable as per the utility payment
policy then in force and effect.



   (B)   A penalty charge of 1.5% per month times any unpaid amount
due, excluding taxes, shall be added to the billed amount to all bills not
paid by the due date.



(Prior Code, § 6-6-10)  (Ord. 1936, passed 4-14-2009; Ord. O-17-09, passed
3-14-2017; Ord. O-17-31, passed 12-12-2017)



§ 52.24  TAXES.



   All taxes or charges imposed or levied by any legally empowered taxing
body, and which taxes or charges have been ordered by the City Council, shall
be included on the bill.



(Prior Code, § 6-6-11)  (Ord. O-17-31, passed 12-12-2017)



§ 52.25  BUDGET BILLING.



     Customers may request and enter into budget billing agreements with
the city as per the utility payment policy then in force and effect.



(Prior Code, § 6-6-12)  (Ord. O-17-31, passed 12-12-2017)



§ 52.26  PLACEMENT OF LIEN FOR FAILURE TO PAY BILLS.



   Whenever a bill for public utility service charges remains unpaid after
the due date, the City Administrator shall cause a statement of lien claims
to be filed with the County Recorder of Deeds. The statement of lien claims
shall be filed in accordance with the most current federal and state
regulations relating to lien claims.



(Prior Code, § 6-6-13)  (Ord. 1936, passed 4-14-2009; Ord. O-17-31, passed
12-12-2017)



§ 52.27  AVAILABILITY.



   (A)   This rate is available only to new commercial or industrial
loads which begin receiving service after July 1, 2010, at an existing
facility served, or previously served, by the City of Geneseo which has been
vacant for at least six months.  This rate is available in conjunction with
service under any of the city’s commercial or industrial electric rate
schedules.



   (B)   Any customer desiring to receive service under this rate shall
provide written application to the city of such desire.  Such notice shall
provide the city with information concerning the load to be served and the
customers’  facilities and shall provide the basis of the city
representation that the characteristics of the load will meet the minimum
eligibility requirements of the electric rate schedule to which this rate
applies.



   (C)   All terms and conditions of the electric rate schedule
applicable to the customer shall apply to service supplied to the customer
except as modified by this rate.



(Ord. 1967, passed 4-13-2010)



§ 52.28  MONTHLY CREDIT.



   The customer will receive a monthly credit on the bill calculated on
the then-effective electric rate.  The schedule of monthly credits will be
calculated as described below in § 52.29.



(Ord. 1967, passed 4-13-2010)



§ 52.29  APPLICATION OF CREDIT.



   Beginning with the date on which service under the then-effective
electric rate is to commence for the eligible load, a monthly credit based on
the following schedule will be applied to the total bill, including basic
service and monthly minimum $/meter, demand charges, energy charges excluding
other applicable rates and special charges, if any.



      Period         Discount



      Months 1-12      20%



      Months 13-24      10%



(Ord. 1967, passed 4-13-2010)



§ 52.30  CONTRACT PERIOD.



   Prior to receiving service under this rate, the customer must enter
into an agreement to purchase electricity from the city for a minimum period
of five years.  Either party can terminate the agreement at the end of the
original term upon 60 days prior written notice. The agreement is made a part
hereof and is attached as Exhibit A to the ordinance codified herein.



(Ord. 1967, passed 4-13-2010)



§ 52.31  PARAMETERS FOR UTILITY PAYMENTS AND BILLING.



   The budget billing, payment arrangements, disconnects, ACH policy,
deposits, processing fee, billing cycle/mailing of bills, bills due/late
charge/exception, bad payments and initial service outlined in Exhibit A to
Ordinance O-17-30, are incorporated by reference as if fully set forth herein.



(Ord. O-17-30, passed 12-12-2017)



§ 52.32  ELECTRONIC METERS REQUIRED.



   Any customer who refuses to permit the city to install a meter of the
type selected by the city as part of the city’s billing system for either
electric or water service, and thereby causes the city to use methods
different from those of its selected system to read such a meter to determine
consumption amounts, whether for electric or water service, shall be charged
an additional $20 per reading.  Should the existing meter fail to accurately
meter consumption then, upon two days notice delivered to the address at
which the failing or faulty meter is located, should the customer continue to
refuse to permit the city to install a meter of the type selected by the city
such customer shall be subject to disconnection from that utility service
until the new meter of the type selected by the city is installed.



(Ord. O-18-05, passed 6-12-2018)
