GENERAL PROVISIONS




§ 53.01  METER REQUIRED FOR USE OF CITY WATER.



   (A)   All water obtained in any way from the city waterworks system,
except when drawn from fire hydrants by officers of the City Fire Protection
District or employees of the city, shall pass through a water meter between
the water mains of the city and the outlet of the service pipe through which
water is obtained for use.



   (B)   The Water and Sewer Superintendent may permit the obtainment
of city water without passing through a meter for the following
circumstances, provided the conditions set forth are met:



      (1)   The filling of any movable water tank from the
waterworks system, provided that the rate established is paid before the
filling of the tank; and



      (2)   The use of city water for training sessions of the City
Fire Protection District, provided the Fire Chief, or a ranking
representative, shall notify the Water and Sewer Superintendent of the time
and place of the planned training exercise and obtain written authorization
from the Water and Sewer Superintendent.



(Prior Code, § 6-2-3)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 53.02  METER SERVICE FEE.



   (A)   A service charge for the cost of the meter and for the cost of
installing a water meter shall be paid for initial installations.



   (B)   There shall be placed in all service pipes immediately within
the wall of the building supplied, a brass stop and waste cock before the
meter; also, a brass shut-off valve on discharge side of the meter. The meter
is to be set in a horizontal position, and shall be placed in a place easily
accessible, and at least eight inches from the outside wall of the building,
and where the water in the same will not freeze. All pipe shall be free from
all accumulation of all kinds before the same are attached to meter and the
meter shall be sealed. No meter, or the seal thereon, shall be removed
without permission from the Water Department. No by-pass or T shall be
installed in the service pipes between the shut-off box and the meter.



   (C)   All damage done to meters that have been installed which is
caused by negligence or misconduct of any person other than city employees
shall be paid by the owners of the premises.



   (D)   Whenever the use of water is discontinued, the city shall have
the right to remove the meter. If the owner of the premises desires again to
use water, the owner shall have a meter installed in the manner of an initial
installation. If a user is requesting to have the water service shut off
after seasonal occupancy, the city will shut the service off and may remove
the meter. Upon re-occupancy, at the user’s request, the city will turn the
water service back on and install a meter if one was removed. This seasonal
service is offered free of charge as an attempt by the Water Department to
decrease the number of weather related water breaks.



   (E)   Whenever a user states that a water meter is not registering
properly, the following shall apply: 



      (1)   The Water and Sewer Superintendent  will make one
complimentary test and inspection of the meter within a three-year period;



      (2)   The user will be charged $40 for any test in excess of
the one complimentary test, should the meter be found to be accurate within
2%. Any additional test may be requested, and a fee of actual cost shall be
charged as applicable.



   (F)   If a meter fails to register correctly, then when the Water
and Sewer Superintendent can determine the amount of the inaccuracy, the
Water and Sewer Superintendent shall adjust the user’s current bill. When
the amount of inaccuracy can not be determined, then the bill shall be
determined by using the previous year’s consumption for the month in
question times the rates for water currently in effect.



(Prior Code, § 6-2-5)



§ 53.03  TAPPING FEE; PREREQUISITES AND REQUIREMENTS.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful to dig up or into city streets, alleys,
or property of the city for the purpose of tapping any of the water mains
without first obtaining a permit. It shall be unlawful for any person, either
with or without a permit, to do so except upon the terms and conditions
contained in this section.



   (B)   The Water Department may, in the performance of their duties,
tap into water mains without a permit.



   (C)   A permit fee of $100 shall be collected for each water system
connection. For any connection which serves a building with more than one
living unit, except condominium complex, a permit fee of $100 for the first
unit plus a fee of $50 per additional unit and for any additional unit added
within an 18-month period from issuance of a permit, shall be collected.
However, a $100 fee for any unit added after the 18-month period shall be
collected. Each unit of a condominium complex is a separate building and
requires a permit for each. The City Treasurer shall deposit all fees
collected into the Water operating account. Permits for water system
connection shall be issued by the Plumbing Inspector.



   (D)   A permit shall not be granted to tap, or cause to be tapped,
any water main of the city for the acquisition of water from the waterworks
system of the city to anyone who is not the actual and bona fide owner of the
property.



   (E)   A licensed plumber shall perform the work of tapping or
connecting with any water mains of the city. The licensed plumber may have
helpers assist them in the work.



   (F)   Licensed plumbers pay to the city the cost of repairs of all
damages to the city’s water mains, hydrants, fixtures, equipment, or to any
part of the city’s waterworks system, and any other expenses the city may
incur whenever the damages are the result of the improper or unskillful
workmanship or doing of any work performed. The city may avail itself to the
plumber’s bond, but shall not be limited in its recovery against the
plumber or property owner by the amount of the bond.



   (G)   All trenches, unions, joints, fixtures, and attachments in any
way connected with the waterworks system of the city shall be inspected by
the Water and Sewer Superintendent. However, the Water and Sewer
Superintendent  may designate the Plumbing Inspector to make inspections.
Inspections shall be made before the work is covered, hidden from view, or
used for obtaining water from the waterworks system. If the workmanship is
determined to be defective, the defect shall be corrected.



   (H)   Saddles shall be supported by four inch cement block or
equivalent under the direct supervision of the Water and Sewer Superintendent
or the Plumbing Inspector.



   (I)   No white or red lead shall be used on any joint. Service taps
shall be made at a 45-degree angle between horizontal and vertical.



   (J)   City water mains must be tapped in the body, and in no case
nearer than 18 inches to the joints of the mains, and no two taps shall be
placed in any one water main closer than 18 inches of each other.



   (K)   All service pipes shall be laid not less than five feet below
the established surface grade at all points of all streets, alleys, or public
property of the city where a surface grade is now or shall be hereafter
established, and at least five feet below the surface of the ground at all
points.



   (L)   No pipe shall be used except type K copper pipe for two inch
or smaller from the water main to the shut off, and for greater than two
inch, PVC may be used from the water main to the shut off.



   (M)   All work performed shall be done in the best and most approved
manner known for doing such work and shall be in compliance with city code
ordinance. Materials, fixtures, and appliances used in so doing shall be the
best quality for the purpose for which the same are used.



   (N)   When the owner of any real property which does not abut upon a
street in which there is laid a water main of the city wants to connect the
property with the water main, the owner shall apply to the Water and Sewer
Superintendent  for the connection. All mains shall be cement lined ductile
or C900 PVC or equivalent AWWA specification. Underground copper shall be
connected with flare or compression type fittings and all mains shall be laid
with at least five feet of cover.



   (O)   Water service lines for condominium complexes shall have
separate water service lines of at least one inch for each condominium.



   (P)   Water service lines for duplexes and apartment buildings may
have a common water service line; however, the type of building must have at
least the water service line size indicated as follows:



 


Building Type

 

Water Service Line Size



Duplex/two-unit apartment
 

1 inch service line



Tri-plex/three-unit apartment
 

1.5 inch service line



Four-plex/four-unit apartment
 

1.5 inch service line



More than four
 

2 inch service line




 



   (Q)   The common service line must be located in such a manner as to
facilitate a meter manifold and to provide easy access for the city to read
and service meters.



(Prior Code, § 6-2-6)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 53.04  CROSS-CONNECTION CONTROL.



   (A)   If, in accordance with the State Plumbing Code, or in the
judgment of the Water and Sewer Superintendent, an approved backflow
prevention device is necessary for the safety of the public water supply
system, the Water and Sewer Superintendent will give notice to the water user
to install an approved device immediately.



   (B)   The water user shall, at the owner’s expense, install an
approved device at a location and in a manner in accordance with the State
Plumbing Code, State Environmental Protection Agency, and all applicable
local regulations, and shall have inspections and tests made of approved
devices as required by the State Plumbing Code and local regulations.



   (C)   No person, firm, or corporation shall establish, or permit to
be established, or maintain, or permit to be maintained, any connection
whereby a private, auxiliary, or emergency water supply other than the
city’s water supply enter the supply or distribution system, unless the
private, auxiliary, or emergency water supply and the method of connection
and use of the supply shall have been approved by the Water and Sewer
Superintendent and the State Environmental Protection Agency.



   (D)   It shall be the duty of the Chief Water Operator to cause
surveys and investigations to be made of industrial and other properties
served by the public water supply to determine whether actual or potential
hazards to the public water supply may exist. Such surveys and investigations
shall be made a matter of public record and shall be repeated at least every
two years, or as often as the Public Works Director shall deem necessary.
Records of such surveys shall be maintained and available for review for a
period of at least five years.



   (E)   The approved cross-connection control device inspector shall
have the right to enter at any reasonable time any property served by a
connection to the public water supply or distribution system of the City of
Geneseo for the purpose of verifying the presence or absence of
cross-connections, and  the Chief Water Operator or his or her authorized
agent shall have the right to enter at any reasonable time any property
served by a connection to the public water supply or distribution system of
the City of Geneseo for the purpose of verifying information submitted by the
owner, lessees or occupants of any property so served. The owner, lessees or
occupants of any property so served shall furnish to the Chief Water Operator
any information which he or she may request regarding the piping system or
systems or water use on such property. The refusal of such information, when
demanded, shall, within the discretion of the Chief Water Operator, be deemed
evidence of the presence of improper connections as provided in this section.



   (F)   The Chief Water Operator of the City of Geneseo is hereby
authorized and directed to discontinue, after reasonable notice to the
occupant thereof, the water service to any property wherein any connection in
violation of the provisions of this section is known to exist, and to take
such other precautionary measures as he or she may deem necessary to
eliminate any danger of contamination of the public water supply distribution
mains. Water service to such property shall not be restored until such
conditions have been eliminated or corrected in compliance with the
provisions of this section, and until a reconnection fee of $50 is paid to
the City of Geneseo. Immediate disconnection with verbal notice can be
effected when the Chief Water Operator is assured that there is imminent
danger of harmful contamination or pollution of the public water supply,
provided that, in the reasonable opinion of the Chief Water Operator or the
Illinois Environmental Protection Agency, such action is required to prevent
actual or potential contamination or pollution of the public water supply.
Neither the public water supply, the Chief Water Operator, or its agents or
assigns shall be liable to any customer for any injury, damages nor lost
revenue which may result from termination of the customer’s water supply in
accordance with terms of this section, whether or not said termination was
with or without notice.



   (G)   The consumer responsible for back siphoned material or
contamination through backflow, if contamination of the potable water supply
system occurs through an illegal cross-connection or an improperly installed,
maintained or repaired device , or a device which has been bypassed, must
bear the cost of cleanup of the potable water supply system.



(Prior Code, § 6-2-7)  (Ord. O-14-112, passed 10-14-2014) Penalty, see §
10.99



§ 53.05  OWNER AND USER LIABILITY.



   (A)   The owner of property, the occupant thereof, and the user of
the service shall be jointly and severally liable to pay for the service to
the property. The service is furnished to the property by the city only upon
the condition that the owner of the property, occupant, and user of the
service are jointly and severally liable therefore to the city. Property
owners shall be responsible for maintaining and repairing water service
lines, from and including, the shut-off box to the meter.  No refunds shall
be made to customers in the event of problems, including break of the water
lines.  This shall include no refunds on the sewer portion of the utility
bill, even if the water did not go through the sanitary sewer system.



   (B)   The city shall own and maintain all water meters located on
the property. Upon the initial installation of the meter, the owner of the
property shall pay to the city an installation/service charge to be
established by the city. Only duly authorized representatives of the Water
and Sewer Department are permitted to remove meters from property.



   (C)   The owner or developer of any site shall be responsible for
the installation and maintenance of any necessary booster equipment needed to
maintain the needed pressures in the improvements located on the sites.



   (D)   The city is not responsible for insufficient water pressure.
Applications to use water from the water mains of the city shall be made with
the express understanding that the city is not responsible for providing
adequate water pressure to sites where natural conditions or the type of
improvements located on the sites creates a situation where the water
pressure is not sufficient for the needs of existing or proposed improvements.



   (E)   Any user of the city’s water system is responsible for
backsiphoned material or contamination through backflow, if contamination of
the potable water supply system occurs through an illegal cross-connection or
an improperly installed, maintained, or repaired device, or a device which
has been bypassed, and must bear the cost of clean up of the potable water
supply system.



(Prior Code, § 6-2-1)  (Ord. O-12-050, passed 7-10-2012)



§ 53.06  CITY PERMITTED TO SUPPLY OUTSIDE OF CITY LIMITS.



   (A)   Any property located outside the city limits which is
currently connected to and serviced by the city’s waterworks system shall
be allowed to continue to be so serviced, subject to the rate provisions of
Appendix A of this chapter, and subject to all other applicable city
ordinances and regulations.



   (B)   Any property contiguous to but located outside the corporate
limits of the city, which is not currently connected to and serviced by the
city’s waterworks system, shall not be allowed to receive water unless and
until the property is annexed into the city. Notwithstanding this
prohibition, the city may supply water to any property located outside the
corporate limits, and not contiguous therewith, provided that all of the
following conditions apply:



      (1)   There are water service mains currently adjacent to the
property or within the proximity that in the discretion of the Water and
Sewer Superintendent of the city, it is reasonable to connect water service
lines to the property;



      (2)   The owner requesting connection to the city’s
waterworks system obtains a permit and pays for the cost of the extension and
connection and any permit fees required by the city; and



      (3)   The owners of the property enter into an agreement to
annex to the city at the time the property does become contiguous to the
city, which agreement shall run with the land.



(Prior Code, § 6-2-2)



§ 53.07  LEAKAGE.



   (A)   Whenever a leak occurs between the shut-off box and the meter,
the leak shall be immediately reported by the property owner to the Water and
Sewer Department.



   (B)   Property owners shall be responsible for maintaining and
repairing of water service lines from, and including, shut-off box to meter.



(Prior Code, § 6-2-4)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 53.08  SPECIAL REQUIREMENT CIRCUMSTANCES.



   (A)   Any subdivision which shall use the facilities of the city for
its water supply, and, which by reason of its elevation or other natural
conditions of the site of the subdivision, does not have adequate water
pressure for the uses the property is zoned, then the plat of any subdivision
shall have affixed to it a notice stating that any improvements located in
the subdivision may require equipment to boost the water pressure for use in
the improvements. Furthermore, the notice shall state that the responsibility
and expense for the booster equipment shall be the responsibility of the
recorded owner of the property and shall not be the responsibility of the
city.



   (B)   If a meter is used in connection with a steam boiler, or under
any conditions where it is exposed to a back pressure, the same must be
protected by a dual check valve placed between the outlet of the meter and
the back pressure.



   (C)   In all cases where service pipes are abandoned, it shall be
the responsibility of the property owner to shut off and disconnect, or have
shut off and disconnected, the water at the shut-off box between the water
mains and the premises. The disconnected service is then required to be
inspected by the Water and Sewer Superintendent.



   (D)   No cross-connection with any cistern, well, or other supply
shall be allowed in the city water system.



(Prior Code, § 6-2-8)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 53.09  PUBLIC SAFETY.



   (A)   It shall be the duty of the Water and Sewer Superintendent to
have surveys and investigations made of commercial, industrial, and other
properties served by the public water supply to determine whether actual or
potential hazards to the public water supply may exist. The surveys and
investigations shall be made a matter of public record and shall be repeated
at least every two years, or as often as the Water and Sewer Superintendent
shall deem necessary. Records of the surveys shall be maintained and
available for review for a period of at least five years.



   (B)   The cross-connection control device inspector shall, in the
course of his or her duties and inspections, make all reasonable efforts to
obtain the consent of the owner or occupant of the premises for the
inspection. If the consent cannot be obtained and the cross-connection
control device inspector has probable cause for the necessity of the
inspection, he or she shall contact the City Attorney for the purpose of
obtaining a search warrant.



(Prior Code, § 6-2-9)



§ 53.10  WATER DISTRIBUTION SYSTEM CONSTRUCTION.



   (A)   All regulations of the state statutes, State Environmental
Protection Agency, and United States Environmental Protection Agency, shall
be complied with in regard to water main construction.



   (B)   Designed to provide a minimum water pressure of 35 pounds per
square inch in the top floor of every structure or building to be constructed.



   (C)   Construction will not commence until grade is within four
inches of final grade.



   (D)   Water mains of ductile iron pipe cement lined, or of PVC SDR
18 (C900) or (C909) and non-conductive material must have a properly
installed tracer wire.



   (E)   Diameter of water mains shall not be less than six inches.



   (F)   All water mains shall be looped.



   (G)   Service lines of one-inch minimum type K copper.



   (H)   Service line extends from the water main to the lot line of
each lot.



   (I)   Service lines of each lot are clearly marked after completion
of the improvements.



   (J)   Drawings and plans for the proposed distribution system must
be approved by the Water and Sewer Superintendent prior to construction.



   (K)   All parts, components, and accessories such as pipe, valve
boxes, bolts, glands, saddles, curb boxes and the like, must be American made
and approved by the Water and Sewer Superintendent prior to construction.



(Prior Code, § 4-1-8)  (Ord. 1929, passed 1-13-2009; Ord. O-15-138, passed
8-11-2015)



§ 53.11  FIRE PROTECTION SYSTEM CONSTRUCTION.



   (A)   Designed to provide minimum flow of 600 gallons/minute at each
hydrant.



   (B)   Fire hydrants to include auxiliary valves and valve boxes.



   (C)   Installed at intervals not to exceed 400 feet.



   (D)   Located not less than four feet from the edge of the
street’s or alley’s pavement.



   (E)   All hydrants shall be American made (Mueller or city approved
hydrant) of the steamer type and approved by the Water and Sewer
Superintendent prior to construction.



(Prior Code, § 4-1-9)  (Ord. O-15-138, passed 8-11-2015)



§ 53.12  BILLING RATES.



   The water and sewer rates for the city shall be set and established by
resolution adopted by the corporate authorities of the city from time to time.



(Ord. O-16-175, passed 9-27-2016)




COMMUNITY WELL PROTECTION




§ 53.20  PURPOSE.



   Pursuant to the authority conferred by ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, § 11-125-4,
ILCS Ch. 415, Act 5, §§ 14.2 and 14.3, and ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, § 7-4-2,
Municipal Property Outside Corporate Limits, and in the interest of securing
the public health, safety, and welfare, to preserve the quality and quantity
of groundwater and resources in order to assure a safe and adequate water
supply for present and future generations, and to preserve groundwater
resources currently in use and those aquifers having a potential for future
use as a public water supply, the provisions of this subchapter shall apply
to all properties located within the minimum setback zone established under
§ 14.2 of the Environmental Protection Act (ILCS Ch. 415, Act 5, § 14.3)
and this subchapter, and the maximum setback zone established under § 14.3
of the Act (ILCS  Ch. 415, Act 5, § 14.3) and this subchapter.



(Prior Code, § 6-2-10)



§ 53.21  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
Except as defined below, the definition of words or terms in this subchapter
shall be the same as those used in the Act and the State Ground Water
Protection Act (ILCS Ch. 415, Act 55, §§ 1 et seq.).



   ACT.  The Environmental Protection Act (ILCS Ch. 415, Act 5, §§ 1 et
seq.).



   AGENCY.  The State Environmental Protection Agency.



   BOARD.  The State Pollution Control Board.



   MAXIMUM SETBACK ZONE.  The area around a community water supply well
established under § 14.3 of the Act and this subchapter, and described in
Appendix B of Ordinance No. 1534.



   MINIMUM SETBACK ZONE.  The area around a community water supply well
established under § 14.2 of the Act and this subchapter, and described in
Appendix B of Ordinance No. 1534.



(Prior Code, § 6-2-10)



§ 53.22  PROHIBITED CONDUCT.



   Except as provided in §§ 53.23 and 53.24 of this subchapter, no
person shall place a new potential primary source, new potential secondary
source, or new potential route within the minimum setback zone.



(Prior Code, § 6-2-10)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 53.23  WAIVERS, EXCEPTIONS AND MINIMAL HAZARD CERTIFICATES.



   (A)   If, pursuant to § 14.2(b) of the Act, the owner of a new
potential primary source, new potential secondary source, or new potential
route is granted a waiver by the Agency, the owner shall be deemed to have a
waiver to the same extent from Section C, paragraph 1.



   (B)   If, pursuant to § 14.2(c) of the Act, the owner of a new
potential primary source (other than landfilling or land treating), new
potential secondary source, or new potential route is granted an exception by
the Board, the owner shall be deemed to have an exception to the same extent
from Section C, paragraph 1.



   (C)   If, pursuant to § 14.2(c) of the Act, the owner of a new
potential primary source (other than landfilling or land treating) is granted
an exception by the Board, the owner shall be deemed to have an exception to
the same extent from Section C, paragraph 2.



   (D)   If, pursuant to § 14.5 of the Act, the owner of a new
potential primary source, new potential secondary source, or new potential
route is issued a certificate of minimal hazard by the Agency, the owner
shall not be subject to Section C, paragraph 1 to the same extent that the
owner is not subject to § 14.2(d) of the Act.



(Prior Code, § 6-2-10)



§ 53.24  EXCLUSION.



   Section C, paragraph 1, shall not apply to new common sources of
sanitary pollution as specified pursuant to § 17 of the Act and the
regulations adopted thereunder by the Agency; however, no such common sources
may be located within the applicable minimum distance from a community water
supply well specified by the regulations.



(Prior Code, § 6-2-10)  Penalty, see § 10.99




GROUNDWATER




§ 53.35  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   PERSON.  Any individual, partnership, co-partnership, firm, company,
limited liability company, corporation, association, joint stock company,
trust, estate, political subdivision, or any other legal entity, or their
legal representatives, agents, or assigns.



   POTABLE WATER.  Any water used for human or domestic consumption,
including, but not limited to, water used for drinking, bathing, swimming,
washing dishes, or preparing foods.



(Prior Code, § 6-2-11)



§ 53.36  USE OF GROUNDWATER AS POTABLE WATER SUPPLY.



   The use, or attempt to use, as a potable water supply, groundwater from
within the corporate limits of the city by the use, installation or drilling
of wells, or by any other method, is hereby prohibited at any property that
is within 500 feet of the city’s water supply system provided that the
water supply system may be extended to said property within public
right-of-way, city property, or easements or other property to which either
the city or the relevant property owner has the property rights necessary to
extend and install the system improvement. Every private well producing
potable water as of November 1, 2017 for properties that are within 500 feet
of the city’s water supply, and every new private well installed after
November 1, 2017, shall be considered legal until such time as said well or
wells shall no longer be potable or shall no longer produce sufficient
quantities of potable water.  At such time as said private well shall no
longer be potable or shall not produce sufficient quantities of potable
water, said well shall be capped and, provided the city water supply system
is within 500 feet of the property and either the city or the property owner
has the property rights necessary to extend and install the water supply
system to said property, said property owner shall connect said property to
the city’s water supply system. The cost to extend the city’s water
supply system to the relevant property shall be the exclusive responsibility
of the property owner; provided, however, that the city may consider
financing agreements and recapture agreements. This prohibition shall not
apply to the city, which may install or drill a public well as part of its
waterworks system pursuant to the state statutes.



(Prior Code, § 6-2-11)  (Am. Ord. O-17-32, passed 11-14-2017)  Penalty,
see § 10.99

to 100% of the amount.

passed 7-10-2012; Ord. O-16-175, passed 9-27-2016)



CHAPTER 54:  ELECTRICITY



Section



   54.01   Definitions



   Appendix A:  Residential rate schedule



   Appendix B:  Commercial rate schedule



   Appendix C:  Non-profit rate schedule



   Appendix D:  Non-residential rate schedule



   Appendix E:  Large service rate schedule



   Appendix F:  Unmetered street lighting



   Appendix G:  Unmetered lighting



   Appendix H:  Municipal service rate schedule



§ 54.01  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   BILLING DEMAND.  The monthly billing demand for the large commercial
service rate is the maximum 15-minute integrated kW demand for the billing
month, but not less than 75% of the previous maximum billing demand in the
previous 12 months. 



   COMMERCIAL SERVICE. The commercial service rate applies to
non-residential customers with loads of 50 kW or less for all separately
metered general service usage in one establishment, through one meter, at one
point of delivery.  This rate is not available for consumers using more than
20,000 kWh in any month or with firm loads greater than 50 kW.



   DEPOSITS, PAYMENTS AND MISCELLANEOUS ADMINISTRATIVE AND SERVICE FEES. 
City service rules shall establish deposits, payment terms and miscellaneous
administrative and service fees.



   DISCONNECTION AND RECONNECTION.  Accounts remaining delinquent are
subject to disconnection and a reconnection charge in accordance with city
service rules.



   LARGE COMMERCIAL SERVICE.  The large commercial service rate applies
to non-residential customers for all separately metered usage with a minimum
50 kW of load in one establishment, through one meter, at one point of
delivery.  Interval recording meters are required and customer will
reimburse the city for its installed cost of metering, plus monthly telemetry
costs, if any.  This rate is also applicable for consumers using more than
20,000 kWh in any month regardless of kW demand.



   LARGE NON-PROFIT SERVICE.  The large non-profit service rate applies
to all licensed non-profit entities for all separately metered usage with a
minimum 50 kW of load in one establishment, through one meter, at one point
of delivery.  Interval recording meters are required and customer will
reimburse the city for its installed cost of metering, plus monthly telemetry
costs, if any.  This rate is also applicable for non-profit consumers using
more than 20,000 kWh in any month regardless of kW demand.



   LARGE SERVICE ELECTRIC HEAT.  The large service electric heat rate
applies to large commercial service or large non-profit service customers
with all water and space heating provided by electrical means.



   MASTER METERING.  No master metering, sub-metering, joint use (for
other than multiple dwelling units) or resale of electric service is
permitted hereunder.



   MULTIPLE DWELLING UNITS.  When two or more flats, apartments, or
dwelling units are served by one meter in accordance with city service rules,
the basic service charge shall be billed at the multiple of individual units
served and kWh shall be billed on a pro-rata basis in each price step.  That
is, total kWh usage divided by the number of dwelling units, calculate the
kWh charges in each rate step and then multiply total kWh charges by the
number of dwelling units. 



   MUNICIPAL.  City and interdepartmental usage will be billed under the
price schedule for general service, large general service or street lights,
as applicable.



   NON-PROFIT SERVICE.  The non-profit service rate applies to all
licensed non-profit entities with loads of 50 kW or less for all separately
metered general service usage in one establishment, through one meter, at one
point of delivery.  This rate is not available for consumers using more than
20,000 kWh in any month or with firm loads greater than 50 kW.



   NON-RESIDENTIAL ELECTRIC HEAT SERVICE.  The non-residential electric
heat service rate applies to commercial service or non-profit service
customers with all water and space heating provided by electrical means.



   POWER FACTOR. For purposes of billing, the monthly billing demand shall
be increased by 1% for each 1% customer's power factor is measured during any
15-minute interval to be less than 95%.  Payment of the power factor penalty
shall not relieve customer of the obligation to self-correct the power factor
to 95% or greater.  The city may install power factor correction capacitors
on its primary distribution system to compensate for customer's lagging power
factor and customer shall reimburse the city for the installed cost thereof,
including all necessary labor, materials, mountings, controls and
appurtenances.



   RATES.  Every person, firm, corporation, industry or farm that is
furnished electricity by the City Municipal Electric Utility shall be charged
under the approved applicable rate schedule for each separate class of
service.



   RESIDENTIAL SERVICE.  The residential rate applies to a single-family
residence, or a multiple dwelling unit, for all domestic uses, including
water heating and space heating.  If all water heating and space heating are
done by electrical means then the home will qualify for the residential
electric heat service rate.  Where a portion of a residential dwelling is
used for commercial purposes and is not separately metered, the applicable
residential rate shall apply to all metered usage. Commercial usage at a
residence shall require a separate meter with service under the commercial
service rate when the commercial load is over 5 kW and less than 50 kW and
with service under the large commercial rate when the commercial load is over
50 kW. 



   SUMMER MONTHS.  For purposes of billing, summer months are June
through September.



   TAX ADJUSTMENT.  Sales under all rate schedules are subject to a Tax
Adjustment Factor (TAF).  Charges for all metered and un-metered services
will be adjusted by the amount of applicable sales and local option taxes and
any new or increased tax imposed and levied on gross receipts, the
production, transmission, distribution or sale of electricity by the city.



   WINTER MONTHS.  For purposes of billing, winter months are October
through May.



(Prior Code, § 6-1-1)  (Ord. 1936, passed 4-14-2009; Am. Ord. O-12-060,
passed 9-11-2012)

CHAPTER 55:  INTERCONNECTION AND NET METERING PROGRAMS



Section



   55.01   Definitions



   55.02   Interconnection requirements



   55.03   Net metering requirements and policy



   55.04   System use and regulations



   55.05   Required safety features



   55.06   Small wind energy conversion systems (SWES)



   55.07   Disconnection, termination, modification and assignment



   55.08   Terms and conditions



 



   55.99   Penalty



§ 55.01  DEFINITIONS.



   For purposes of this chapter the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   ANNUAL PERIOD.  The period of 12 consecutive monthly billing periods
ending on the last day of either the net metering customer's April monthly
billing period or its October monthly billing period, whichever was selected
by the customer in connection with its application for net metering.



   CUSTOMER. A retail customer (residential, commercial, or industrial)
that owns or operates an eligible solar or wind renewable electrical
generating facility with a rated capacity of not more than 2,000 kilowatts
that is located on the customer's premises and is intended primarily to
offset the customer's own electrical requirements.



   ELECTRICITY SUPPLIER. The alternative retail electric supplier that is
providing electric supply services; or the electric utility that is providing
electric supply services, either within or outside its service area.



   ELIGIBLE RENEWABLE ELECTRICAL GENERATING FACILITY. A generator up to
2,000 kilowatts powered by solar electric energy, wind, dedicated crops grown
for electricity generation, anaerobic digestion of livestock or food
processing waste, fuel cells or microturbines powered by renewable fuels, or
hydroelectric energy.



   INTERCONNECTION SERVICES. On-site generating facilities connected to
the city electric distribution system in a manner that will allow excess
electricity generated by the eligible renewable electrical generating
facility to be safely delivered onto the city's electric distribution system.



   NET ELECTRICITY METERING (or NET METERING). The measurement, during the
billing period applicable to an eligible customer, of the net amount of
electricity supplied by an electricity provider to the customer's premises or
provided to the electricity provider by the customer or subscriber.



   NET PURCHASER OF ELECTRICITY. The total amount of generation produced
by the customer is less than the customer's total usage during the applicable
billing period.



   NET SELLER OF ELECTRICITY. The total amount of generation produced by
the customer is greater than the customer's total usage during the applicable
billing period.



   SMALL WIND ENERGY SYSTEM (SWES).  A wind energy conservation system
consisting of wind turbine, a tower, and associated control or conversion
electronics, which has a rated capacity of not more than 10 kW or less for
residential electric customers, or 20 kW or less for commercial or industrial
electric customers, and which is intended to primarily reduce on-site
consumption of utility power.



   UTILITY. An electric utility owned and operated by the Geneseo
Municipal Utility.



(Ord. O-18-03, passed 4-10-2018)



§ 55.02  INTERCONNECTION REQUIREMENTS.



   The utility shall make available, upon request, net metering services
to any customer taking services from the utility and who meets the
requirements set forth in this policy. Requirements for interconnection to
Geneseo Municipal Utilities shall be as follows:



   (A)   Application. Customer shall submit all net metering
application materials to the city. Upon receipt of a completed and executed
application, the utility shall, within ten business days after receipt of an
application, notify the applicant as to whether it is authorized to
participate as a net metering customer. If utility issues a denial, it shall
provide the reasons for denying the prospective net metering customer's
application based on noncompliance with this chapter.



   (B)   Final interconnection and operation. The customer may operate
the eligible renewable electrical generating facility and interconnect with
the utility's electric distribution system after all of the following have
occurred:



      (1)   Electrical inspection.  The customer shall obtain an
electrical permit and pass an electrical inspection before customer's
generating system will be connected or operated in parallel with the utility
and shall obtain all governmental authorizations and permits required for the
construction and operation of the system and interconnection facilities.



      (2)   Certificate of completion.  The customer shall provide
the utility with a copy of the certificate of completion with all relevant
and necessary information fully completed by the customer, as well as an
inspection form from the local electrical inspection authority demonstrating
that the distributed generation facility passed inspection.



      (3)   The utility, at its discretion, has completed its
witness test as per the following: Within ten business days of the
commissioning date, the utility must, upon reasonable notice and at a
mutually convenient time, conduct a witness test of the distributed
generation facility to ensure that all equipment has been appropriately
installed and that all electrical connections and metering have been made in
accordance with the applicable codes.



   (C)   Compliance. The eligible renewable electrical generating
facility shall be installed, operated and tested in accordance with the
requirements of UL 1741 and The Institute of Electrical and Electronics
Engineers, Inc. (IEEE), 3 Park Avenue New York, NY  10016-5997, Standard
1547 (2003) "Standard for Interconnecting Distributed Resources with Electric
Power Systems."  Photovoltaic installations must comply with Article 690,
Solar Photovoltaic Systems, of the National Electric Code.  All
interconnection related protective functions and associated batteries shall
be periodically tested at intervals specified by the manufacturer system
integrator, or the authority that has jurisdiction over the distributed
resources interconnection, or all tests shall be performed at a minimum of
every three years.  Periodic test reports shall be maintained and submitted
to the city's Electric Department.



   (D)   Access.  The utility shall have direct, unabated access to
the disconnect switch and metering equipment of the eligible renewable
electrical generating facility at all times. At the utility's discretion, it
may enter the customer's premises or property if a hazardous condition exists
and such immediate action is necessary to protect persons, the utility's
facilities, or property of others, from damage or interference cause by the
customer's generating facilities, or lack of properly operating protective
devices or inability to inspect the same.  The disconnect switch shall be
clearly labeled and installed within two feet of the meter.  The utility
shall provide five business days notice to the customer prior to using its
right of access except in emergencies.



   (E)   Metering.  Any required metering shall be installed at
customer expense. Any expenses incurred due to modification to the existing
utility system necessitated by the introduction of customer's renewable
electrical generating facility into the system shall be paid by the
customer.  The utility shall determine whether the customer is a net
purchaser of electricity, or a net seller of electricity during the billing
period.



   (F)   Interconnection.



      (1)   The customer shall comply with the net metering
application set forth as Exhibit B, attached to Ordinance O-18-03 and
incorporated by reference as if fully set forth herein.  Customer shall also
pay for designing, installing, inspecting, operating, and maintaining the
renewable electrical generating facility in accordance with all applicable
laws and regulations.



      (2)   Once in operation, the customer shall make no changes or
modifications in the equipment, wiring, or the mode of operation, without
prior written approval of the utility.



(Ord. O-18-03, passed 4-10-2018)



§ 55.03  NET METERING REQUIREMENTS AND POLICY.



   (A)   Subject to the limitations set forth herein, utility shall
make net metering service available upon request to any residential electric
customer with an eligible renewable electrical generating facility of 10 kW
capacity or less. For commercial and industrial accounts, the limit will be
20 kW or less.



   (B)   Any generating facility greater than the limits in division
(A) above, but less than 1 MW shall be considered on a case by case basis. 
The decision with respect to such facilities shall be made by the utility.



   (C)   Notwithstanding the provisions in division (B) above, utility
reserves the authority to limit the size of a customer's renewable electrical
generating facility to a size such that the electrical output will not, as a
matter of routine operation, exceed the electric load of the structure on
which it is installed.



   (D)   Total net metered capacity for all customers interconnected
under this policy for the utility system shall not exceed 2% of the system's
peak as it existed in the prior calendar year. In the event that the system
peak is reduced such that the existing net capacity for all interconnected
customers exceeds the 2% level, those existing net metered customers shall be
allowed to continue under this policy. However, no new interconnections will
be allowed until such time as the system peak grows such that net metered
capacity for all interconnected customers is again no greater than 2% of the
system's peak.



   (E)   Energy generated by the customer-owned renewable electrical
generating facility will offset the energy required by the customer's load
during the billing period. For any energy generated by the customer in excess
of the energy required by the customer's loads for a given billing period a
credit shall be carried forward to the customer's next billing period. In no
case shall credits for excess energy be carried forward for a period greater
than 12 consecutive monthly billing periods ending on the last day of the
customer's monthly billing period. In the event of termination of an account
qualifying for net metering under this policy, any outstanding credits are
surrendered. Under no circumstances will customer credits have any cash value
for any other reason and customer credits may not be assigned, transferred,
hypothecated or encumbered by or to any third party.



   (F)   Any costs utility incurs associated with the net metering
program, including but not limited to changes in metering (to include
installation of a bi-directional meter), other physical facilities or
billing-related costs, shall be borne by the customers in the net metering
program. Any expenses incurred due to the modification to the existing
utility system necessitated by the introduction of customer's renewable
electrical generating facility into the system shall by paid by the customer.



   (G)   In addition to the cost referenced in division (F) above,
utility will charge a distribution system utilization fee which is approved
annually by the City Council via resolution to ensure all customers pay a
share of the costs of maintenance and improvements to the distribution
system. This fee is exclusive to customers who receive net metering services
under this policy and represents the non-by passable costs associated with
maintaining the distribution system that backs up net metered generation.



(Ord. O-18-03, passed 4-10-2018)



§ 55.04  SYSTEM USE AND REGULATIONS.



   Customer may participate in the net metering program pursuant to the
following regulations.



   (A)   Setback.  Customer's pole-mounted net metering facilities
shall be setback from all property lines, above-ground utility lines, and
roadways, a distance no less than 110% of the tower height.  Any application
that is a part of customer's net metering facilities including guy wires
shall be setback from all property lines no less than 30 feet. All other
renewable electrical generating facilities must comply with the applicable
setbacks for the district in which it is located.



   (B)   Yard restriction.  Customer's net metering facilities shall
not be permitted in any front yard.



   (C)   Color.  Customer's net metering facilities shall be painted a
non-reflective, non-obtrusive color or a color that conforms to the
environment and architecture of its surroundings.



   (D)   Illumination.  Customer's net metering facilities shall not
be lighted, except as required by the FAA.



   (E)   Noise level.  Audible sound from a customer's net metering
facilities shall not exceed 25 dBA in residential districts or 50 dBA in all
other districts, as measured at the exterior of any occupied building on an
adjacent or neighboring property. Methods for measuring and reporting
acoustic emissions from customer's net metering facilities shall be equal to
or exceed the minimum standards for precision described in American Wind
Energy Association Standard 2.1 - 1989 titled Procedures for the Measurement
and Reporting of Acoustic Emissions from Wind Turbine Generation Systems
Volume I:  First Tier.



   (F)   Turbine blade location.  At its lowest point, the tip of any
turbine blade comprising part of a small wind energy system shall be no less
than 15 feet above the surface of the ground.



   (G)   Installation.  Customer's renewable electrical generating
facility may not be installed until evidence has been given that all utility
companies have been informed of the customer's intent to install an
interconnected customer-owned generator.  Off-grid systems shall be exempt
from this requirement.



   (H)   Removal.  If any customer's net metering facility is not
operational for a period exceeding 12 consecutive months, the landowner may
be required to remove it at their expense.



   (I)   Signage. No commercial signage is permitted.



   (J)   Screening. No screening is required.



(Ord. O-18-03, passed 4-10-2018)



§ 55.05  REQUIRED SAFETY FEATURES.



   (A)   Customer's small wind energy system shall be designed with an
automatic over-speed control to render the system inoperable when winds are
blowing in excess of the speeds for which the machine is designed.



   (B)   Customer's net metering facilities shall have a manually
operable method to render the system inoperable in the event of a structural
or mechanical failure of any part of the system.



   (C)   Customer's net metering facilities shall be designed with an
automatic control to render the system inoperable in case of loss of utility
power to prevent the net metering facility from supplying power to a
de-energized electrical distribution system.



(Ord. O-18-03, passed 4-10-2018)



§ 55.06  SMALL WIND ENERGY CONVERSION SYSTEMS (SWES).



   The following uses may be allowed by a special use permit in accordance
with the provisions of this chapter. SWES shall be permitted as a special use
pursuant to the following regulations.



   (A)   Location.  SWES may be located on property of no less than
one acre.



   (B)   Tower height.  The height of a SWES shall be measured from
the ground to the blade extended at its highest point. A single-family
residential use shall have a maximum height of 35 feet with a maximum blade
length of four feet and a maximum nameplate capacity of one kW.  A
commercial and industrial use shall have a maximum height of 50 feet with a
maximum blade length of ten feet and a maximum nameplate capacity of ten kW.



   (C)   Setback.  SWES shall be setback from all property lines,
above-ground utility lines, and roadways, a distance no less than 110% of the
tower height.  Any application that is a part of SWES including guy wires,
shall be setback from all property lines no less than 30 feet.



   (D)   Restriction.  No SWES shall be permitted in any front yard.



   (E)   Color.  SWES shall be painted a non-reflective, non-obtrusive
color or a color that conforms to the environment and architecture of its
surroundings.



   (F)   Illumination.  No SWES shall be lighted, except as required
by the FAA.



   (G)   Noise level.  Audible sound from a SWES shall not exceed 25
dBA in residential districts or 50 dBA in all other districts, as measured at
the exterior of any occupied building on an adjacent or neighboring
property.  Methods for measuring and reporting acoustic emissions from SWES
shall be equal to or exceed the minimum standards for precision described in
American Wind Energy Association Standard 2.1 - 1989 titled Procedures for
the Measurement and Reporting of Acoustic Emissions from Wind Turbine
Generation Systems  Volume I:  First Tier.



   (H)   Turbine blade location.  At its lowest point, the tip of any
turbine blade shall be no less than 15 feet above the surface of the ground.



   (I)   Access.  Access to SWES shall be controlled in a manner
consistent with local building codes.



   (J)   Installation.  No SWES shall be installed until evidence has
been given that the utility company has been informed of the customer's
intent to install an interconnected customer-owned generator.  Off-grid
systems shall be exempt from this requirement.



   (K)   Removal.  If any SWES is not operational for a period
exceeding 12 consecutive months, the landowner may be required to remove the
SWES at their expense.



(Ord. 1939, passed 5-11-2009; Ord. O-18-03, passed 4-10-2018)



§ 55.07  DISCONNECTION, TERMINATION, MODIFICATION AND ASSIGNMENT.



   (A)   Disconnection.



      (1)   The utility may disconnect, interrupt, or reduce
deliveries from the eligible renewable electrical generating facility upon
any of the following conditions, but must reconnect the eligible renewable
electrical generating facility once the condition is cured:



         (a)   For scheduled outages, provided that the eligible
renewable electrical generating facility is treated in the same manner as
utility's load customers;



         (b)   For unscheduled outages or emergency conditions;



         (c)   If the eligible renewable electrical generating
facility does not operate in the manner consistent with this agreement;



         (d)   Improper installation or failure to pass the
witness test;



         (e)   If the eligible renewable electrical generating
facility is creating a safety, reliability or a power quality problem; or



         (f)   The interconnection equipment used by the eligible
renewable electrical generating facility is de-listed by the Nationally
Recognized Testing Laboratory that provided the listing at the time the
interconnection was approved.



      (2)   Should customer's net metering facilities be declared to
be unsafe by the utility, it shall be deemed to be a public nuisance and
shall be abated by repair, rehabilitation, demolition or removal in
accordance with the procedures set forth in the city's Building Code.



   (B)   Termination.  This agreement may be terminated under the
following conditions:



      (1)   By customer. The customer may terminate any net metering
agreement by providing 30 days' prior written notice to the utility. If the
interconnection customer ceases operation of the eligible renewable
electrical generating facility, the customer must notify the utility.



      (2)   By the utility. The utility may terminate any net
metering agreement if the customer fails to remedy a violation of terms of
the agreement within 30 calendar days after notice, or such other date as may
be mutually agreed to prior to the expiration of the 30 calendar day remedy
period.  The termination date may be no less than 30 calendar days after the
customer receives notice of its violation from the utility.



   (C)   Modification of eligible renewable electrical generating
facility.  The customer must receive written authorization from the utility
before making any changes to the eligible renewable electrical generating
facility that could affect the utility's distribution system.  If the
customer makes such modifications without the utility's prior written
authorization, the utility shall have the right to disconnect the eligible
renewable electrical generating facility immediately.



   (D)   Permanent disconnection.  In the event the net metering
agreement is terminated, the utility shall have the right to disconnect its
facilities or direct the customer to disconnect its eligible renewable
electrical generating facility.



   (E)   Assignment/transfer of ownership of the eligible renewable
electrical generating facility.  A net metering agreement shall terminate
upon the transfer of ownership of the eligible renewable electrical
generating facility to a new owner unless the transferring owner assigns the
agreement to the new owner, the new owner agrees in writing to the terms of
the agreement, and the transferring owner so notifies the utility in writing
prior to the transfer of ownership.



(Ord. O-18-03, passed 4-10-2018)



§ 55.08  TERMS AND CONDITIONS.



   (A)   Governing law, regulatory authority, and rules.  The
validity, interpretation and enforcement of a net metering agreement and each
of its provisions shall be governed by the Codes and Regulations of the City
of Geneseo as well as the laws of the State of Illinois. Nothing in any
agreement is intended to affect any other agreement between the utility and
the customer.



   (B)   Survival rights.  Net metering agreements shall remain in
effect after termination to the extent necessary to allow or require either
party to fulfill rights or obligations that arose under the agreement.



   (C)   Force majeure. Neither party shall be liable to the other for,
or be considered to be in breach of or default under a net metering agreement
because of any failure or delay in performance by such party under the
agreement to the extent that such failure or delay is caused by or results
from any such cause or condition which is beyond such party's reasonable
control, or which such party is unable to prevent or overcome by exercise of
reasonable diligence, including breach of contract or failure of performance
by any person providing services to the utility.



   (D)   Entire agreement. Net metering agreements and any exhibits,
policies, and applications set forth the entire agreement of the parties and
supersede any and all prior agreements with respect to the subject matter for
the agreement. The rights and obligations of the parties under the agreement
shall be subject to and governed by this chapter.



   (E)   Independent contractors. The parties to net metering
agreements are independent contractors and shall not be deemed to be
partners, employees, franchisees, or franchisors, servants or agents of each
other for any purpose under or in connection with any agreement.



   (F)   Notice.  The parties may mutually agree to provide notices,
demands, comments, or requests in writing by electronic means such as
e-mail.  Absent agreement to electronic communication, or unless otherwise
provided in a net metering agreement, all applications and any written
notice, demand, or request required or authorized in connection with net
metering agreements shall be deemed properly given if delivered in writing,
in person, delivered by recognized national courier service, or sent by first
class mail, postage prepaid, to the person specified below:



      (1)   If to customer:  Use the contact information provided
in the customer's application. The customer is responsible for notifying the
utility of any change in the contact party information, including change of
ownership.



      (2)   If to utility:  Use the contact information provided
below. The utility is responsible for notifying the customer of any change in
the contact party information.



      Name:
_______________________________________________________________________________



      Mailing Address:
______________________________________________________________________



      City: _________________________________ State:
_____________________ Zip Code: ___________



      Telephone (Daytime): _________________________ (Evening):
________________________________



      Fax Number: ________________________________ E-Mail Address:
___________________________



(Ord. O-18-03, passed 4-10-2018)



§ 55.99  PENALTY.



   Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be fined not
less than $25 per day nor more than $500 per day.



(Ord. O-18-03, passed 4-10-2018)



TITLE VII:  TRAFFIC CODE



   Chapter

CHAPTER 70:  GENERAL PROVISIONS



Section



   70.01   Definitions



§ 70.01  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this title, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   BUSINESS DISTRICT.  The closely built up business portion of the city.



   CROSSWALK.  The portion of the roadway included within the
prolongation of the sidewalk lines at street intersections.



   DAY.  The time from 12:00 midnight to 12:00 the following midnight.



   DRIVER.  Any person who is in actual physical control of a vehicle or
street car.



   EMERGENCY VEHICLE.  Vehicles of the Police or Fire Departments,
ambulances, or any vehicle conveying a city official or employee in response
to an emergency official call.



   EXPLOSIVE.  Any chemical compound or mechanical mixture that is
commonly used or intended for the purpose of producing an explosion and which
contains any oxidizing and combustive units or other ingredients in
proportions, quantities, or packing that an ignition by fire, by friction, by
concussion, by percussion, or by detonator of any part of the compound or
mixture may cause a sudden generation of highly heated gases that the
resultant gaseous pressures are capable of producing destructible effects on
contiguous objects or of destroying life or limb.



   FARM TRACTOR.  Every motor vehicle designed and used primarily as a
farm implement for drawing plows, moving machines, and other implements of
husbandry.



   FLAMMABLE LIQUID.  Any liquid which has a flash point of 70°F or
less, as determined by the customary closed cup test device or equivalent.



   IMPROVED HIGHWAY.  A roadway of concrete, brick, asphalt, macadam, or
gravel.



   INTERSECTION.  The area embraced within the prolongation of the
property lines of two or more streets which join at an angle, whether or not
the streets cross.



   LANED HIGHWAY.  A street, the roadway of which is divided into three
or more clearly marked lanes for vehicular traffic.



   LOADING ZONE.  The space adjacent to a curb reserved for the exclusive
use of vehicles during the loading or unloading of passengers or materials.



   METAL TIRE.  Every tire, the surface of which in contact with the
roadway, is wholly or partly of metal or other hard, nonresilient material.



   MOTOR VEHICLE.  Every vehicle which is self-propelled, and every
vehicle which is propelled by electric power obtained from overhead wires,
but not operated upon rails.



   MOTORCYCLE.  Every motor vehicle having a saddle for the use of the
rider and designed to travel on no more than three wheels in contact with the
ground, but excluding a tractor.



   PARK.  To stand a vehicle, whether occupied or not, for a period of
time greater than is reasonably necessary for the actual loading or unloading
of persons.



   PEDESTRIAN.  Any person afoot.



   PNEUMATIC TIRE.  Every tire in which compressed air is designed to
support the load.



   PROPERTY LINE.  The line marking the boundary between any street and
the lots or property abutting thereon.



   PUBLIC BUILDINGS.  A building used by the city or by any park
district, school district, the state, or the United States government.



   RESIDENCE DISTRICT.  The closely built up residence portion of the
city.



   RESIDENTIAL DISTRICT.  Any area in which 75% or more of the buildings
therein are dwelling houses, as distinguished from buildings used for
commercial or industrial purposes.



   ROAD TRACTOR.  Every motor vehicle designed and used for drawing other
vehicles and not so constructed as to carry any load thereon, either
independently or any part of the weight of a vehicle or load so drawn.



   ROADWAY.  The portion of a street designed or ordinarily used for
vehicular traffic.



   SAFETY ZONE.  The portion of a roadway reserved for the exclusive use
of pedestrians, suitably marked or elevated.



   SEMI-TRAILER.  Every vehicle without motive power designed for
carrying persons or property and for being drawn by a motor vehicle and so
constructed that some part of its weight and that of its load rests upon or
is carried by another vehicle.



   SIDEWALK.  The portion of a street between the curb line and the
adjacent property line.



   SOLID TIRE.  Every tire of rubber or other resilient material which
does not depend upon compressed air for the support of the load.



   STREET.  Every way set aside for public travel except footpaths.



   SUBURBAN DISTRICT.  The portion of the city other than the closely
built up business and residence districts.



   TRAFFIC.  All vehicles using any street for travel.



   TRAILER.  Every vehicle without motive power designed for carrying
passengers or property and for being drawn by a motor vehicle and so
constructed that no part of its weight rests upon the towing vehicle.



   TRUCK.  Any motor vehicle used in the transportation of livestock for
hire, and includes a trailer.



   TRUCK TRACTOR.  Every motor vehicle designed and used primarily for
drawing other vehicles and not so constructed as to carry a load other than a
part of the weight of the vehicle and load so drawn.



   VEHICLE.  Any device by which any person or property may be
transported upon a highway, except those operated upon rails or tracks.



(Prior Code, § 8-1-1)
