   73.999   Penalty




BICYCLES




§ 73.001  APPLICATION OF CHAPTER.



   It is unlawful for any person to do any act forbidden, or fail to
perform any act required, in this chapter. The parent of any child, and the
guardian of any ward, shall not authorize or knowingly permit any child or
ward to violate any of the provisions of this chapter.



(Prior Code, § 8-4-1)  Penalty, see § 73.999



§ 73.002  TRAFFIC LAWS APPLIED.



   Every person riding a bicycle upon a highway shall be granted all of
the rights and shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to the driver
of a vehicle by this chapter, except as to those provisions of this chapter
which by their nature can have no application.



(Prior Code, § 8-4-2)



§ 73.003  PROPER RIDING POSITION; USE OF HANDS.



   (A)   (1)   A person propelling a bicycle shall not ride other
than upon or astride a permanent and regular seat attached thereto.



      (2)   No bicycle shall be used to carry more persons at one
time than the number for which it is designed and equipped, except that an
adult rider may carry a child securely attached to his or her person in a
backpack or sling.



(Prior Code, § 8-4-3) 



   (B)   No person operating a bicycle shall carry any package, bundle,
or article which prevents the use of both hands in the control and operation
of the bicycle.  A person operating a bicycle shall keep at least one hand
on the handlebars at all times.



(Prior Code, § 8-4-7)  Penalty, see § 73.999



§ 73.004  CLINGING TO VEHICLE PROHIBITED.



   No person riding upon any bicycle, coaster, roller skates, sled, or toy
vehicle shall attach the same or themselves to any vehicle upon a roadway.



(Prior Code, § 8-4-4)  Penalty, see § 73.999



§ 73.005  RIDING NEAR EDGE OF ROADWAY; EXCEPTIONS.



   (A)   Any person operating a bicycle or motorized pedal cycle upon a
roadway at less than the normal speed of traffic at the time and place and
under the conditions then existing, shall ride as close as practicable to the
right hand curb or edge of the roadway, except under the following situations:



      (1)   When passing another bicycle, motorized pedal cycle, or
vehicle proceeding in the same direction;



      (2)   When preparing for a left turn at an intersection or
into a private road or driveway; or



      (3)   When reasonably necessary to avoid conditions including,
but not limited to, fixed or moving objects, parked or moving vehicles,
bicycles, motorized pedal cycles, pedestrians, animals, surface hazards, or
substandard width lanes that make it unsafe to continue along the right hand
curb or edge. For purposes of this division, SUBSTANDARD WIDTH LANE means a
lane that is too narrow for a bicycle or motorized pedal cycle and a vehicle
to travel safely side by side within the lane.



   (B)   Any person operating a bicycle or motorized pedal cycle upon a
one-way highway with two or more marked traffic lanes may ride as near the
left hand curb or edge of the roadway as practicable.



(Prior Code, § 8-4-5)



§ 73.006  RIDING SIDE BY SIDE.



   Persons riding bicycles or motorized pedal cycles upon a roadway shall
not ride more than two abreast, except on paths or parts of roadways set
aside for their exclusive use. Persons riding two abreast shall not impede
the normal and reasonable movement of traffic and, on a laned roadway, shall
ride within a single lane, subject to the provisions of § 73.005.



(Prior Code, § 8-4-6)  Penalty, see § 73.999



§ 73.007  LAMPS; REFLECTORS; EQUIPMENT.



   (A)   Every bicycle, when in use at nighttime, shall be equipped
with a lamp on the front which shall emit a white light visible from a
distance of at least 500 feet to the front, and with a red reflector on the
rear, of a type approved by the city, which shall be visible from all
distances from 100 to 600 feet to the rear when directly in front of lawful
lower beams of head lamps on a motor vehicle. A lamp emitting a red light
visible from a distance of 500 feet to the rear may be used in addition to
the red reflector.



   (B)   A bicycle shall not be equipped with, nor shall any person use
upon a bicycle, any siren.



   (C)   Every bicycle shall be equipped with a brake which will
adequately control movement of and stop and hold the bicycle.



   (D)   No person shall sell a new bicycle, or a pedal for use on a
bicycle, that is not equipped with a reflex reflector on each pedal,
conforming to specifications prescribed by the Department and visible from
the front and rear of the bicycle during darkness from a distance of 200 feet.



   (E)   No person shall sell or offer for sale a new bicycle that is
not equipped with side reflectors. The reflectors shall be visible from each
side of the bicycle from a distance of 500 feet and shall be essentially
colorless or red to the rear of the center of the bicycle and essentially
colorless or amber to the front of the center of the bicycle provided. The
requirements of this division may be met by reflective materials which shall
be at least three-sixteenths of an inch wide on each side of each tire or rim
to indicate as clearly as possible the continuous circular shape and size of
the tires or rims of the bicycle and which reflective materials may be of the
same color on both the front and rear tire or rim. The reflectors shall
conform to specifications prescribed by the city.



   (F)   No person shall sell or offer for sale a new bicycle that is
not equipped with an essentially colorless front-facing reflector.



(Prior Code, § 8-4-8)  Penalty, see § 73.999



§ 73.008  LAMPS REQUIRED ON MOTORIZED PEDAL CYCLE.



   Every motorized pedal cycle, when in use at nighttime, shall be
equipped with a lamp on the front which shall emit a white light visible from
a distance of at least 500 feet to the front, and with a red reflector on the
rear, of a type approved by the city, which shall be visible from a distance
from 100 feet to 600 feet to the rear when in front of lawful, low-powered
beams of head lamps on a motor vehicle. A lamp emitting a red light visible
from a distance of 500 feet to the rear may be used in addition to the red
reflector.



(Prior Code, § 8-4-9)  Penalty, see § 73.999



§ 73.009  IDENTIFICATION NUMBER REQUIRED.



   A person engaged in the business of selling bicycles at retail shall
not sell any bicycle unless the bicycle has an identifying number permanently
stamped or cast on its frame.



(Prior Code, § 8-4-10)  Penalty, see § 73.999



§ 73.010  BICYCLE INSPECTION.



   A uniformed police officer may at any time, upon reasonable cause to
believe that a bicycle is unsafe or not equipped as required by law, or that
its equipment is not in proper adjustment or repair, require the person
riding the bicycle to stop and submit the bicycle to an inspection and test
with reference thereto, as may be appropriate.



(Prior Code, § 8-4-11)



§ 73.011  LEFT TURN REQUIREMENTS; TURN AND STOP SIGNALS.



   (A)   (1)   A person riding a bicycle or motorized pedal cycle
intending to turn left shall follow a course described in division (A)(2) of
this section.



      (2)   A person riding a bicycle or motorized pedal cycle,
intending to turn left, shall approach the turn as close as practicable to
the right curb or edge of the roadway. After proceeding across the
intersection roadway to the far corner of the curb or intersection of the
roadway edges, the bicyclist or motorized pedal cycle driver shall stop, as
much as practicable, out of the way of traffic. After stopping, the person
shall yield to any traffic proceeding in either direction along the roadway
the person had been using. After yielding, the bicycle or motorized pedal
cycle driver shall comply with any official traffic-control device or police
officer regulating traffic on the highway along which he or she intends to
proceed, and the bicyclist or motorized pedal cycle driver may proceed in the
new direction.



      (3)   Notwithstanding the foregoing provisions, the city may
cause official traffic-control devices to be placed and, thereby, require and
direct that a specific course be traveled by turning bicycles and motorized
pedal cycles, and, when devices are so placed, no person shall turn a bicycle
or motorized pedal cycle other than as directed and required by the devices.



(Prior Code, § 8-4-12)



   (B)   A signal of intention to turn right or left, when required,
shall be given during not less than the last 100 feet traveled by the bicycle
before turning, and shall be given while the bicycle is stopped waiting to
turn. A signal by hand and arm need not be given continuously, if the hand is
needed in the control or operation of the bicycle.



(Prior Code, § 8-4-13)  Penalty, see § 73.999



§ 73.012  PARKING.



   (A)   A person may park a bicycle on a sidewalk, unless prohibited
or restricted by an official traffic-control device.



   (B)   A bicycle parked on a sidewalk shall not impede the normal and
reasonable movement of pedestrian or other traffic.



   (C)   A bicycle may be parked on the roadway at any angle to the
curb or edge of the roadway at any location where parking is allowed.



   (D)   A bicycle may be parked on the roadway abreast of another
bicycle or bicycles near the side of the roadway at any location where
parking is allowed.



   (E)   A person shall not park a bicycle on a roadway in such a
manner as to obstruct the movement of a legally parked motor vehicle.



   (F)   In all other respects, bicycles parked anywhere on a highway
shall conform with the provisions of this title regulating the parking of
vehicles.



(Prior Code, § 8-4-14)  Penalty, see § 73.999



§ 73.013  BICYCLE RACING; TRICK RIDING.



   (A)   (1)   Bicycle racing on a highway shall not be unlawful
when a racing event has been approved by the city on any highway under their
respective jurisdictions. Approval of bicycle highway racing events shall be
granted only under conditions which assure reasonable safety for all race
participants, spectators, and other highway users, and which prevent
unreasonable interference with traffic flow which would seriously
inconvenience other highway users.



      (2)   By agreement with the city, participants in an approved
bicycle highway racing event may be exempted from compliance with any traffic
laws otherwise applicable thereto, provided that traffic control is adequate
to assure the safety of all highway users.



(Prior Code, § 8-4-15)



   (B)   No rider of a bicycle shall remove both hands from the
handlebars, or feet from the pedals, or practice any acrobatic or fancy
riding on any street, nor shall any person operating a bicycle upon a public
highway participate in any race for speed or endurance contest with any other
vehicles except under permit from and under the supervision of the Chief of
Police.



(Prior Code, § 8-4-16)  Penalty, see § 73.999



§ 73.014  RIDING OR PARKING ON SIDEWALK PROHIBITED.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to ride or operate any
form of bicycle, tricycle, skateboard, roller skates, push scooter, or
similar vehicle upon the sidewalks located in the city, except sidewalks
which are in the residential districts of the city. RESIDENTIAL DISTRICT, as
used herein, shall mean that portion of the city which is so defined and
limited in the zoning provisions of the city. Parents or guardians who push
or pull strollers or wagons to convey their young children are specifically
excepted from the prohibition of this section.



(Prior Code, § 8-4-17)



   (B)   Bicycles which are parked in business districts shall be
parked in designated bicycle parking areas. They shall not be parked on the
sidewalks.



(Prior Code, § 8-4-18)  Penalty, see § 73.999




SNOWMOBILES




§ 73.025  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   OPERATE.  To control the operation of a snowmobile.



   OPERATOR.  A person who operates or is in actual control of a
snowmobile.



   SNOWMOBILE.  A self-propelled vehicle designed for travel on snow or
ice, in natural terrain, steered by wheels, skis, or runners.



(Prior Code, § 8-5-1)



§ 73.026  PROHIBITIONS ON OPERATION.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a snowmobile under the
following circumstances:



   (A)   On private property of another without the express permission
to do so by the owner or occupant of the property;



   (B)   On public school grounds, park property, playgrounds, and
recreational areas without express provision or permission to do so by the
proper public authority;



   (C)   In a manner so as to create loud, unnecessary, or unusual
noise so as to disturb or interfere with the peace and quiet of other persons;



   (D)   In a careless, reckless, or negligent manner so as to endanger
the safety of any person or the property of any other person;



   (E)   Without having the snowmobile registered as provided for by
statute, except that this provision shall not apply to the operation of a
snowmobile on the private property of the owner by the owner or a member of
his or her immediate family; or



   (F)   Within the right-of-way of any public street.



(Prior Code, § 8-5-2)  Penalty, see § 73.999



§ 73.027  EXCEPTIONS.



   Notwithstanding the prohibitions of this subchapter, the Park Board
shall have the authority to supervise and regulate events or programs in
connection with events conducted by the Park Department in which snowmobiles
are used. The Park Board shall have the authority to designate city park
areas that it shall deem available for the use of snowmobiles.



(Prior Code, § 8-5-3)



§ 73.028  REQUIRED EQUIPMENT.



   All snowmobiles operated within the city shall have the following
equipment:



   (A)   Mufflers which are properly attached and which reduce the
noise of operation of the vehicle to the minimum noise necessary for
operating the vehicle, and no person shall use a muffler cut-out, by-pass, or
similar device on the vehicle;



   (B)   Adequate brakes in good working condition, and at least one
headlight and one taillight; and



   (C)   A safety or so called dead man throttle in operating
condition. SAFETY or DEAD MAN THROTTLE is a device which, when pressure is
removed from the accelerator or throttle, causes the motor to be disengaged
from the driving track.



(Prior Code, § 8-5-4)  Penalty, see § 73.999



§ 73.029  UNATTENDED VEHICLES.



   It is unlawful for the owner or operator to leave or allow a snowmobile
to be or remain unattended on public property while the motor is running, or
with the keys for starting the vehicle left in the ignition.



(Prior Code, § 8-5-5)  Penalty, see § 73.999



§ 73.030  TRAFFIC REGULATIONS APPLIED.



   Each person operating a snowmobile shall strictly observe all traffic
signs and signals and all other traffic rules and regulations applicable
thereto, and shall obey the orders and directions of any police officer of
the city authorized to direct or regulate traffic.



(Prior Code, § 8-5-6)  Penalty, see § 73.999



§ 73.031  DECLARATION OF SNOW EMERGENCY.



   The Mayor of the city shall have the power to declare a snow emergency
and suspend the provisions of § 73.026(F) for a period of time to be
specified by the Mayor in his or her declaration of the snow emergency.
During the suspension period of the section, a snowmobile may be operated
within the right-of-way of any public street within the city, but only if the
operator shall have a valid driver’s license or is accompanied by a
licensed driver who is actually occupying a seat in the vehicle.



(Prior Code, § 8-5-7)




ELECTRIC SCOOTERS




§ 73.045  APPLICATION OF RULES AND REGULATIONS TO SCOOTERS.



   All electric scooters shall be operated and maintained in a manner so
as to comply with all laws of this state and regulations of this city
governing the operation of motor vehicles, except as otherwise provided
herein.



(Prior Code, § 8-8-1)



§ 73.046  SINGLE DRIVER; NO PASSENGER ALLOWED.



   No person other than the driver shall operate an electric scooter. No
passenger shall be allowed to ride with a driver on an electric scooter.



(Prior Code, § 8-8-2)  Penalty, see § 73.999



§ 73.047  OPERATION RESTRICTED TO SIDEWALKS AND BIKE PATH.



   No electric scooter shall be allowed to travel on the streets, alleys,
or public ways within the city except as provided herein. Electric scooters
shall only be allowed to operate on the sidewalks in the city and shall be
allowed to operate on the bike trail route. This section shall supercede the
definition of motor vehicle and the restriction prohibiting a motor vehicle
to operate on sidewalks and the bike trail route. Notwithstanding anything to
the contrary, an electric scooter may operate on a crosswalk in the city if
the operator of the electric scooter is 16 years of age or older, and no
electric scooter shall be allowed to operate on sidewalks or crosswalks in
the business district or any other location in the city where the operation
of bicycles is prohibited.



(Prior Code, § 8-8-3)  Penalty, see § 73.999



§ 73.048  BICYCLE SAFETY PROVISIONS APPLY.



   The operator of an electric scooter shall be required to comply with
all the safety rules and regulations as may be provided by the city for
bicycle operators in the city.



(Prior Code, § 8-8-4)



§ 73.049  MAXIMUM SPEED; MINIMUM AGE.



   (A)   No electric scooter shall be operated at a speed greater than
12 mph at any time or at any location within the city.



(Prior Code, § 8-8-5)



   (B)   No one under the age of eight years shall be allowed to
operate an electric scooter.



(Prior Code, § 8-8-6)  Penalty, see § 73.999



NON-HIGHWAY VEHICLES



§ 73.060  PURPOSE.



   Whereas, the city, after considering volume, speed, and character of
traffic on streets with the city, finds that non-highway vehicles, as defined
herein, may not safely travel on and across the streets within the city, and
that the public safety will not be jeopardized by operation of such vehicles,
except as hereinafter permitted in this subchapter.



(Prior Code, § 8-9-1)  (Ord. 1983, passed 12-14-2010; Ord. O-13-077, passed
3-12-2013)



§ 73.061  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definition shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   NON-HIGHWAY VEHICLE. A motor vehicle not specifically designated to be
used on a public highway, including:



      (1)   An all-terrain vehicle, as defined by ILCS Ch. 625, Act
5, § 1-101.8 of the Illinois Vehicle Code;



      (2)    A golf cart, as defined by ILCS Ch. 625, Act 5, §
1-123.9;



      (3)   A neighborhood vehicle, as defined by ILCS Ch. 625, Act
5, § 1-148.3m;



      (4)   An off-highway motorcycle, as defined by ILCS Ch. 625,
Act 5, § 1-153.1;



      (5)   A recreational off highway vehicle, as defined by ILCS
Ch. 625, Act 5, § 1-168.8; and



      (6)   A low-speed vehicle, as defined by ILCS Ch. 625, Act 5,
§ 1-140.7.



(Prior Code, § 8-9-2)  (Ord. 1983, passed 12-14-2010; Ord. O-13-077, passed
3-12-2013)



§ 73.062  PROHIBITIONS AND LIMITATIONS ON OPERATION.



   (A)   Except as expressly permitted in this subchapter, it shall be
unlawful for any person to operate a non-highway vehicle on any street within
the city.



(Prior Code, § 8-9-3)



   (B)   (1)   A not for profit organization, or a person
participating in an authorized public parade may operate a non-highway
vehicle in conformance with the remaining terms of this subchapter, pursuant
to a permit issued by the Chief of Police in writing after application is
made for that purpose. The permit shall set forth the times and location of
the use of the non-highway vehicle.



      (2)   A non-highway vehicle may be operated pursuant to a
permit as set forth in division (B)(1) above as long as at a minimum it and
its driver comply with the following requirements:



         (a)   Brakes;



         (b)   A steering apparatus;



         (c)   Tires;



         (d)   A rearview mirror;



         (e)   Red reflector warning devices in the front and
rear;



         (f)   A slow moving emblem (as required of other
vehicles in § 12-709 of the Illinois Vehicle Code) on the rear of the
neighborhood vehicle;



         (g)   A headlight that emits a white light visible from
a distance of 500 feet to the front;



         (h)   A tail lamp that emits a red light visible from at
least 100 feet from the rear;



         (i)   Brake light; and



         (j)   Turn signals.



      (3)   When operated on a roadway, a non-highway vehicle shall
have its headlight and tail lamps lighted as required by § 12-201 of the
Illinois Vehicle Code. If approved, the operation of non-highway vehicles is
subject to the following requirements:



         (a)   The operator of the vehicle must hold a valid
driver's license issued by this or any other state.



         (b)   The vehicle is insured;



         (c)   The operator of the vehicle complies with the
applicable requirements of the Illinois Vehicle Code.



(Prior Code, § 8-9-4)  (Ord. 1983, passed 12-14-2010; Ord. O-13-077, passed
3-12-2013)   Penalty, see § 73.999



§ 73.999  PENALTY.



   (A)   Any person violating any provision of this chapter for which
no specific penalty is prescribed shall be subject to § 10.99



   (B)   Every person convicted of violation of §§ 73.001 through
73.014 of this chapter shall be punished by a fine of not less than $5 nor
more than $25, or shall have his or her bicycle impounded by the Chief of
Police for a period of not less than one week, nor more than four weeks, or
both fine and impounding.



(Prior Code, § 8-4-19)



   (C)   Any person found in violation of §§ 73.025 through 73.031 of
this chapter shall be subject to a fine of not less than $25, nor more than
$750.



(Prior Code, § 8-5-8)



   (D)   Every person convicted of violation of §§ 73.045 through
73.049 of this chapter shall be punished by a fine of not less than $5, nor
more than $25, or shall have his or her electric scooter impounded by the
Chief of Police for a period of not less than one week, nor more than four
weeks, or both fine and impounding.



(Prior Code, § 8-8-7)



   (E)   Any person found in violation of §§ 73.060 through 73.062 of
this chapter shall be subject to a fine of not less than $25, nor more than
$750.



(Ord. 1983, passed 12-14-2010)



CHAPTER 74:  PARKING SCHEDULES



Schedule



      I.   Downtown parking zones



      II.   Designated parking spaces



      III.   Time restrictions



      IV.   Parking prohibited



      V.   Private property parking - Wells Fargo Bank



      VI.   Stopping, standing, loading, unloading prohibited



SCHEDULE I.  DOWNTOWN PARKING ZONES.



   (A)   The following described streets in the city are hereby
designated and established as downtown parking zones, to-wit:



      (1)   State Street from the north line of North Street to the
south line of Park Street;



      (2)   Second Street from the west line of State Street to the
east line of Center Street;



      (3)   First Street from the west line of Oakwood Avenue to the
east line of the north and south alley running through the middle of blocks 2
and 3 of Munson’s Second Addition to the city;



      (4)   Exchange Street from the west line of Oakwood Avenue to
the east line of Center Street;



      (5)   Orange Street from the east line of State Street to the
east line of Oakwood Avenue;



      (6)   Sommers Avenue from the north line of Exchange Street to
the south line of Park Street;



      (7)   The portion of the west side of Center Street from the
south line of First Street to the north line of the alley running east and
west from Center Street through a portion of block 2 of Munson’s Addition
to the city; and



      (8)   Off-street parking in block 1 of Humphrey and Turner’s
First Addition.



   (B)   Also included are the north and south side of East Second
Street proceeding east from the intersection of State Street and Second
Street to the west edge of the alley dividing the block, and the east side of
South State Street proceeding south 50 feet from the south edge of North
Street.



(Prior Code, § 8-3-1)



SCHEDULE II.  DESIGNATED PARKING SPACES.



   (A)   The Street Department of the city shall, in the downtown
parking zone, designate and mark on those streets, spaces for vehicles to be
parked parallel to the curb of the streets.



   (B)   Angle parking is hereby permitted on the north side only of
Exchange Street from the west line of Oakwood Avenue to the east line of
State Street.



(Prior Code, § 8-3-2)



SCHEDULE III.  TIME RESTRICTIONS.



   (A)   No vehicle shall be continuously parked in a designated
parking space in a downtown parking zone longer than two hours. Hours during
which parking limitations are in effect are from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m.,
Monday through Saturday. On Sundays and holidays, there shall be no parking
limitation.



   (B)   Notwithstanding the foregoing provisions of this section,
those designated parking spaces situated on the north side of First Street
and which are adjacent to the property occupied by the United States post
office shall have a legal parking limit of 15 minutes, and no vehicle shall
be continuously parked in those parking spaces for a period longer than 15
minutes. Furthermore, the east side of the 200 block of South State Street
which borders and is adjacent to the public library shall, in all designated
parking spaces situated in that portion of South State Street, be limited to
a legal parking limit of one hour, and no vehicle shall be continuously
parked in those parking spaces longer than one hour.



   (C)   No vehicle shall be parked during the hours of 1:00 a.m. to
5:00 a.m. on the following streets:



      (1)   The west side of South Center Street from the south line
of West First Street to the private drive running east and west;



      (2)   The east side of South Center Street from the south line
of West Second Street to the north line of West North Street;



      (3)   Along either side of State Street from the south line of
Brown Street to the north line of Pearl Street;



      (4)   Along either side of Sommers Avenue from the south line
of East Park Street to the north line of East Exchange Street;



      (5)   Along either side of Exchange Street from the east line
of North Center Street to the west line of North Oakwood Avenue;



      (6)   Along either side of First Street from the east line of
the alley between College Avenue (Illinois Route 82) and Center Street to the
west line of Oakwood Avenue;



      (7)   Along either side of Second Street from the east line of
South Center Street to the west line of South State Street, and the north
side of Second Street from the east line of South State Street to the west
line of Oakwood Avenue, and the south side of Second Street from the east
line of South State Street to the alley running north and south; and



      (8)   Along either side of Orange Street from the east line of
North State Street to the west line of Sommers Street and the north side of
Orange Street from the east line of Sommers Street to the west line of North
Oakwood Avenue.



   (D)   No vehicle shall be parked along the north side of Ogden
Avenue between State and Center Streets for more than two hours between 7:00
a.m. and 4:00 p.m. on days when Geneseo High School is in session.



(Prior Code, § 8-3-4)  (Ord. O-17-22, passed 9-12-2017)



SCHEDULE IV.  PARKING PROHIBITED.



   (A)   No person shall park a vehicle, except when necessary to avoid
conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a police
officer or traffic-control device, in any of the following places:



      (1)   On a sidewalk;



      (2)   In front of a public or private driveway;



      (3)   Within an intersection;



      (4)   Within 15 feet of a fire hydrant;



      (5)   On a crosswalk;



      (6)   Within 20 feet of a crosswalk at an intersection;



      (7)   Within 30 feet upon the approach to any flashing beacon,
stop sign, or traffic controlled signal located at the side of the roadway;



      (8)   Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb, or within
20 feet of points on the curb immediately opposite the end of a safety zone;



      (9)   Within 50 feet of the nearest rail of a railroad grade
crossing;



      (10)   Within 20 feet of the driveway entrance to any fire
station, and on the entrance when properly sign-posted;



      (11)   On the roadway side of any vehicle parked at the edge
or curb of a street, commonly known as double parking;



      (12)   Alongside or opposite any street excavation or
obstruction when parking would obstruct traffic;



      (13)   Upon any bridge or within a tunnel or subway;



      (14)   Between the curb line and the sidewalk, except with the
permission of the owner or occupant of the adjacent premises;



      (15)   At any place where official signs prohibit parking;



      (16)   At the following specific locations:



         (a)   Along either side of College Avenue between Elk
Street and North Street, and on North Street from College Avenue to Henry
Street, and on Henry Street from North Street to Main Street, all of which is
marked as Illinois Route 82 within the corporate limits of the city;



         (b)   Along either side of College Avenue between Elk
Street and Smith Street;



         (c)   Along either side of Main Street and Oakwood
Avenue (marked Illinois Route 82 and U.S. Route 6) between the west corporate
limit and the southeast corporate limit within the corporate limits of the
city, with the exception of:



            1.   A parking lane along the south side of Main
Street located west of State Street approximately 117 feet in length
providing for two parking spaces;



            2.   A parking lane along the south side of Main
Street located east of State Street approximately 91 feet in length and
providing for three parking spaces; and



            3.   Diagonal parking in the parking area north of
Main Street between Center Street and State Street.



         (d)   Along either side of Oakwood Avenue (marked
Illinois Route 82) between Route 6 and Interstate 80;



         (e)   Along the south side of Smith Street between the
west right-of-way line of North State Street and the east right-of-way line
of North College Avenue, which is otherwise known as Illinois Route 82;



         (f)   Along the east side of South Chicago Street
between the south right-of-way line of Prospect Street and the north
right-of-way line of the public highway known as U.S. Route 6;



         (g)   On both sides of North Street within the limits of
the improvement, with the exception that parking will be permitted on the
north side of North Street from 30 feet east of State Street to 30 feet west
of Oakwood Avenue. Parking shall be prohibited 30 feet in advance of stop
signs with North Street;



         (h)   Along either side of Pearl Street between State
Street and Center Street, along either side of Center Street between Pearl

Street and State Street, and along either side of State Street between Main
Street and Pearl Street between the hours of 10:30 p.m. and 6:00 a.m.;



         (i)   Along the north side of Dilenbeck Drive going east
from the intersection of Neptune Street and Dilenbeck Drive to where
Dilenbeck Drive turns north;



         (j)   Along the north side of East North Street from the
east drive of the Community Center to the east right-of-way line of Spring
Street;



         (k)   Along the west side of North State Street between
Ogden Avenue to the south and the intersection of North State Street with
Smith Street to the north, parking shall be prohibited between the hours of
7:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. on days when J. D. Darnall Senior High School is in
session; and along the east side of North State Street from Ogden Avenue to
Wells Street without limitation as to time;



         (l)   Along the north side of Smith Street for its
entire length, parking shall be prohibited between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and
4:00 p.m. on days when J. D. Darnall Senior High School is in session;



         (m)   Along the south side of Smith Street;



         (n)   Along either side of Main Street, U.S. Route 6,
between the most westerly corporate limits of the city and Geneseo Street.
Parking will not be permitted within the limits of intersections as
determined by the state from intersection studies;



         (o)   Along either side of College Avenue between Elk
Street and North Street, and on North Street from College Avenue to Henry
Street, and on Henry Street from North Street to Main Street, all of which is
marked as Illinois Route 82 within the corporate limits of the city;



         (p)   Along the east side of Oakwood Avenue from East
Exchange Street to East Park Street;



         (q)   Along either side of North Center Street from the
south line of West Exchange Street to the north line of West First Street;



         (r)   Along either side of South Center Street from the
south line of West First Street to the north line of West Second Street,
except the west side of South Center Street from the south line of West First
Street to the alley running east and west;



         (s)   The west side of South Center Street from the
south line of West Second Street to the north line of North Street;



         (t)   Along the north side of West North Street east
from the east right-of-way line of South Vail Street to a point at which a
line extending north from the west curb line of South Henry Street intersects

         (u)   Along the east side of Stewart Street from
Exchange Street to Pearl Street;



         (v)   Along the south side of Park Street from Oakwood
Avenue to Pearl Street;



         (w)   Along the east side of Congress Street between the
entry drives to Millikin School from 7:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. on days when
school is in session;



         (x)   Along the east side of North Aldrich Street from
Ogden Avenue to Wells Street;



         (y)   Along the east side of North Russell Avenue from
Ogden Avenue to Wells Street; and



         (z)   Along the east side of North Russell Avenue from
Wells Street to Palace Row from 7:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. on days when Northside
Elementary School is in session.



         (aa)   Along the east side of Center Street between the
driveway entrance to Southwest School and Frank Street from 2:00 p.m. to 4:00
p.m. on days when Southwest School is in session.



   (B)   It shall be unlawful to park, or to operate, any motor vehicle
on any private property without the prior consent of the owner, lawful agent

   (C)   It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle upon any street for
the purpose of displaying it for sale or to park any vehicle upon any
business street from which vehicle merchandise is peddled.



(Prior Code, § 8-3-7)  (Ord. O-17-22, passed 9-12-2017)



SCHEDULE V.  PRIVATE PROPERTY PARKING - WELLS FARGO BANK.



   (A)   No person, firm, or corporation shall park a motor vehicle on
the private property owned by Wells Fargo Bank for a period of time longer
than two consecutive hours during the bank’s business hours.



   (B)   Notwithstanding the foregoing, no person, firm, or corporation
shall park a motor vehicle for any length of time on those areas of the
private property owned by Wells Fargo Bank designated for employee parking,
except for authorized employees of Wells Fargo Bank.



   (C)   No person, firm, or corporation shall park a motor vehicle for
any length of time on those areas of private property owned by Wells Fargo
Bank designated for disabled parking, except for a motor vehicle bearing
registered plates or decals issued to a physically disabled person.



   (D)   Wells Fargo Bank shall post signs giving notice that to park a
motor vehicle for a longer period of time than two consecutive hours during
the bank’s business hours is a violation of a city ordinance, and that the
violator shall be subject to the fines provided in§ 72.99. The signs shall
be approved by the Police Department prior to installation.



   (E)   The city and the Police Department are granted all rights to
enter upon the property for the purpose of enforcing these provisions. All
fines collected in the enforcement shall belong to the city.



   (F)   The property which is the subject of this division is
comprised of two separate hard-surfaced parking lots owned by the Wells Fargo
Bank, and described as follows.



      (1)   Lot 1.



         (a)   A tract of land in the Northwest Quarter of
Section 21, Township 17 North, Range 3 East, in the City of Geneseo, County
of Henry, State of Illinois, described as follows:  Beginning at the point
of intersection of the west line of State Street with the southerly line of
the Chicago, Rock Island, and Pacific Railroad Company’s station grounds;
thence westerly along said southerly line 310 feet, more or less, to a point
on the east line of Center Street; thence north along the extension of last
east line 38 feet, more or less, to a point of intersection with a line 15
feet southerly from and parallel with the centerline of the railroad
company’s southerly main track (eastbound main); thence southeasterly along
parallel line 310 feet, more or less, to a point on the extension of west
line of State Street; thence south along the last extension 38 feet, more or
less, to the point of beginning.



         (b)   Lots 2 and 3, all being and lying in Block One of
Munson’s Second Addition to the Town, now City, of Geneseo, Henry County,
Illinois.



      (2)   Lot 2.  That part of Lots 7 and 8 of Block Two of
Munson’s Second Addition to the town, now City of Geneseo, described as
follows:  Beginning at the southeast corner of said Lot Seven, running
thence west along the south line of Lot Seven 70 feet, thence north in a line
parallel with the east line of Block Two 115 feet, running thence east on a
line parallel with the south line of Lot Seven 43 feet, running thence south
in a line parallel with the east line of Block Two 15 feet, running thence
east in a line parallel with the south line of Lot Seven 27 feet to the east
line of Block Two, running thence south along the east line of Block Two 100
feet to the place of beginning; situated in Henry County, Illinois.



(Prior Code, § 8-3-12)



SCHEDULE VI.  STOPPING, STANDING, LOADING, UNLOADING PROHIBITED.



   On days when school is in session, no person shall park, stop, stand,
load or unload a vehicle, except when necessary to avoid a hazard or to
comply with the directions of a police officer or traffic- control device, in
any of the following places between 7:45 a.m. and 8:30 a.m. or between 2:30
p.m. and 3:30 p.m.:



   (A)   West side of Russell Avenue for the 100 feet north of Wells
Street;



   (B)   South side of Wells Street for the 175 feet east of Russell
Avenue;



   (C)   West side of Congress Street from Prospect to the south
driveway to Millikin School.



(Ord. O-17-22, passed 9-12-2017)

General Provisions



   90.40   Cruelty to animals



 



   90.99   Penalty




CATS




§ 90.01  DEFINITION.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definition shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   RUNNING AT LARGE.  The running or traveling of a cat or other feline
animal on or across any property other than that belonging to the owner or
keeper of the animal while the animal is not attached to a leash and held by
a person.



(Prior Code, § 7-2-1)



§ 90.02  RUNNING AT LARGE PROHIBITED.



   It shall be unlawful for any vicious, ferocious, or dangerous cat or
other feline, or any such animal with or liable to communicate any contagious
or infectious disease, or any such animal which shall bite any person or
injure any person, or any such animal without a rabies vaccination tag
attached to its collar or harness, to run at large. The running at large of
any cat or other feline animal within the corporate limits is hereby declared
to be a nuisance. It shall be the duty of the Police Department, and of other
officers and persons as the Mayor may from time to time designate, to abate
the nuisance and to destroy, kill, or remove all cats or other feline animals.



(Prior Code, § 7-2-2)  Penalty, see § 90.99



§ 90.03  RABIES VACCINATION REQUIRED.



   Each calendar year, every owner of a cat or other feline animal, four
months or more of age, shall cause the animal to be inoculated against rabies
by a licensed veterinarian. Evidence of the inoculation shall consist of a
rabies inoculation certificate signed by the person administering the
vaccine, and one copy of the certificate shall be given to the owner and
retained in his or her possession at all times. The licensed veterinarian who
inoculates the animals against rabies shall provide serially numbered rabies
inoculation tags, one to be issued with each rabies inoculation certificate.
The tag shall at all times be attached to a collar or harness worn by the
animal for which the certificate and tag have been issued.



(Prior Code, § 7-2-3)



§ 90.04  IMPOUNDING FEES.



   (A)   A pickup fee of $30 shall be assessed the owner or keeper of
the cat or other feline animal(s) at the time the cat is claimed by its owner
or keeper. A fee of $10 per day, or fraction thereof, shall also be assessed
for every day the cat is so impounded.



   (B)   The impounding fees as set forth in this section are separate
and distinct from the penalties hereinafter imposed for violation of this
subchapter.



(Prior Code, § 7-2-5)




DOGS




§ 90.15  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   DANGEROUS DOG.  Any individual dog which, when either unmuzzled,
unleashed, or unattended by its owner or a member of its owner’s family, in
a vicious or terrorizing manner, approaches any person in an apparent
attitude of attack upon streets, sidewalks, or any public grounds or places,
or any private property within the city.



   DOG.  All animals, male and female, of the canine species.



   OWNER/KEEPER.  Any person who shall harbor, or suffer, or permit any
dog to remain on any premises within the city under his or her charge or
control.



   STRAY DOG.  Any dog which is either not registered, or which cannot be
identified by a county license tag.



   VICIOUS DOG.



      (1)   Any individual dog that, when unprovoked, inflicts bites
or attacks a human being or other animal either on public or private property.



      (2)   Any individual dog with known propensity, tendency, or
disposition to attack without provocation, to cause injury, or to otherwise
endanger the safety of human beings or other animals.



      (3)   Any individual dog which has been found to be a
dangerous dog upon more than one occasion.



      (4)   Any dog defined as a vicious dog under the State Animal
Control Act, ILCS Ch. 510, Act 5.



      (5)   No dog shall be deemed vicious if it bites, attacks or
menaces a trespasser on the property of its owner, or harms or menaces anyone
who has tormented or abused it, or is a professionally trained dog for law
enforcement.



      (6)   Vicious dogs shall not be classified in a manner that is
specific as to breed, unless permitted by the State Animal Control Act.



(Prior Code, § 7-3-1)



§ 90.16  DETERMINATION AND NOTICE OF DANGEROUS DOGS.



   (A)   The County Animal Administrator, or his or her duly authorized
representative, or a law enforcement officer of the city, shall make the
determination that a dog is a dangerous dog, after an investigation has been
conducted.



   (B)   The finding will be made in writing, and shall be hand
delivered to the owner or person keeping the dog, or delivered by both
certified mail and by first class mail to his or her last known address
through the United States postal service. Delivery by certified mail shall be
considered properly delivered if the certified mail is returned to the city
with a notification that delivery was refused or unclaimed.



(Prior Code, § 7-3-2)



§ 90.17  CONTROL OF DANGEROUS DOGS.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to permit any dangerous dog to
leave the premises of its owner when the dog is not securely muzzled and
restrained with a leash having a tensile strength of no less than 300 pounds
and not exceeding three feet in length, and under the direct control and
supervision of the owner or keeper of the dog.



(Prior Code, § 7-3-3)  Penalty, see § 90.99



§ 90.18  VICIOUS DOGS PROHIBITED.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or maintain any dog which
has been found to be a vicious dog anywhere within the corporate limits of
the city, regardless of the conditions of the animal’s enclosure, restraint
or controllability.



(Prior Code, § 7-3-4)  Penalty, see § 90.99



§ 90.19  DETERMINATION, NOTICE, AND IMPOUNDMENT OF VICIOUS DOGS.



   (A)   The County Animal Control Administrator, or his or her duly
sworn representative, or a law enforcement officer of the city, shall make
the determination that a dog is a vicious dog as defined in this subchapter,
after an investigation has been conducted.



   (B)   The finding will be made in writing, and shall be hand
delivered to the owner or person keeping the dog, or delivered by both
certified mail and by first class mail to his, her or their last known
address through the United States postal service. Delivery by certified mail
shall be considered properly delivered if the certified mail is returned to
the city with a notification that delivery was refused or unclaimed. At the
same time, an impoundment order will be delivered to the owner or keeper of
the dog. IMPOUNDMENT means taken into custody of the pound, which is operated
by the county.



   (C)   The owner of any dog in the city which has been found to be
vicious shall surrender the animal to the pound by order of the County Animal
Control Administrator, or his or her duly authorized representative, or the
Chief of Police, or his or her duly authorized representative.



   (D)   If the owner of the vicious dog has not appealed the
impoundment order by filing an appropriate pleading with the Circuit Court of
the county within seven working days, the dog shall be humanely dispatched.



(Prior Code, § 7-3-5)



§ 90.20  DUTY UPON DOG BITE OCCURRENCE.



   (A)   If at any time a person is bitten by a dog, it shall be
reported to the Police Department immediately, who, in turn, shall notify the
Rabies Warden of the county, and the case shall then be under the
jurisdiction of the Rabies Warden. Any and all expenses incurred by the
procedure and any and all medical expenses incurred from the bite shall be
borne by the owner or keeper of the dog.



(Prior Code, § 7-3-6)



   (B)   It shall be the duty of the owner or keeper of any dog which
bites any human being to keep the dog locked up in an enclosure until the
Rabies Warden can investigate the circumstances.



(Prior Code, § 7-3-7)



§ 90.21  CITY PARKS AND OTHER PUBLIC AREAS.



   (A)   The owner or keeper of a dog shall keep the same on a leash at
all times when the dog is in a city park or other public area of the city.
The leash shall be of a reasonable length, not to exceed ten  feet, and the
dog shall be under the immediate control of the owner or keeper while on the
leash. Notwithstanding the foregoing provisions, the owner or keeper of a dog
may exercise the same without a leash in Richmond Hill City Park in those
areas specifically designated by signs for the purpose.



   (B)   The owner or keeper of a dog which is in a city park or other
public area shall not permit any solid waste excreted by the dog to remain in
or upon the city park or other public area grounds.



   (C)   The owner or keeper of a dog who violates either division (A)
or (B) above shall be subject to the penalties imposed below in § 90.99.



(Prior Code, § 7-3-8)  Penalty, see § 90.99



§ 90.22  NUISANCE DECLARED.



   (A)   Any dog, or animal of the dog kind, which by loud or unusual
barking or howling disturbs the peace and quiet of the neighborhood, or
causes the occupants of adjacent premises to be disturbed in any way, shall
be declared a nuisance.



   (B)   The owner or keeper of the nuisance on, in, or about his or
her premises, or premises under his or her control, shall be in violation of
this section, and subject to the penalties imposed below in § 90.99.



(Prior Code, § 7-3-9)  Penalty, see § 90.99



§ 90.23  RUNNING AT LARGE PROHIBITED.



   Any dog that is not attached to a leash and held by a person who is on
any property other than that belonging to the owner or keeper of the dog
shall be termed running at large. The owner or keeper of a dog running at
large shall be in violation of this subchapter and subject to the penalties
imposed below in § 90.99.



(Prior Code, § 7-3-10)  Penalty, see § 90.99



§ 90.24  IMPOUNDMENT PROCEDURE; TREATMENT; FEES.



   (A)   (1)   Any dog running at large, or any dog without a rabies
vaccination tag attached to its collar or harness, shall be taken by the City
Dog Catcher, or any police officer, and impounded in the City Dog Pound for a
period of not less than three days. At the end of this time, if the dog is
not claimed by its owner or keeper by paying the required fees, the dog shall
be disposed of at the discretion of the Chief of Police.



      (2)   Any person identifying an impounded dog as belonging to
him or her shall be served a notice to appear in court for violation of the
ordinance.



      (3)   Any owner or keeper not redeeming any dog impounded
within three days shall be deemed to have lost all property rights in the dog.



(Prior Code, § 7-3-11)



   (B)   Animals which are kept in the City Pound shall be humanely
treated, sheltered, and watered; the pound shall be under the charge of the
Pound Master, who shall be responsible for the care and custody of the
animals, but in no case will the city, Pound Master, or the Chief of Police
be responsible for the dog if it should die while being impounded in the
pound, providing the aforementioned care is adequately provided.



(Prior Code, § 7-3-12)



   (C)   (1)   A pickup fee of $30 shall be assessed the owner or
keeper of the dog at the time the dog is claimed by its owner or keeper. A
fee of $10 per day, or fraction thereof, shall also be assessed for every day
the dog is so impounded.



      (2)   The impounding fees as set forth in this section are
separate and distinct from the penalties hereinafter imposed for violation of
this chapter.



(Prior Code, § 7-3-13)



§ 90.25  UNAUTHORIZED ABANDONMENT PROHIBITED.



   No person shall leave, or cause any animal to be left, in or upon the
City Pound area without the express permission and authorization of the
proper representative of the Police Department or Humane Society.



(Prior Code, § 7-3-14)  Penalty, see § 90.99



§ 90.26  RABIES VACCINATION REQUIRED.



   Each calendar year every owner of a dog, four months or more of age,
shall cause the animal to be inoculated against rabies by a licensed
veterinarian. Evidence of the inoculation shall consist of a rabies
inoculation certificate signed by the person administering the vaccine, and
one copy of the certificate shall be given to the owner and retained in his
or her possession at all times. The licensed veterinarian who inoculates the
animals against rabies shall provide serially numbered rabies inoculation
tags, one to be issued with each rabies inoculation certificate. The tag
shall at all times be attached to a collar or harness worn by the animal for
which the certificate and tag have been issued. Failure of the owner of a dog
to have the same inoculated as herein provided shall be in violation of this
subchapter and subject to the penalties imposed below in § 90.99.



(Prior Code, § 7-3-15)  Penalty, see § 90.99



GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 90.40  CRUELTY TO ANIMALS.



   If a community service officer or peace officer has probable cause to
believe that an animal has been subjected to cruelty as defined in ILCS Ch.
510, Act 70, §§ 1 et seq. and that the animal's life, safety or health is
in danger, the community service officer or peace officer may seize and
impound the animal, may give the animal veterinary or other care at the owner
or keeper's expense, and may process the misdemeanor charges laws as outlined
in ILCS Ch. 510, Act 70, §§ 1 et seq.  The city adopts in its entirety
ILCS Ch. 510, Act 70, §§ 1 et seq., with the exception of prosecution as a
felony.  Any violation of ILCS Ch. 510, Act 70, §§ 1 et seq. at a felony
level will be processed through the criminal courts.



(Ord. 1957, passed 11-10-2009)



§ 90.99  PENALTY.



   (A)   Any person violating any provision of this chapter for which
no specific penalty is prescribed shall be subject to § 10.99



   (B)   Any owners or keepers of a cat or other feline animal who
shall suffer, or permit the same to run at large, in violation of the
provisions of §§ 90.01 through 90.04 of this chapter, shall be subject to a
fine and penalty of not less than $25 nor more than $100.



(Prior Code, § 7-2-4)



   (C)   (1)   Any person, firm, or corporation violating any of the
provisions of §§ 90.15 through 90.24, and the provisions of § 90.26 of
this chapter, shall be fined not less than $5 nor more than $25 for the first
offense; not less than $15 nor more than $100 for the second offense; not
less than $50 nor more than $200 for the third offense; and a separate
offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation
occurs or continues.



      (2)   In addition to the foregoing penalties, any dog which
has been subject to two prior running at large counts, or any vicious or
dangerous dog that has been the subject of one prior running at large count
may, at the discretion of the city, be turned over to a licensed veterinarian
for destruction by lethal injection.



(Prior Code, § 7-3-16)



   (D)   Any person, firm, or corporation violating any provision of §
90.25 shall be fined not less than $50 for the first offense; not less than
$100 for the second offense; not less than $200 for the third offense; and a
separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a
violation occurs or continues.



(Prior Code, § 7-3-14)



CHAPTER 91:  ABANDONED VEHICLES

   91.12   Limitation of liability

§ 91.01  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   ABANDONMENT, ABANDONING, and ABANDONED AUTO.  Any motor vehicle or
part thereof which a reasonable person would consider dumped, discarded, or
abandoned on private or public property in view of the general public under
the circumstances.



   ANTIQUE VEHICLE.  A motor vehicle that is more than 25 years of age,
or a bona fide replica thereof, and which is driven on the highways only
going to and returning from an antique auto show or an exhibition, or for
servicing or demonstration, or a fire-fighting vehicle more than 20 years old
which is not used as fire-fighting equipment but is used only for the purpose
of exhibition or demonstration. The mechanical and physical condition of the
vehicle, including brakes, lights, glass, and appearance, must be the same or
as safe as originally equipped. An antique vehicle may be a BONA FIDE
REPLICA, which is an exact copy of the original in design, frame, and
mechanical operation. FACSIMILES are close, but not exact, reproductions of
the original, and do not qualify for antique vehicle plates.



   INOPERABLE MOTOR VEHICLE.  Any vehicle from which, for a period of
seven or more days, the engine, wheels, doors, windows, or other parts have
been removed, or on which the engine, wheels, doors, windows, or other parts
have been altered, damaged, or otherwise so treated, that the vehicle is
incapable of being driven under its own power, or is incapable of being moved
by another vehicle designed to move it, including vehicles that are propped
up so that the wheels cannot be used to move the vehicle, or due to legal
prohibitions including, but not limited to, want of licenses, defective
parts, absence of required parts and the like. The obtaining and installation
of an antique vehicle license shall not be a defense against the enforcement
of this chapter for an inoperable motor vehicle, as defined herein.



   LAWFULLY OCCUPIED.  Premises occupied under a lease, contract,
license, or other consent.



   MOTOR VEHICLE.  An auto, car, motorcycle, truck, truck trailer, auto
trailer, camper, agricultural tractor, or implement, or any other vehicle for
use on the streets or highways or off highways, as well as any constituent
part thereof.



(Prior Code, § 8-7-1)



§ 91.02  EXEMPTED VEHICLES.



   The requirements of this chapter shall not apply to vehicles
specifically exempt from local licensing pursuant to the laws of the United
States or the state, or vehicles owned or operated by the city, provided that
the vehicles are so designated and lawfully registered.



(Prior Code, § 8-7-2)



§ 91.03  PROHIBITED ACTS.



   No person shall engage in any of the following acts:



   (A)   The abandonment of any motor vehicle on any street, highway,
tollway, expressway, alley, or other public way within the city;



   (B)   The abandonment of any motor vehicle on any public property or
on any private property within the city;



   (C)   The parking of any inoperable motor vehicle on any street,
highway, tollway, expressway, alley, or other public way within the city
where the same constitutes a hazard or dangerous condition for persons and
property lawfully using the highway;



   (D)   The parking of any inoperable motor vehicle on any street,
highway, tollway, expressway, alley, or other public way within the city for
more than ten hours;



   (E)   The parking of any inoperable motor vehicle on any private
property, except property owned or lawfully occupied or on public property,
without the consent of the owner or lawful occupant for more than 24 hours;
and/or



   (F)   The parking of any inoperable motor vehicle on private,
residentially or commercially zoned property and allowing the motor vehicle
to remain there for more than seven days, if the vehicle is open to the view
of the public and not stored within a permanent structure.



(Prior Code, § 8-7-3)  Penalty, see § 91.99



§ 91.04  REMOVAL OF ABANDONED OR INOPERABLE VEHICLE.



   (A)   Whenever any act prohibited by this chapter is perpetrated,
the Police Department shall have the right of authorized removal of the auto
concerned by towing at the time the prohibited act becomes violative of this
chapter.



   (B)   Whenever any citizen is the victim of an act done in violation
of this chapter, he or she shall have the right to request the police to
remove vehicle as if they had initiated the removal.



   (C)   In lieu of making the determination themselves, the police may
apply to the Circuit Court for a determination that a vehicle has been
abandoned or is inoperative.



      (1)   The proceeding held pursuant to this division shall be
an in rem proceeding against the vehicle.



      (2)   No hearing shall be held on an application under this
division until 24 hours’ notice has been given. Notice shall be given by
securely fastening to the vehicle a notice, or by notice in writing, stating
that a proceeding has begun by the city in a named branch of the Circuit
Court, the hour set for the hearing, and the relief requested from the court.



      (3)   The application to the court shall be verified and shall
state facts sufficient to allow the court to make a determination that there
is probable cause to consider the vehicle abandoned or inoperative, and that
the vehicle is parked in violation of this chapter.



      (4)   In the proceedings under this division, the sole
questions before the court shall be:



         (a)   Is there probable cause to believe the vehicle is
abandoned or inoperable; and



         (b)   Is it parked in violation of this chapter.



      (5)   If the court enters an order finding that there is
probable cause to believe the vehicle is abandoned or inoperable, and that
this chapter is being violated, the police shall thereafter proceed in
accordance with this chapter as regards to towing.



(Prior Code, § 8-7-4)



§ 91.05  IMPOUNDMENT OF ABANDONED OR INOPERABLE VEHICLE.



   (A)   The person who abandons the vehicle or parks an inoperative
vehicle in violation of this chapter shall be responsible for all towing,
storage, advertising, disposal, and related costs. In the event the person
cannot be found, the bill shall be paid by the city.



   (B)   After impounding a motor vehicle, the police shall deal with
the towed vehicle as follows:



      (1)   Within 96 hours of having a vehicle towed pursuant to
this chapter, the officer initiating the tow shall cause a complaint to be
filed charging the registered owner thereof with a violation of this chapter,
and the registered owner shall be responsible for the violation in all cases
except when, and only when, a stolen auto report has been filed, prior to the
tow occurring, with an authorized law enforcement agency; and



      (2)   When a motor vehicle or other vehicle is authorized to
be towed away pursuant to this chapter, the Police Department shall keep and
maintain a record of the vehicle towed, listing the color, the year of
manufacture, the manufacturer’s trade name, the manufacturer’s series
name, the body style, the vehicle identification number, and the license
plate year and number displayed on the vehicle. The record shall also include
the date and hour of the tow, the location towed from, the location towed to,
the reason for the towing, and the name of the officer authorizing the tow.



(Prior Code, § 8-7-5)



§ 91.06  RECORD SEARCH.



   (A)   When the Police Department does not know the identity of the
registered owner or other legally entitled person, it will cause the motor
vehicle registration records of the state to be searched, and direct
communication to the Secretary of State for the purpose of obtaining the
required ownership information.



   (B)   The Police Department will cause the stolen motor vehicle
files of the State Police to be searched, and direct communication to the
State Police for stolen or wanted information on the vehicle. When the State
Police files are searched with negative results, the information contained in
the National Crime Information Center (NCIC) files will be searched by the
State Police. The information determined from these record searches will be
used by the Police Department in sending a notification by certified mail to
the owner or legally entitled person, advising where the vehicle is held,
requesting a disposition be made, and setting forth public sale information.



   (C)   When the registered owner, or other person legally entitled to
the possession of a motor vehicle, or other vehicle impounded pursuant to
this chapter, cannot be identified from the registration files of this state
or from the registration files of a foreign state, if applicable, the Police
Department shall notify the State Police for the purpose of identifying the
vehicle’s owner or other person legally entitled to the possession of the
vehicle. The information obtained by the State Police will be immediately
forwarded to the law enforcement agency having custody of the vehicle for
notification of the owner.



(Prior Code, § 8-7-6)



§ 91.07  RECLAIMED VEHICLES; EXPENSES.



   Any time before a motor vehicle or other vehicle is sold at public sale
or disposed of as provided in this chapter, the owner, or other person
legally entitled to its possession, may reclaim the vehicle by presenting to
the Police Department proof of ownership or proof of the right to possession
of the vehicle.  No vehicle shall be released to the owner or other person
under this chapter until all towing and storage charges have been paid.



(Prior Code, § 8-7-7)



§ 91.08  DISPOSAL OF UNCLAIMED VEHICLE.



   (A)   (1)   Whenever an abandoned, lost, stolen, or unclaimed
motor vehicle, or other vehicle seven years of age or newer, remains
unclaimed by the registered owner, or other person legally entitled to its
possession, for a period of 30 days after notice has been given as provided
in this chapter, the Police Department having possession of the vehicle shall
cause it to be sold at public sale to the highest bidder. Notice of the time
and place of the sale shall be posted in a conspicuous place for at least ten
days prior to the sale on the premises where the vehicle has been impounded.
At least ten days prior to the sale, the Police Department shall cause a
notice of the time and place of the sale to be sent by certified mail to the
registered owner, or other person known by the Police Department or towing
service to be legally entitled to the possession of the vehicle. The notice
shall contain a complete description of the vehicle to be sold and what steps
must be taken by any legally entitled person to reclaim the vehicle.



      (2)   When an abandoned vehicle of more than seven years of
age is impounded as specified by this chapter, it will be kept in custody for
a minimum of ten days for the purpose of determining ownership, the
contacting of the registered owner by United States mail, public service, or
in person, for a determination of disposition, and, an examination of the
State Police stolen motor vehicle files for theft and wanted information. At
the expiration of the ten-day period, without the benefit of disposition
information being received from the registered owner, the Chief of Police
will authorize the disposal of the vehicle as junk only.



      (3)   In those instances where the certified notification
specified herein has been returned by the postal authorities to the Police
Department due to the addressee having moved or being unknown at the address
obtained from the registration records of this state, the sending of a second
certified notice will not be required.



(Prior Code, § 8-7-8)



   (B)   When the identity of the registered owner or other person
legally entitled to the possession of an abandoned, lost, or unclaimed
vehicle of seven years of age or newer cannot be determined by any means
provided for in this chapter, the vehicle may be sold as provided herein, or
disposed of in the manner authorized by this division without notice to the
registered owner, or other person legally entitled to the possession of the
vehicle.



(Prior Code, § 8-7-9)



§ 91.09  POLICE REPORT AFTER VEHICLE RECLAIMED OR DISPOSED.



   When a motor vehicle in the custody of the Police Department is
reclaimed by the registered owner, or other legally entitled person, or when
the vehicle is sold at public sale or otherwise disposed of as provided in
this chapter, a report of the transaction will be maintained by the Police
Department for a period of one year from the date of the sale or disposal.



(Prior Code, § 8-7-10)



§ 91.10  DISPOSITION OF UNCLAIMED VEHICLE SALE PROCEEDS.



   When a vehicle located within the corporate limits of the city is
authorized to be towed away by the Chief of Police and disposed of as set
forth in this chapter, the proceeds of the public sale or disposition, after
the deduction of towing, storage, and processing charges, shall be deposited
in the city treasury.



(Prior Code, § 8-7-11)



§ 91.11  ADMINISTRATIVE FEES.



   When towing companies, junk yard, salvage company or similar business
entity requests that the Police Department or Community Service Officer (CSO)
complete junk title or salvage paperwork on the company's behalf, all
reasonable administrative fees shall be paid to the city. Paperwork includes
certificate of purchase, for the transferring of ownership of abandoned,
lost, stolen, or unclaimed vehicles pursuant to Illinois Compiled Statutes,
owner and lien holder notifications. Acceptable administrative fees shall be
for cost of postage, for certified letters or regular postage rates for
letters mailed.  The current postage rate at the time of the mailing shall
be used to determine the amount paid to the city, for services rendered.



(Ord. 1934, passed 4-14-2009)  (Ord. 1934, passed 4-14-2009)



§ 91.12  LIMITATION OF LIABILITY.



   Any police officer, towing service owner, operator, or employee shall
not be held to answer, or be liable for damages, in any action brought by the
registered owner, former registered owner, or his or her legal
representative, or other person legally entitled to the possession of a motor
vehicle or other vehicle, when the vehicle was processed, sold, or disposed
of as provided by this chapter.



(Prior Code, § 8-7-12)



§ 91.99  PENALTY.



   Any person or business convicted of any offense under this chapter
shall be punished by a fine of not less than $25 nor more than $750. A person
shall be guilty of a separate offense for each and every day during any
portion of which any offense occurs.



(Prior Code, § 8-7-13)
