WARDS AND NUMBERING




§ 92.01  CITY DIVIDED INTO WARDS.



   The city shall be divided into four wards, described as follows:



   (A)   First Ward.  All that part of the city which lies south of
the center line of North Street starting at Oakwood Avenue, extended to the
east to the city limit line, and all that part of the city that lies east of
the center line of Oakwood Avenue starting at North Street, extended to the
south to north of the center line of South Street, extending east to east of
the center line of Spring Street, extended south to south of the center line
of Chestnut Street, extended to the west to east of the center line of
Oakwood Avenue,  extended to U.S. Route 6 to the south; further, all that
part of the city which lies east of the center line of Highway Route 82
running south from its intersection with Highway Route 6;



   (B)   Second Ward.  All that part of the city which lies west of
the center line of Russell Avenue starting at Second Street extended to the
north to north of the center line of Wells Street extended east to west of
the center line of Meadow Street, extending north to north of the center line
of Ogden Avenue, extending east to the west of the center line of Chicago
Street, extending north on Chicago Street to the city limit line; further,
all that part of the city which lies north of the center line of Second
Street extended from west of the center line of Russell Avenue, extending
west to the city limit lines; further all that part of the city which lies
north of the center line of Ogden Avenue and west of the center lines of
Chicago Street/Grange Road;



   (C)   Third Ward.  All that part of the city which lies east of the
center line of Russell Avenue extended to the north from North Street to
south of the center line of Wells Street, extended to the east to east of the
center line of Meadow Street extending to the north to south of the center
line of Ogden Avenue, extending east to east of the center line of Chicago
Street extended north to the city limit line, and north of the center line of
North Street extended to the east from east of the center line of Russell
Avenue to the city limit line; further all that part of the city that lies
east of the center line of Chicago Street, north of Ford Road; and



   (D)   Fourth Ward.  All that part of the city which lies south of
the center line of Second Street starting at Russell Avenue extended west to
the western city limit line; further, all that part of the city which lies
south of the center line of Second Street and west of the center line of
Russell Avenue, extended to the south to north of the center line of North
Street, extended west to west of the center line of Oakwood Avenue, extending
south to south of the center line of South Street, extending east to west of
the center line of Spring Street, extending south to north of the center line
of Chestnut Street, extending west to west of the center line of Oakwood
Avenue; further, all that part of the city which lies west of the center line
of Oakwood Avenue from its intersection with Chestnut Street to its
intersection, as extended, with U.S. Route 6; further, all that part of the
city which lies west of the center line of Highway Route 82 running south
from its intersection with U.S. Route 6; further all that part of the city
which lies west of Hanford Street extending north to the city limit line at N
2100th Avenue.



(Prior Code, § 1-6-1) (Ord. O-18-13, passed 8-14-2018)



§ 92.02  NUMBERS REQUIRED FOR ALL LOTS AND BUILDINGS.



   All lots and parts of lots and buildings lying within the corporate
limits of the city shall be designated by street numbers in the manner
prescribed in this subchapter.



(Prior Code, § 1-7-1)



§ 92.03  DESIGNATION OF DIRECTION.



   (A)   All those portions of streets running north and south, or
having their principal direction north and south, lying north of First
Street, or lying north of that part of Exchange Street east of Russell
Avenue, shall be designated by the word “North” prefixed to the name of
the street.



   (B)   All portions of streets running north and south, or having
their principal directions north and south, lying south of First Street, or
lying south of that part of Exchange Street east of Russell Avenue, shall be
designated by the word “South” prefixed to the name of the street.



   (C)   All portions of streets running east and west, or having their
principal directions east and west, lying east of State Street shall be
designated by the word “East” prefixed to the name of the street.



   (D)   All portions of streets running east and west, or having their
principal directions east and west, lying west of State Street shall be
designated by the word “West” prefixed to the name of the street.



(Prior Code, § 1-7-2)



§ 92.04  NUMBERING SYSTEM.



   Streets shall be numbered on the plan of 100 numbers to each block, and
one number for each 25 feet as far as practicable, numbering from First
Street, Exchange Street, or State Street as base lines, beginning with the
number 100 at each base line, north, south, east, or west, as the case may
be. Even numbers shall be assigned to the east and south sides of each block,
and odd numbers to the west and north sides of each block. All streets that
neither touch nor cross either of the base streets shall be numbered in the
same manner as though they crossed the base streets. As far as practicable,
corresponding numbers shall be assigned to all buildings and lots situated on
parallel streets and the same relative distance from their respective base
streets.



(Prior Code, § 1-7-3)



§ 92.05  APPLICATION FOR NUMBER.



   Any owner or occupant of any lot or building desiring to place upon it
the number thereof shall make application to the Public Service
Superintendent, who shall designate the number appropriate to the lot or
building in accordance with the provisions of this chapter and, upon request,
the Public Service Superintendent shall furnish without charge under his or
her hand a certificate as to the number.



(Prior Code, § 1-7-4)



§ 92.06  SIZE AND LOCATION OF NUMBERS.



   All numbers placed upon buildings or lots in this city shall consist of
figures not less than three inches in height, and shall be displayed in a
conspicuous place or manner in front of the building for which they are
designated.



(Prior Code, § 1-7-5)




ENCROACHMENTS




§ 92.20  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   ALTERNATIVE ANTENNA STRUCTURE. An existing pole or other structure
within the public right-of-way that can be used to support an antenna and is
not a utility pole or a city-owned infrastructure.



   ANTENNA. Communications equipment that transmits or receives
electromagnetic radio signals used in the provision of any type of wireless
communications services.



   CITY-OWNED INFRASTRUCTURE. Infrastructure in public right-of-way within
the boundaries of the city, including, but not limited to, streetlights,
traffic signals, towers, structures, or buildings owned, operated or
maintained by the city, other than city-owned electric utility facilities.



   ENCROACHMENT.  Any building, fence, sign, or any other structure or
object of any kind, with the exception of utilities and public road signs,
which is placed, located, or maintained in, on, under, or over any portion of
the roadway right-of-way.



   MONOPOLE. A structure composed of a single spire, pole or tower
designed and used to support antennas or related equipment and that is not a
utility pole, an alternative antenna structure, or city-owned infrastructure.



   RIGHT-OF-WAY.  Those areas existing or acquired by dedication or by
fee simple for highway purposes; also, the areas acquired by temporary
easement during the time the easement is in effect.



   TELECOMMUNICATION EQUIPMENT. Equipment, exclusive of an antenna, that
is part of a telecommunications facility.



   TELECOMMUNICATIONS FACILITY. An antenna, equipment, and related
improvements used, or designed to be used, to provide wireless transmission
of voice, data video streams, images, or other information including, but not
limited to, cellular phone service, personal communication service, paging,
and wi-fi antenna service.



   TOWER. Any structure that is designed and constructed primarily for the
purpose of supporting one or more antennas, including self-supporting lattice
towers, guy towers, or monopole towers, and that is not a utility pole, an
alternative antenna structure, or a city-owned infrastructure. Except as
otherwise provided for by this chapter, the requirements for a tower and
associated antenna facilities shall be those required in this chapter.



   UTILITY POLE. An upright pole designed and used to support electric
cables, telephone cables, telecommunication cables, cable service cables,
which are used to provide lighting, traffic control, signage, or a similar
function.



   VARIANCE or VARIATION. A grant of relief by the City Administrator or
his/her designee.



(Prior Code, § 1-8-1) (Ord. O-17-13, passed 4-11-2017)



§ 92.21  ENCROACHMENT PROHIBITED; VALIDITY.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to
erect or cause to be erected, to retain or cause to be retained, an
encroachment within the limits of the roadway right-of-way. The foregoing
prohibition shall not apply to free standing signs no larger than four square
feet in area advertising garage sales or similar neighborhood events, which
shall be allowed in the right-of-way areas for no longer than 72 hours.



(Prior Code, § 1-8-2)



      (1)   All signs permitted within the right-of-way under
division (A) above must comply with all federal, state and local rules and
regulations regarding underground utilities, to include JULIE at 811.



      (2)   No signs permitted within the right-of-way under
division (A) above shall be attached to or otherwise placed on utility poles
located within such right-of-way.



   (B)   This section is intended to and shall be in addition to all
other sections, rules, and regulations concerning encroachment, and shall not
be construed as repealing or rescinding any other section or part of any
section unless it is in direct conflict therewith.



(Prior Code, § 1-8-4) (Ord. O-14-108, passed 8-12-2014)



Penalty, see § 92.99



RIGHT-OF-WAY OPENING PERMIT



§ 92.35  PERMIT REQUIRED.



   Except as specified in § 92.36 of this chapter, no city street, alley,
sidewalk, or property shall be disturbed, hollowed, pitted, tunneled, or
excavated for the purpose of installing, constructing, enlarging, altering,
repairing, abandoning, removing, or improving underground utilities unless a
separate permit for each excavation has first been obtained from the city.
The property owner or contractor shall be responsible for the cost of the
street backfilling and surface repair as set forth in the repair and
restoration fee schedule below.  The excavation permit fee shall be set by
Council resolution.  The permit fee is separate from the costs to replace
the right-of-way surface and sub base.



(Prior Code, § 4-7-1)  (Ord. O-15-142, passed 5-12-2015)  Penalty, see §
92.99



§ 92.36  PERMIT EXEMPTION.



   (A)   A right-of-way opening permit shall not be required for the
following work:



      (1)   City departments working on city-owned utilities;
however, § 92.41 of this chapter pertaining to notice and inspections is
applicable; and



      (2)   Emergency repairs to underground utilities; however, a
permit, if required, shall be obtained the next working day, and backfilling
and surface repair shall be subject to the conditions set forth in § 92.38
of this chapter.



   (B)   Exemption from the permit requirements of this subchapter
shall not be deemed to grant authorization for any work to be done in any
manner in violation of the provisions of adopted codes or ordinances of the
city.



(Prior Code, § 4-7-2)  (Ord. O-15-142, passed 5-12-2015)



§ 92.37  PERMIT APPLICATION.



   (A)   To obtain a permit, the property owner, or, if the work is
performed by a contractor, the contractor, shall first file an application in
writing at the office of the Director of Public Works.  The application
shall include:



      (1)   Purpose of work;



      (2)   Location of work;



      (3)   Measurements of area and estimate of the cubic yardage
to be excavated;



      (4)   Type of surface that will be removed;



      (5)   Starting and ending dates of the work;



      (6)   A sketch of the work location;



      (7)   Certificate of insurance in the amount of $1,000,000, or
as specified by City Council; and



      (8)   Signed hold harmless agreement.



   (B)   The application and supporting documents filed by an applicant
for a permit shall be reviewed by the Director of Public Works. If the
Director of Public Works finds that the work described in the application for
a permit and supporting documents conform to the requirements of the city and
the applicant has no outstanding bill from a previous street excavation
permit, or is currently not in violation of this subchapter, then the
Director of Public Works shall issue permit and authorize commencement of
work.



(Prior Code, § 4-7-3)  (Ord. O-15-142, passed 5-12-2015)



§ 92.38  PERMIT FEES.



   (A)   Permit fees shall be established by City Council resolution.



   (B)   Repair and restoration fee shall include the cost of
right-of-way surface and sub base repair and restoration costs. All repair
and restoration work will be done to city specified standards and specs. 
The contractor may have the repairs and restoration completed by a city
licensed contractor or opt for the city to complete the work.  If the city
completes or hires the work to be done, the permit holder will be responsible
for all costs incurred by the city.  If a licensed contractor does not
complete the work to the city's standards, the city shall order the repairs
to be brought to city specs and all charges will be incurred by the permit
holder.



   (C)   Whenever any work for which a permit is required by this
chapter has been commenced without first obtaining a permit, except as
provided in § 92.36, the fee for the permit shall be double the regular
fee.  All contractors that install utilities underground shall provide the
city with drawings and asbuilts with exact locations and depths of any
installations.



   (D)   Fee for excavations made by or for the city is hereby waived.



(Prior Code, § 4-7-6)  (Ord. O-15-142, passed 5-12-2015)



§ 92.39  PERMIT SUSPENSION; REVOCATION; EXTENSION.



   The Public Service Superintendent may extend the permit at the
Superintendent’s discretion. The Public Service Superintendent may, in
writing, suspend or revoke a permit issued whenever the permit is issued in
error, or on the basis of incorrect information submitted, or in violation of
any section or regulation of any city ordinance or adopted code.



(Prior Code, § 4-7-5)



§ 92.40  PERMIT EXPIRATION.



   (A)   Permits issued by the city shall expire by limitation and
become void if the work authorized by the permit is not commenced within
seven days from the date of the permit.



   (B)   Permits issued by the city shall expire when the work
authorized by the permit is suspended or abandoned at any time after the work
is commenced for a period of seven days, and the Public Service Department
shall backfill the excavation and repair the surface of the street.



   (C)   Whenever a permit has expired as provided in this section, and
as provided in § 92.39, and has not been renewed, the permit applicant is in
violation of the city code and subject to the penalty stated in § 92.99.



(Prior Code, § 4-7-4)



§ 92.41  INSPECTION OF WORK AREA; SAFETY AND CLEAN-UP REQUIREMENTS.



   (A)   All work shall remain accessible and exposed for inspection
purposes until approved by the Public Service Superintendent or assignee, and
City Plumbing Inspector as applicable.



   (B)   The permit applicant shall notify the Public Service
Superintendent that the work is ready for inspection. The request may be in
writing or by telephone and must be requested at least one working day before
the inspection is desired.



   (C)   Neither the Public Service Superintendent, nor the city, shall
be liable for expenses entailed in the removal or replacement of material
required to allow inspection.



   (D)   The permit applicant shall place warning devices in accordance
with requirements of the State Department of Transportation and the city.
Flagpersons may be required at the discretion of the Public Service
Superintendent. The permit applicant shall secure the work area whenever the
area is unsupervised or workers are not present.



   (E)   The permit applicant shall remove all debris from the
excavation.



(Prior Code, § 4-7-7)



TELECOMMUNICATIONS FACILITIES



§ 92.45  STANDARDS AND REGULATIONS FOR TELECOMMUNICATIONS FACILITIES.



   Telecommunication facilities will be permitted to be placed in
right-of-way within the jurisdiction of the city as attachments to existing
utility poles, alternative antenna structures, or city-owned infrastructure
subject to the following regulations:



   (A)   Number limitation and co-location. The City Administrator or
his/her designee may regulate the number of telecommunications facilities
allowed on each utility pole or city-owned infrastructure based on the height
of the utility pole or city-owned infrastructure, the additional height added
by the telecommunications facility, the ability for the utility pole or
city-owned infrastructure to safely support the telecommunications facility
and the aesthetic impact of the proposed telecommunications facility.  This
subchapter does not preclude or prohibit co-location of telecommunication
facilities on towers or monopoles that meet the requirements as set forth
elsewhere in this section or as required by federal law.



   (B)   Separation and clearance requirements. Telecommunication
facilities may be attached to a utility pole, alternative antenna structure,
monopole, or city-owned infrastructure only where such pole, structure or
infrastructure is located no closer than a distance equal to 100% of the
height of such facility to any residential building. A separation or lesser
clearance may be allowed by the City Administrator or his/her designee as an
administrative variance to this subchapter when the applicant establishes
that the lesser separation or clearance is necessary to close a significant
coverage or capacity gap in the applicant's services, and the proposed
antenna or facility is the least intrusive means to do so within the
right-of-way.



   (C)   Order of preference. In addition to the other regulations
described in this subchapter, telecommunications facilities shall be located
in the right-of-way in accordance with the following order of preference:



      (1)   Existing city-owned infrastructure;



      (2)   Existing utility poles, subject to the approval of the
City Administrator. The City Administrator shall approve, and may not
disapprove, an existing utility pole unless the Director of Electrical
Operations recommends not to approve a specific utility pole for reasons
designed to protect the safety and reliability of the city's electric utility
service;



      (3)   Replacement city-owned infrastructure or utility pole;



      (4)   Alternative antenna structure; and



      (5)   A new tower.



   (D)   City-owned infrastructure. Telecommunication facilities can
only be mounted to utility poles or city-owned infrastructure including, but
not limited to, streetlights, traffic signals, towers or buildings, if
authorized by a license or other agreement between the applicant and the
owner of the utility pole or the city. 



   (E)   New or replacement towers. No new monopole or other tower to
support telecommunication facilities is permitted to be installed on
right-of-way within the jurisdiction of the city unless the City Council
finds, based on clear and convincing evidence provided by the applicant, that
locating the telecommunications facilities on a new tower or monopole in the
right-of-way is necessary to close a significant coverage or capacity gap in
the applicant's services, and the proposed new monopole or other tower within
the right-of-way is the least intrusive means to do so. The height of any new
or replacement monopole or other tower may not exceed the average height of
existing utility poles or city-owned infrastructure located within 300 feet
of the proposed location by greater than ten feet or 10% of the average,
whichever is greater.



   (F)   Attachment limitations. No antenna or telecommunications
facility within the right-of-way will be attached to a utility pole,
alternative antenna structure, tower, or city-owned infrastructure unless all
of the following conditions are satisfied:



      (1)   Volume of antenna.  The antenna, including antenna
panels, whip antennas or dish-shaped antennas, cannot have a volume of more
than seven cubic feet in volume.



      (2)   Size of above-ground telecommunication facility. The
total combined volume of all above-ground equipment and appurtenances
comprising a telecommunication facility, exclusive of the antenna itself,
cannot exceed 32 cubic feet.



      (3)   Telecommunication equipment. The operator of a
telecommunication facility must, whenever possible, locate the base of the
equipment or appurtenances at a height of no lower than eight  feet above
grade.



      (4)   Telecommunication equipment mounted at grade. In the
event that the operator of a telecommunication facility proposes to install a
facility where equipment or appurtenances are to be installed at grade,
screening must be installed to minimize the visibility of the facility.
Screening must be installed at least three feet from the equipment installed
at-grade and eight feet from a roadway.



      (5)   Height. The top of the highest point of the antenna
cannot extend more than ten feet, or 10% of the existing height, whichever is
greater, above the highest point of the utility pole, alternative antenna
support structure, tower or city-owned infrastructure. If necessary, the
replacement or new utility pole, alternative support structure or city-owned
infrastructure located within the public right-of-way may be no more than ten
feet or 10% of the average, whichever is greater, higher than the average
height of existing utility poles or city-owned infrastructure located within
300 feet of the proposed location.



      (6)   Color. A telecommunication facility, including all
related equipment and appurtenances, must be a color that blends with the
surroundings of the pole, structure tower or infrastructure on which it is
mounted and use non-reflective materials which blend with the materials and
colors of the surrounding area and structures. Any wiring must be covered
with an appropriate cover.



      (7)   Antenna panel covering. An antenna may include a radome,
cap or other antenna panel covering or shield, to the extent such covering
would not result in a larger or more noticeable facility and, if proposed,
such covering must be of a color that blends with the color of the pole,
structure, tower or infrastructure on which it is mounted.



      (8)   Wiring and cabling. Wires and cables connecting the
antenna to the remainder of the facility must be installed in accordance with
the electrical code currently in effect. No wiring and cabling serving the
facility will be allowed to interfere with any wiring or cabling installed by
a cable television or video service operator, electric utility or telephone
utility.



      (9)   Grounding. The telecommunication facility must be
grounded in accordance with the requirements of the electrical code currently
in effect in the city.



      (10)   Guy wires. No guy or other support wires will be used
in connection with a telecommunication facility unless the facility is to be
attached to an existing utility pole, alternative antenna support structure,
tower or city-owned infrastructure that incorporated guy wires prior to the
date that an applicant has applied for a permit.



      (11)   Pole extensions. Extensions to utility poles,
alternative support structures, towers and city-owned infrastructure utilized
for the purpose of connecting an antenna and its related telecommunications
equipment must have a degree of strength capable of supporting the antenna
and any related appurtenances and cabling and capable of withstanding wind
forces and ice loads in accordance with the applicable structural integrity
standards. An extension must be securely bound to the utility pole,
alternative antenna structure, tower or city-owned infrastructure in
accordance with applicable engineering standards for the design and
attachment of such extensions.



      (12)   Structural integrity. The telecommunication facility,
including the antenna, pole extension and all related equipment must be
designed to withstand a wind force and ice loads in accordance with
applicable standards. For any facility attached to city-owned infrastructure
or, in the discretion of the city, for a utility pole, tower, or alternative
antenna structure, the operator of the facility must provide the city with a
structural evaluation of each specific location containing a certification
that the proposed installation passes the applicable standards. The
evaluation must be prepared by a professional structural engineer licensed in
the State of Illinois.



   (G)   Signage. Other than signs required by federal law or
regulations or identification and location markings, installation of signs on
a telecommunication facility is prohibited.



   (H)   Screening. If screening is required under division (F)(4)
above, it must be natural landscaping material or a fence subject to the
approval of the city and must comply with all regulations of the city.
Appropriate landscaping must be located and maintained and must provide the
maximum achievable screening, as determined by the city, from view of
adjoining properties and public or private streets. Notwithstanding the
foregoing, no such screening is required to extend more than one foot higher
than the top of any ground mounted equipment. Landscape screening when
permitted in the right-of-way must be provided with a clearance of three feet
in all directions from the facility. The color of housing for ground-mounted
equipment must blend with the surroundings. For a covered structure, the
maximum reasonably achievable screening must be provided between such
facility and the view from adjoining properties and public or private streets.



   (I)   Permission to use utility pole or alterative antenna
structure. The operator of a telecommunication facility must submit to the
city written copies of the approval from the owner of a utility pole,
monopole, or an alternative antenna structure, to mount the telecommunication
facility on that specific pole, tower, or structure, prior to issuance of the
city permit.



   (J)   Licenses and permits. The operator of a telecommunication
facility must verify to the city that all concurrent licenses and permits
required by other agencies and governments with jurisdiction over the design,
construction, location and operation of said facility have been obtained and
will be maintained within the corporate limits of the city.



   (K)   Abandonment and removal. Any telecommunication facility
located within the corporate limits of the city that is not operated for a
continuous period of 12 months, shall be considered abandoned and the owner
of the facility must remove same within 90 days of receipt of written notice
from the city notifying the owner of such abandonment. Such notice shall be
sent by certified or registered mail, return-receipt-requested, by the city
to such owner at the last known address of such owner. In the case of
telecommunication facilities attached to city-owned infrastructure, if such
facility is not removed within 90 days of such notice, the city may remove or
cause the removal of such facility through the terms of the applicable
license agreement or through whatever actions are provided by law for removal
and cost recovery.



(Ord. O-17-13, passed 4-11-2017)



§ 92.46  VARIANCES.



   (A)   Each location of a telecommunication facility within a
right-of-way must meet all of the requirements described in § 92.45, unless
a variance has been obtained in accordance with the following procedures set
forth in this section.



   (B)   Request for variance. An applicant requesting a variance from
one or more of the provisions of this subchapter must do so in writing to the
City Administrator as a part of the permit application. The request shall
identify each provision of this subchapter from which a variance is requested
and the reasons why a variance should be granted.



   (C)   Authority to grant variances. The City Administrator shall
decide whether a variance is authorized for each provision of this subchapter
identified in the variance request on an individual basis.



   (D)   Conditions for granting of variance. The City Administrator
may authorize a variance only if the applicant requesting the variance has
demonstrated that:



      (1)    One or more conditions not under the control of the
applicant (such as terrain features or an irregular right-of-way line) create
a special hardship that would make enforcement of the provision unreasonable,
given the public purposes to be achieved by the provision; or



      (2)   The degree of variance requested is the least intrusive
means necessary to close a significant coverage or capacity gap in the
applicant's services; and



      (3)   All other designs, methods, materials, locations or
facilities that would conform with the provision from which a variance is
requested are impracticable in relation to the requested approach.



   (E)   Additional conditions for granting of a variance. As a
condition for authorizing a variance, the City Administrator may require the
applicant requesting the variance to meet reasonable standards and conditions
that may or may not be expressly contained within this subchapter, but which
carry out the purposes of this subchapter.



   (F)   Right to appeal. Any applicant aggrieved by any order,
requirement, decision or determination, including denial of a variance, made
by the City Administrator under the provisions of this subchapter shall have
the right to appeal to the City Council, or such other board or commission as
it may designate. The application for appeal shall be submitted in writing to
the City Clerk within 30 days after the date of such order, requirement,
decision or determination. The City Council shall commence its consideration
of the appeal at the Council's next regularly scheduled meeting occurring at
least seven  days after the filing of the appeal. The City Council shall
timely decide the appeal.



(Ord. O-17-13, passed 4-11-2017)



§ 92.47  PERMITS AND APPLICATION FEES AND PROCEDURES.



   Permits for placement of telecommunication facilities in right-of-way
within the city are required. Any application must demonstrate compliance
with the requirements of this subchapter. Unless otherwise provided by
franchise, license, or similar agreement, or federal, state or local law, all
applications for permits pursuant to this section must be accompanied by a
fee in the amount of no less than $500. The application fee will reimburse
the city for regulatory and administrative costs with respect to the work
being performed.



(Ord. O-17-13, passed 4-11-2017)



§ 92.48  CONFLICT OF LAWS.



   Where the conditions imposed by any provisions of this subchapter
regarding the siting and installation of telecommunication facilities are
more restrictive than comparable conditions imposed elsewhere in any other
local law, ordinance, resolution, rule or regulation, the regulations of this
subchapter will govern.



(Ord. O-17-13, passed 4-11-2017)




SNOW




§ 92.55  DUTY TO CLEAR SIDEWALK.



   (A)   It shall be the duty of the owner and the occupant of all
premises abutting any sidewalk in the city to keep the sidewalk, in front of
or along the same, free from snow or other obstruction. Sidewalks shall be
cleared within  24 hours of the accumulation of one inch of snow or other
deposits on the sidewalk and within 24 hours of the conclusion of  a snow
event. With regard to the owners and occupants of corner lots which abut
sidewalks which include ramps to the street, it shall be the duty of the
owner and occupant to keep the ramps free from snow or other obstruction
within the same time frame as well. This duty shall include all owners and
occupants of business premises, regardless of hours of operation. In the
event that the person or persons responsible for the snow removal pursuant to
this section fails to do so, such person or persons shall be subject to the
penalties set forth in § 92.99(E).  In addition, the city may in its
discretion give notice to the property owner by mail or signage posted on the
property, cause the snow to be cleared by its employees or outside
contractors and charge a fee for such service to the owner of the property
abutting the sidewalk.  The city may also choose to clear, without charge,
those sidewalks where the City Council determines such clearing to be useful
or necessary and in the interest of commerce or transportation.  The
determination of City Council shall be resolution identifying the adjoining
parcels by their PIN numbers.  Where a charge is imposed by the city, the
charge by the city for clearing snow from a sidewalk or ramp shall be the
actual cost incurred for clearing the snow, whether that is by city employees
or contracted by another party, plus $125 administrative fee.  Each day that
snow or other obstruction shall remain on the sidewalk after the initial
24-hour period shall constitute a separate offense.



   (B)   Lien for failure to pay snow removal charge.  If snow is
removed off the sidewalk by the city, or by someone directed by the city, and
a charge is imposed by the city for such service, the charges shall be
itemized on an invoice and mailed to the owner of the relevant property. 
The invoice shall be paid within ten days of the date of mailing. If the
charges are not paid to the city within ten days after the date on which the
invoice was mailed, then the city shall serve, by mail, a notice of lien for
the invoiced amount upon the property owner and the city may record the lien
in the office of the Recorder of Deeds. The notice or lien shall be filed
within 60 days after the cost and expense is incurred, and shall consist of a
sworn statement setting out:



      (1)   The legal description of the real estate sufficient for
identification thereof;



      (2)   The amount of money representing the cost and expense
incurred or payable for the service; and



      (3)   The date or dates when the cost and expense were
incurred by the city.



   (C)   Upon payment of the cost and expense after notice of lien has
been filed, the city shall release the lien and the release shall be filed of
record in the same manner as filing notice of the lien. The City
Administrator or the Director of Public Works is each authorized to execute
the release of lien on behalf of the city without further action of the City
Council.



(Prior Code, § 7-5-1) (Ord. O-14-101, passed 3-11-2014; Ord. O-15-151,
passed 11-10-2015; Ord. O-16-187, passed 12-13-2016)  Penalty, see § 92.99



§ 92.56  PLACEMENT OF CLEARED SNOW.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for the owner or occupant of any premises
to cause snow from that premises to be placed onto any city street, alley, or
other right-of-way which has been plowed.



   (B)   This section does not apply to snow removed from sidewalks in
front of commercial properties in the downtown business district on State
Street, from Second Street to Brown Street, on Second Street, from Oakwood
Avenue to Center Street, on First Street, from Oakwood Avenue to College
Avenue, on Exchange Street, from Oakwood Avenue to Center Street, and on
Orange Street, from Oakwood Avenue to State Street.



(Prior Code, § 7-5-2)  Penalty, see § 92.99



§ 92.57  PARKING RESTRICTIONS DUE TO SNOWFALL.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle on any public street
in the city at any time within 12 hours after a snowfall of three inches or
more has occurred, unless the snow has been plowed off or otherwise removed
from the street.



   (B)   Whenever the Mayor, City Administrator or Chief of Police
perceives an emergency to exist in the city, or in any section(s) thereof,
because of snow, freezing rain, sleet, ice, drifting snow, or other
precipitation or natural phenomena which create hazardous conditions or
impede the free movement of fire, police, ambulance, emergency or other
vehicular traffic or otherwise endanger the safety and welfare of the public,
the Mayor, City Administrator or Chief of Police may declare an emergency to
exist and the period during which said emergency shall exist.  If no
duration is expressly stated, the duration of the emergency shall be twenty
four hours from the time of the declaration.



   (C)   Primary notification will be made by sending notice of such
emergency and duration thereof to the local media with a request to broadcast
the emergency declaration.



   (D)   It shall be unlawful for any person to place or permit to
stand any vehicle for a period of more than ten minutes for the loading or
unloading of passengers or materials on any public street or right of way
within the city during an emergency as declared pursuant to division (B)
above.



(Prior Code, § 7-5-3) (Am. Ord. O-15-152, passed 12-8-15)  Penalty, see §
92.99



§ 92.58  REMOVAL OF VEHICLE; CHARGE.



   The police officers of the city are hereby required and empowered to
remove from any streets, any vehicle found standing thereon in violation of
any provision of this chapter where the position in which the vehicle is
standing blocks or materially inconveniences the removal of snow therefrom,
or the movement of traffic or pedestrians thereon. In the event any vehicle
is so removed, the reasonable expense of the removal shall be taxed as part
of the costs, in addition to any penalty either voluntarily paid or assessed
by the court as provided by law.



(Prior Code, § 7-5-4)  (Am. Ord. O-15-152, passed 12-8-15)



§ 92.99  PENALTY.



   (A)   Any person violating any provision of this chapter for which
no specific penalty is prescribed shall be subject to § 10.99.



   (B)   Any person placing a number, or permitting a number to remain
upon any building, other than the number designated in accordance with the
provisions of §§ 92.01 through 92.06 or in any other manner than as herein
provided, shall be required to remove the number, and shall be subject to a
fine of not less than $10 nor more than $750 for each offense, and a separate
offense shall be deemed to be committed for each and every day during which a
violation continues or exists.



(Prior Code, § 1-7-6)



   (C)   Any person, firm, or corporation violating § 92.21 of this
chapter shall be fined not less than $25 nor more than $750 for each offense,
and a separate offense shall be deemed committed for each and every day
during which a violation continues or exists.



(Prior Code, § 1-8-5)



   (D)   (1)   Any person, firm, or corporation who has commenced
work prior to the issuance of a permit as required in § 92.35 of this
chapter shall be in violation, and justly cause the Public Service
Superintendent to issue a stop order. Prior to the removal of the stop order,
a permit must be issued in accordance to the provisions of this chapter.



      (2)   Any person, firm, or corporation who has completed the
work required by this chapter without being issued a permit shall be in
violation, and shall be fined not less than $25 nor more than $500 for each
day during or on which a violation occurs or continues.



      (3)   Any person, firm, or corporation violating any provision
of §§ 92.35 through 92.41 of this chapter shall be fined not less than $25
nor more than $750 for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed
committed upon each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues.



(Prior Code, § 4-7-8)



   (E)   (1)   Any violations of the provisions of § 92.55 shall be
punishable by a minimum fine of $25 and a maximum fine of $750, and further
be subject to abatement of the nuisance as therein provided.



      (2)    In the event that a person is charged with a violation
of § 92.55 under an ordinance violation notice as a first-time offender, the
person may satisfy the penalty by paying the $25 fine in person or by mail
within five days of being charged with the violation.  All penalties shall
be paid at the Police Department.



(Prior Code, § 7-5-5) (Ord. O-14-101, passed 3-11-2014)

CHAPTER 93:  HEALTH AND SANITATION



Section




Nuisances




   93.01   Declaration of nuisances



   93.02   Burning



   93.03   Animals in cemeteries prohibited



   93.04   Notice to abate nuisance

   93.15   Definitions

   93.17   Notice to cut weeds and grass

   93.99   Penalty




NUISANCES




§ 93.01  DECLARATION OF NUISANCES.



   The following shall be declared as public nuisances:



   (A)   To cause or suffer the carcass of any animal or any offal,
filth, or noisome substance to be collected, deposited, or to remain in any
public place to the prejudice of others;



   (B)   To throw or deposit any offal or other offensive matter or the
carcass of any dead animal in any public place, common sewer, street, or
public highway;



   (C)   To obstruct access to, or encroach upon, public highways,
sidewalks, private ways, streets, alleys, commons, or any public place, or to
plant any tree upon the public right-of-way without written permission from
the Public Service Superintendent. For the purpose of this section, OBSTRUCT
encompasses, but shall not necessarily be limited to, one or more of the
following:



      (1)   Obstruction of the free unhampered passage of
pedestrians or vehicles;



      (2)   Obstruction, molesting, or interfering with any person
lawfully upon any public highways, sidewalks, private ways, streets, alleys,
commons, or any public place;



      (3)   Obstructing or otherwise interfering with the free
passage of persons entering or occupying buildings or premises;



      (4)   Engaging in any activity which tends to provoke a breach
of peace; and/or



      (5)   Refusing to move on when so requested by a peace
officer, provided that the peace officer has exercised his or her discretion
reasonably under the circumstances in order to preserve or promote public
peace and order. For the purpose of this section, PUBLIC PLACE includes the
quasi-public area in front of or adjacent to any store, shop, restaurant,
luncheonette, or other place of business, and also includes parking lots or
other vacant property not owned or under the control of the person charged
with a violation of this section.



   (D)   To erect, construct, or maintain poles, wires, conduits,
cables, gas, water pipes or mains, or any other obstruction for the
transmission of electric current, natural or artificial gas in, upon, along,
or under any of the streets, alleys, avenues, or other public places without
a license from the city for such purpose;



   (E)   To permit to remain in, upon, along, or under the streets,
alleys, avenues, or other public places any poles, wires, conduits, cables,
gas, water pipes or mains after the expiration of any license granted for
such purpose and after ten day’s notice from the city to remove any poles,
wires, conduits, cables, gas, or water pipes or mains;



   (F)   To construct, erect, repair, or maintain any poles, wires,
conduits, cables, gas, or water pipes or mains without a written permit from
the city;



   (G)   To obstruct or injure, or cause to be obstructed or injured,
any street, alley, sidewalk, crosswalk, bridge, or causeway or continue an
obstruction so as to render the same inconvenient or dangerous to pass, or to
pollute or obstruct any water course or common sewer or continue the
obstruction or pollution so as to render the same offensive or unwholesome,
or to maintain or carry on any establishment for steaming or rendering lard,
tallow, offal, and other substances as may be rendered, or to maintain and
carry on any slaughtering establishment without first having obtained a
permit from the City Council to carry on a slaughtering establishment in an
offensive or unwholesome manner, or to erect or establish any offensive,
nauseous, or unwholesome trade or manufacture or business or continue the
same after it has been erected or established, within the corporate limits of
the city or within one mile of the corporate limits;



   (H)   To make or maintain any connection of roof downspouts,
foundation drains, driveway drains, garage drains, sump pumps or other
sources of surface water, ground water, storm water, roof runoff or
subsurface drainage to a building sewer or lateral sewer which is connected
directly or indirectly to a public sanitary sewer;



   (I)   To direct or redirect water as described in division (H)
above, so that it shall routinely pond or freeze on sidewalks, streets, or
alleys in such a manner as will cause a public safety hazard;



   (J)   To discharge sump pump discharge water in such a manner as to
cause accumulation of water or ice to remain on sidewalks, streets, or
alleys. If the accumulation is determined to be a public safety hazard by the
city, the property owner and tenant, if different from the owner, shall be
given notice that the sump pump discharge is in apparent violation of this
section. The property owner and tenant shall thereafter have 60 days to
either redirect the water flow or to connect the sump pump discharge to the
city’s storm sewer system when the city has placed a storm sewer or sump
pump collection system adjacent to the property. Connection to the city’s
storm sewer or sump pump collection system shall be done to the
specifications and standards for the connection as set forth by the city’s
Public Service Superintendent;



   (K)   To shoot any air gun, air rifle, BB gun, air pump gun, BB pump
gun, paint ball gun, or any other similar device, or any sling shot, upon the
streets, alleys, parks, or other public places, or if so shooting such
implements that the missiles propelled thereby will or may pass over or onto
any street, alley, park, or public place;



   (L)   To burn trash, garbage, refuse or materials other than
combustible yard waste. The owner of any engine, whether locomotive or
stationary, and the person employed as engineer or otherwise in the operation
of the engine, and the proprietor, lessee, and occupant of any building who
shall permit dense smoke to issue or be emitted from the smoke stack of any
engine or the chimney or smoke stack of a building, shall be deemed and held
guilty of creating a public nuisance;



   (M)   To feed, house, or keep hogs in any pen, enclosure, or place
which is less than 350 feet from any residence. Any feeding or keeping of a
hog or hogs in any such place is hereby declared to be a nuisance; and



   (N)   To cause or permit the accumulation of any amount of junk
within any property in any district of the city other than
“agriculture”.  JUNK shall include waste paper, rags, scrap metal or
other discarded material, unused furniture, appliances or machinery (or parts
thereof) not in operating condition.



(Prior Code, § 7-1-1) (Am. Ord. 1970, passed 5-11-2010; Am. Ord. O-13-088,
passed 6-11-2013)   Penalty, see § 93.99



§ 93.02  BURNING.



   (A)   Prohibition and definition.



      (1)   Burning of fallen leaves, cut weeds, grass clippings is
prohibited within the city limits at any given time or location.



      (2)   Other fires are permitted subject to the following terms
and conditions:



         (a)   The dimensions of the pit or fire container shall
not exceed three feet in diameter and two feet in height.



         (b)   No fire shall be conducted within 25 feet of a
structure or combustible materials.



         (c)   The length of time any fire shall be permitted to
burn shall not exceed four hours total in any 24-hour time period.



         (d)   All fires must be attended at all times with a
means of extinguishment readily available.



         (e)   No fire shall cause excessive or unreasonable
smoke or odor to carry over onto the property of other persons so as to
create a nuisance.



      (3)   (a)   Owners of real estate zoned Agriculture (A)
Districts within the city limits may request an exemption from the burn
prohibitions of this section.  In order to obtain such an exemption, the
owners shall apply in writing to the city, which shall cause an inspection of
the property to be made by the Zoning Officer and a report made to the Zoning
Board of Appeals.  This report shall include all relevant factors, including
but not limited to:



            1.   The size and area of the property.



            2.   The location of the property in relation to
residential or business properties which could be affected by burning thereon.



            3.   The area set aside on the property for
burning.



         (b)   The Zoning Board of Appeals shall hold a public
hearing on the application. Notice of the hearing shall be sent to all owners
of real estate within 250 feet not less than 15 nor more than 30 days of the
hearing. At the hearing, the Zoning Board of Appeals shall consider the
report of the Zoning Officer and all other relevant evidence, and shall
recommend approval or denial of the application to the City Council at its
next meeting scheduled after the public hearing.



         (c)   In the case of newly annexed agriculture-zoned
property, an exemption from the prohibitions of this section may be contained
in the terms of an annexation agreement, and shall be subject to hearing and
approval in the manner set forth in ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, § 11-15.1, and as
that statute may be thereafter amended.



         (d)   All permits shall contain provisions regarding the
location on the real estate where burning may occur, size of the burning
area, type of container (if any) to be used and number of fires per month
(from one to unlimited). These provisions shall be established by the Zoning
Board of Appeals upon approval of the permit.



         (e)   Any permit issued pursuant to this subsection
shall run with the land for which it is issued. Such permit may be subject to
review, modification, suspension or termination in the event that any of the
circumstances upon which it was issued had changed. Before any modification,
suspension or termination of a permit takes place, the issue shall be set for
hearing before the Zoning Board of Appeals. Notice of the hearing date shall
be sent to the owners of the real estate subject to the permit and the owners
of all real estate within 250 feet, not less than 15 days nor more than 30
days. The Zoning Board of Appeals shall consider all relevant evidence and
testimony at such hearing and render a decision on this issue.



   (B)   Police enforcement.



      (1)   Police officers are hereby authorized to cause a fire to
be extinguished whenever they may determine the burning of fallen leaves, cut
weeds, grass clippings leaves or use of bonfires or recreational fires in
violation of this section.



      (2)   The foregoing immediate action of the police shall not
in any manner restrict or prohibit the prosecution of an ordinance violation
complaint in any such case.



      (3)   Police officers are hereby authorized to cause fires
which are in violation of these provisions to be extinguished.  In assessing
whether a fire is a nuisance pursuant to division (A)(2)(e) above, the police
may consider any applicable factor, including weather conditions, wind, time
of day, etc.



(Prior Code, § 7-1-4)  (Ord. 1932, passed 3-10-2009; Ord. 1962, passed
2-9-2010; Ord. O-12-032, passed 3-13-2012)  Penalty, see § 93.99



§ 93.03  ANIMALS IN CEMETERIES PROHIBITED.



   Any cemetery located within the city limits is hereby held to be a
place of reverence and respect for the deceased persons buried therein, and
the persons who visit their grave sites.  It is therefore declared to be a
public nuisance to permit any dog, cat, or other domestic animal, owned by or
under the control of any person, to be on any portion of the cemetery
grounds. This provision shall apply regardless of whether the animal shall be
restrained by a leash or any other method.



(Prior Code, § 7-1-5)  Penalty, see § 93.99



§ 93.04  NOTICE TO ABATE NUISANCE.



   Notice shall be given ten days before the abatement or commencement of
any action of any nuisance, and may be given in writing to any person
maintaining any nuisance, by the Mayor, City Clerk, or Public Service
Superintendent.



(Prior Code, § 7-1-6)



WEEDS AND GRASS



§ 93.15  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   GRASS. Any plant having jointed stems and blade-like leaves of the type
generally cultivated for lawns.



   WEEDS.  Any plant that is useless, injurious, or unsightly, or
established in an area that impedes normal visual needs for pedestrian and
vehicle traffic, including the following: blue vervain, burdock, cockelbur,
common mile weed, curled dock, horseweed, jimpson weed, lambs quarter,
milkweed (common), nettles, poison hemlock, poison ivy, poison oak, ragweed
(common), ragweed (giant), rough pigweed, smart weeds (all varieties),
thistle, wild carrot, wild hemp, wild lettuce, and wild mustard.



(Prior Code, § 7-4-1)  (Ord. O-13-075, passed 3-12-2013)



§ 93.16  CUTTING OF WEEDS AND GRASS REQUIRED.



   It is declared to be illegal for the owner of real estate to refuse or
neglect to cut weeds and grass when such plants have reached a height in
excess of eight inches. Every owner of real estate within the city shall cut
weeds and grass on his or her property at all times as may be necessary so
that such plants shall not exceed eight inches in height, and, if the owner
neglects or refuses to cut weeds and grass so that they do not exceed eight
inches in height, the city may cut the weeds or grass or authorize some
person to cut them on behalf of the city.



(Prior Code, § 7-4-2)  (Ord. O-13-075, passed 3-12-2013; Ord. O-15-145,
passed 6-9-2015) Penalty, see § 93.99



§ 93.17  NOTICE TO CUT WEEDS AND GRASS.



   The city shall give notice in writing to at least one of the owners of
real estate before cutting the weeds and grass thereon. The notice shall
state the date on or after which the city will cut the weeds and grass if not
cut by the owner and the potential penalties for non-compliance. The notice
shall be acceptable if a door hangar is hung on the front door of the
property and a letter sent via regular mail.  The owner or his or her
designee will have 72 hours from the time the door hangar was hung to have
the weeds and grass cut.



(Prior Code, § 7-4-3)  (Ord. O-13-075, passed 3-12-2013; Ord. O-15-145,
passed 6-9-2015)



§ 93.18  CHARGE FOR WEED AND GRASS CUTTING BY CITY.



   The charge by the city for cutting weeds shall be the actual cost
incurred for mowing property, whether that be by city employees or contracted
by another party, plus $125 administrative fee. In addition, the owners of
the real estate may be fined as provided in § 93.99.



(Prior Code, § 7-4-4)  (Ord. O-13-075, passed 3-12-2013)



§ 93.19  LIEN FOR FAILURE TO PAY CUTTING CHARGE.



   (A)   If weeds and grass are cut by the city, or by someone directed
to cut them on behalf of the city, and if the charge therefore is not paid to
the city within ten days after the completion of the work, a notice of lien
of the cost and expense thereof incurred by the city shall be recorded by the
city, or the person performing the service by authority of the city, in its
or his or her own name, in the office of the Recorder of Deeds in the county.
The notice of lien shall be filed within 60 days after the cost and expense
is incurred, and shall consist of a sworn statement setting out:



      (1)   The description of the real estate sufficient for
identification thereof;



      (2)   The amount of money representing the cost and expense
incurred or payable for the service; and



      (3)   The date or dates when the cost and expense were
incurred by the city.



   (B)   Upon payment of the cost and expense after notice of lien has
been filed, the lien shall be released by the city or person in whose name
the lien has been filed, and the release shall be filed of record in the same
manner as filing notice of the lien.



(Prior Code, § 7-4-5)  (Ord. O-13-075, passed 3-12-2013)



§ 93.20  PROHIBITING GRASS AND WEED CLIPPINGS ON PUBLIC RIGHT-OF-WAYS.



   It is declared illegal for an owner or occupant of any real estate in
the city to cause or allow cut grass and weed clippings to be deposited and
remain for any period of time upon any street, roadway or sidewalk within the
city.



(Ord. O-13-075, passed 3-12-2013)



§ 93.99  PENALTY.



   (A)   (1)   Any violations of the provisions of § 93.01 shall be
punishable by a minimum fine of $25 and a maximum fine of $750, and further
be subject to abatement of the nuisance. In the event a person violates §§
93.01 through 93.04 a second or subsequent time, the minimum fine shall be
$50.



      (2)   In the event that a person is charged with a violation
of § 93.01 under an ordinance violation notice as a first-time offender, the
person may satisfy the penalty by paying the $25 fine in person or by mail
within five days of being charged with the violation. All penalties shall be
paid at the Police Department.



(Prior Code, § 7-1-1)



   (B)   (1)   Any person who violates the provisions of § 93.02
shall be subject to a fine not less than $25 nor more than $750, and further
be subject to abatement of the nuisance. In the event a person violates this
section a second or subsequent time, the minimum fine shall be $50.



      (2)  In the event that a person is charged with a violation of
§ 93.02 under an ordinance violation notice as a first-time offender, the
person may satisfy the penalty by paying the $25 fine in person or by mail
within five days of being charged with the violation. All penalties shall be
paid at the Police Department.



(Prior Code, § 7-1-4)



   (C)   Any public nuisance as set forth above in § 93.03 is hereby
prohibited. Any violations of the provisions of § 93.03 shall be punishable
by a minimum fine of $25 and a maximum fine of $750. In the event of a second
or subsequent violation, the minimum fine shall be $50. A first time offender
may satisfy the penalty by paying the $25 fine in person or by mail within
five days of being charged with the violation, at the Police Department.



(Prior Code, § 7-1-5)



   (D)   Any person who violates the provisions of §§ 93.15 through
93.19 shall be subject to a fine of not less than $25 and not more than $750.



(Prior Code, § 7-4-6)



(Ord. 1932, passed 3-10-2009)



CHAPTER 94:  CITY PARKS



Section



   94.01   Hours of operation



   94.02   Unlawful conduct



   94.03   Exceptions



 



   94.99   Penalty



§ 94.01  HOURS OF OPERATION.



   All city parks, being those areas which are now, or which hereafter may
be, owned and operated by the city for public park purposes, shall be open to
the public only in accordance with the following schedule:  Monday, Tuesday,
Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, Saturday, and Sunday  -  Hours: Sunrise until
10:00 p.m.



(Prior Code, § 6-8-1)



§ 94.02  UNLAWFUL CONDUCT.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to occupy or be
present in any city park at any time during which the park is not open to the
public, except as provided hereafter in § 94.03.



(Prior Code, § 6-8-2)



   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to operate any
motor vehicle, minibike, or motorcycle in any city park at any time, except
as provided hereafter in § 94.03.



(Prior Code, § 6-8-3)



Penalty, see § 94.99



§ 94.03  EXCEPTIONS.



   (A)   It is not hereby made unlawful for any person to walk through
any city park at any time in an otherwise lawful manner on public sidewalks
there provided.



   (B)   It is not hereby made unlawful for any person to be present in
any park during hours when the park is not open to the public, if the person
is attending or participating in any party, entertainment, theatrical
performance, picnic, dance, or similar event being conducted by an
organization, association, or family group, provided the event has been
scheduled in advance on the list maintained for that purpose in the office of
the City Clerk.



   (C)   It is not hereby made unlawful for any person who is employed
by the city to perform police or custodial functions to be present in any
city park or cemetery at any time.



   (D)   It is not hereby made unlawful for any person authorized by
the Public Service Superintendent to operate an authorized motor vehicle in
any city park at any time in a lawful manner.



(Prior Code, § 6-8-4)



§ 94.99  PENALTY.



   Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be fined not
less than $25 nor more than $750.



(Prior Code, § 6-8-5)



CHAPTER 95:  CITY CEMETERIES



Section



   95.01   Rates and hours of operation



   95.02   Unlawful conduct



 



   95.99   Penalty



§ 95.01  RATES AND HOURS OF OPERATION.



   (A)   The city cemeteries, known as North Cemetery and Oakwood
Cemetery, shall be open to the public only between the time of sunrise and
the time of sunset each day of the week.



      (1)   Grave openings:



         (a)   Regular size:



            1.   Monday through Friday: $850.



            2.   Saturday until noon: $1,050.



            3.   Saturday afternoon: $1,250.



            4.   Sunday: $1,500.



         (b)   Small (less than two feet by two feet):



            1.   Monday through Friday: $400.



            2.   Saturday until noon: $500.



            3.   Saturday afternoon: $600.



            4.   Sunday: $850.



      (2)   Disinterment: $850.



      (3)   Lots: $400.



   (C)   Oakwood Cemetery rates shall be:



      (1)   Grave openings:



         (a)   Regular size:



            1.   Monday through Friday: $850.



            2.   Saturday until noon: $1,050.



            3.   Saturday afternoon: $1.250.



            4.   Sunday: $1,500.



         (b)   Small (less than two feet by two feet):



            1.   Monday through Friday: $400.



            2.   Saturday until noon: $500.



            3.   Saturday afternoon: $600.



            4.   Sunday: $850.



      (2)   Disinterment: $850.



      (3)   Lots: $500.



   (D)   No funerals shall be held or scheduled for holidays.



   (E)   Grave side services or funeral services in either North
Cemetery or Oakwood Cemetery which commence after 3:00 p.m. will be assessed
a minimum one-half hour surcharge of $50, and $50 per each additional
one-half hour subsequently exceeding the aforementioned times until the
conclusion of the service.



 



   (F)   A $50 fee will be charged to transfer deeds of plot.



(Prior Code, § 6-9-1)  (Ord. 1931, passed 2-10-2009; Ord. 1980, passed
12-14-2010)



§ 95.02  UNLAWFUL CONDUCT.



   It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to occupy or be present
in any city cemetery at any time during which the cemetery is not open to the
public.



(Prior Code, § 6-9-2)  Penalty, see § 95.99



§ 95.99  PENALTY.



   Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be fined not
less than $25 nor more than $750.



(Prior Code, § 6-9-3)



CHAPTER 96:  AIRCRAFT



Section



   96.01   Definitions



   96.02   Unlawful operation



 



   96.99   Penalty



§ 96.01  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   AIRCRAFT.  Any contrivance now known or hereafter invented or designed
for navigation of or flight in the air.



   LAND.  Real property and all improvements thereto, and water forming a
part of any real property.



   OPERATOR.  Any person who controls the flight, including landing and
takeoffs, of an aircraft, including the pilot and/or navigator thereof.



(Prior Code, § 8-6-1)



§ 96.02  UNLAWFUL OPERATION.



   It shall be unlawful for the operator of any aircraft to land or take
off the aircraft from any land within the city limits, except a landing as
had been authorized for landings and takeoffs in compliance with the City
Zoning Ordinance and any regulations imposed thereunder.



(Prior Code, § 8-6-2)  Penalty, see § 96.99



§ 96.99  PENALTY.



   Any person who violates § 96.02 of this chapter shall be subject to a
fine of not less than $100, nor greater than $750 for each violation.



(Prior Code, § 8-6-3)
