CHAPTER 113:  SOLICITORS, HAWKERS, AND PEDDLERS



Section



   113.01   Definitions



   113.02   Certificate of registration required



   113.03   Application for certificate of registration



   113.04   Revocation of certificate



   113.05   Registration fee



   113.06   Occupant notice regarding soliciting



   113.07   Uninvited soliciting prohibited



   113.08   Duty of solicitor to observe occupant notice



   113.09   Hours when soliciting permissible



   113.10   Restriction on peddling in public



   113.11   Creating hazard prohibited



§ 113.01  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   HAWKER.  A hawker is a solicitor who seeks to sell or obtain orders
for property, as set forth in this section, who conducts his or her business
from one or more specified locations specifically advertised or held out for
the purpose of the business.



   ITINERANT VENDORS.  Any person who transports tangible personal
property for retail sale within the city who does not maintain in this city
an established office, distribution house, in-sales house, warehouse, service
center, or residence from which the business is conducted. However, this
chapter does not apply to any person who delivers tangible personal property
within this city who is fulfilling an order for the property which was
solicited or placed by mail or other means.



   PEDDLER.  A solicitor who seeks to sell or obtain orders for property,
as set forth in this section, who travels to the location of the prospective
customer in order to conduct his or her business.



   REGISTERED SOLICITOR.  Any person who has obtained a valid certificate
of registration as hereinafter provided, which certificate is in the
possession of the solicitor on his or her person while engaged in soliciting.



   RESIDENCE.  Every separate living unit occupied for residential
purposes by one or more persons contained within any type of building or
structure.



   SOLICITING.  Any one or more of the following activities:



      (1)   Seeking to sell or obtain orders for the purchase of
goods, wares, merchandise, foodstuffs, services of any kind, character, or
description whatever for any kind of consideration whatever;



      (2)   Seeking to obtain subscriptions to books, magazines,
periodicals, newspapers, and every other type or kind of publication; or



      (3)   Seeking to obtain gifts or contributions of money,
clothing, or any other valuable thing for the support or benefit of any
charitable or nonprofit association, organization, corporation, or project.



   TRANSIENT MERCHANT.  Any person who is engaged temporarily in the
retail sales of goods, wares, or merchandise in the city and who, for the
purpose of conducting the business, occupies any building, room, vehicle,
structure of any kind, or vacant lot. However, this does not apply to any
person selling goods, wares, or merchandise which are raised, produced, or
manufactured by him or her, to any person selling vegetables, fruits, or
perishable farm products at any established city market, or to any person
operating a stand or booth on or adjacent to property owned by him or her or
upon which he or she resides.



(Prior Code, § 5-6-1)



§ 113.02  CERTIFICATE OF REGISTRATION REQUIRED.



   It shall be unlawful for any person 18 years of age or older, any firm,
or any corporation to engage in soliciting or to engage as a hawker or
peddler or itinerant vendor or transient merchant of any merchandise,
article, thing, or amusement without first having secured certificates of
registration thereof.



(Prior Code, § 5-6-2)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 113.03  APPLICATION FOR CERTIFICATE OF REGISTRATION.



   (A)   Application for a certificate of registration shall be made
upon a form provided by the municipality. The applicant shall truthfully
state in full the information requested on the application, to wit:



      (1)   Name and address of present place of residence, length
of residence at the address, business address if other than present address,
and address of the place of residence during the past three years, if other
than the present residence;



      (2)   Age of applicant;



      (3)   Physical description of the applicant;



      (4)   Name and address of the person, firm, corporation, or
association by whom the applicant is employed or represents, and the length
of time of the employment or representation;



      (5)   Description sufficient for identification of the subject
matter of the soliciting in which the applicant will engage, and the location
or areas in which the solicitation will take place;



      (6)   Period of time for which the certificate is applied;



      (7)   The date or approximate date of the latest previous
application for certificate under this chapter, if any;



      (8)   Has a certificate of registration issued to the
applicant under this chapter ever been revoked;



      (9)   Has the applicant ever been convicted of a violation of
a felony under the laws of the state or any other state or federal law of the
United States;



      (10)   Sales Tax Identification Number;



      (11)   Tax Exemption Number (if any); and



      (12)   Number and kind of vehicles to be used.



   (B)   Each applicant must submit with the application required
certificates and approvals from all county, state and federal regulatory
agencies for the products the applicant is seeking to sell or obtain orders
for.



   (C)   All statements made by the applicant upon the application or
in connection therewith shall be under oath.



   (D)   The Police Department shall cause to be kept in its office an
accurate record of every application received and acted upon, together with
all other information and data pertaining thereto, all certificates of
registration issued under the provisions of this chapter, and all denials of
applications. Applications for certificates shall be numbered in consecutive
order, as filed, and every certificate issued and any renewal thereof shall
be identified with the duplicate number of the application upon which it was
issued. The Chief of Police shall require every applicant to submit to
photographing and fingerprinting by the Police Department in connection with
the application for a certificate. The Chief of Police shall collect a fee
for the cost of fingerprinting and any photo identification, which fee shall
not be more than $36.50. The background check shall be valid for not more
than one year from the time of its receipt.



   (E)   No certificate of registration shall be issued to any person
who has been convicted of the commission of a felony under the laws of the
state or any other state or federal law of the United States within five
years of the date of application, nor to any person who is a registered sex
offender in this or any other state, nor to any person who has been convicted
of a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter, nor to any person
whose certificate of registration issued hereunder has previously been
revoked as herein provided.



   (F)   Application for a license under this chapter shall be made in
writing to the City Clerk at least ten days prior to the time that the
applicant desires to commence such business.



   (G)   The application under this division shall be accompanied by a
bond in the penal sum of $1,000 to the city, such bond to be executed by good
and sufficient sureties to be approved by the City Clerk, and to be
conditioned that all goods, wares and merchandise will be as represented, and
that the purchase price will be refunded on any article sold which is not as
represented and that final delivery of goods ordered will be made in
accordance with the terms of such order, and, failing therein, the advance
payment on such order will be refunded. Any person aggrieved by the action of
any such peddler or itinerant merchant shall have the right of action on the
bond for the money paid or damages, or both.



(Prior Code, § 5-6-3)  (Ord. O-13-072, passed 2-12-2013; Ord. O-13-085,
passed 6-25-2013; Ord. O-14-124, passed 11-11-2014)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 113.04  REVOCATION OF CERTIFICATE.



   (A)   Any certificate of registration issued hereunder shall be
revoked by the Chief of Police if the holder of the certificate is convicted
of a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter, or has made a false
material statement in the application, or otherwise becomes disqualified for
the issuance of a certificate of registration under the terms of this chapter.



   (B)   Immediately upon the revocation, written notice thereof shall
be given by the Chief of Police to the holder of the certificate in person or
by certified United States mail addressed to his or her residence address set
forth in the application.



   (C)   Immediately upon the giving of the notice, the certificate of
registration shall become null and void.



   (D)   The certificate of registration shall state the expiration
date thereof.



(Prior Code, § 5-6-4)



§ 113.05  REGISTRATION FEE.



   (A)   (1)   In general. Each solicitor shall pay to the City
Clerk a registration fee of $50 for the first day and $10 for each day
thereafter. The charge for the daily fee may be extended for a set period of
days and paid at the time of registration but in no event may a solicitor’s
permit be issued for a period of greater than 30 days without renewal.



      (2)   Exemption to solicitor’s license. A solicitor who
represents an agency or business which maintains a physical office, store or
service center within the corporate limits of the city for a term of at least
12 months, shall be exempt from the $10 fee for each day.



   (B)   Each hawker or peddler shall pay to the City Clerk a
registration fee of $50 per day or for any part of a day as reported in the
application.



(Prior Code, § 5-6-6) (Ord. O-14-124, passed 11-11-2014)



§ 113.06  OCCUPANT NOTICE REGARDING SOLICITING.



   (A)   Every person desiring to secure the protection provided by the
regulations pertaining to soliciting contained in this chapter shall comply
with the following directions.



   (B)   Notice of the determination by the occupant of giving
invitation to solicitors or the refusal of invitation to solicitors to any
residence shall be given in the manner following:



      (1)   A weatherproof card approximately three inches by four
inches in size shall be exhibited upon or near the main entrance door to the
residence indicating the determination by the occupant, containing the
applicable words, as follows:



         (a)   “Only Solicitors Registered in Geneseo
Invited”; or



         (b)   “No Solicitors Invited”.



      (2)   The letters shall be at least one-third inch in height.
For the purpose of uniformity, the cards shall be provided by the Chief of
Police to persons requesting, at the cost thereof.



   (C)   The card so exhibited shall constitute sufficient notice to
any solicitor of the determination by the occupant of the residence of the
information contained thereon.



(Prior Code, § 5-6-5)



§ 113.07  UNINVITED SOLICITING PROHIBITED.



   It is hereby declared to be unlawful, and shall constitute a nuisance,
for any person to go upon any premises and ring the door bell upon or near
any door, or create any sound or motion in any other manner calculated to
attract the attention of the occupant of the residence, for the purpose of
securing an audience with the occupant thereof and engage in soliciting as
herein defined in defiance of the notice exhibited at the residence in
accordance with the provisions of § 113.06.



(Prior Code, § 5-6-8)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 113.08  DUTY OF SOLICITOR TO OBSERVE OCCUPANT NOTICE.



   (A)   It shall be the duty of every solicitor upon going on to any
premises in the municipality upon which a residence as herein defined is
located to first examine the notice provided for in this chapter, if any is
attached, and be governed by the statement contained on any notice. If the
notice states “Only Solicitors Registered in Geneseo Invited”, then the
solicitor not possessing a valid certificate of registration as herein
provided shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises and if the
notice states “No Solicitors Invited”, then the solicitor, whether
registered or not, shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises.



   (B)   Any solicitor who has gained entrance to any residence,
whether invited or not, shall immediately and peacefully depart from the
premises when requested to do so by the occupant.



(Prior Code, § 5-6-7)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 113.09  HOURS WHEN SOLICITING PERMISSIBLE.



   It is hereby declared to be unlawful and shall constitute a nuisance
for any person, whether registered under this chapter or not, to go upon any
premises and ring the door bell upon or near any door of a residence located
thereon and engage in soliciting as herein defined prior to 9:00 a.m. or
after 5:30 p.m. of any week day or at any time on a Saturday, Sunday, or on a
state or national holiday.



(Prior Code, § 5-6-9)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 113.10  RESTRICTION ON PEDDLING IN PUBLIC.



   No hawker or peddler shall ply his or her vocation on any street,
sidewalk, park, parkway, or in any other public place or any public
right-of-way unless his or her certificate of registration specifies that
solicitation in public places is permitted thereunder.



(Prior Code, § 5-6-10)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 113.11  CREATING HAZARD PROHIBITED.



   (A)   No hawker or peddler shall be allowed to ply his or her
vocation at any location, whether public or private property, if in so doing
he or she causes, or contributes to the causing, of any hazard to the general
public including, but not limited to, creation of traffic congestion or the
distracting of the operators of motor vehicles from the hazards of the
roadway.



   (B)   (1)   Further, no solicitor, hawker, or peddler shall sell,
or cause to be sold, any firework of any kind, regardless of whether the
firework is permitted by the statutes of the state. This includes, but is not
limited to:



         (a)   Sparklers;



         (b)   Smoke bombs;



         (c)   Snake or glow worm pellets;



         (d)   Party poppers;



         (e)   Booby traps;



         (f)   Snappers;



         (g)   Trick matches; or



         (h)   Cigarette loads.



      (2)   This shall not include toy pistols, canes, toy guns or
other devices in which paper or plastic caps containing twenty-five
hundredths grains or less of explosive compound are used.



(Prior Code, § 5-6-11)  Penalty, see § 10.99



CHAPTER 114:  TOBACCO REGULATIONS



Section



   114.01   License required; warning signs



   114.02   License fee



   114.03   Responsibility for agents and employees



 



   114.99   Penalty



   Appendix A:  License application form



§ 114.01  LICENSE REQUIRED; WARNING SIGNS.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or to have, keep,
or offer for sale, any tobacco, nicotine or similar products, including, but
not limited to, any substance containing tobacco leaf, cigarettes, vapor
cigarettes, electronic cigarettes, cigars, pipe tobacco, snuff, chewing
tobacco or dipping tobacco without first having obtained a license so to do,
signed by the Mayor, countersigned by the City Clerk, and sealed with the
seal of the city, and it shall further be unlawful for any person to sell any
of the articles or any tobacco of any kind to any minor under the age of 18
years.



   (B)   Signs informing the public of the age restrictions provided
herein shall be posted by every licensee at or near every display of tobacco
products and on or upon every vending machine of tobacco or nicotine products
for sale. Each sign shall be plainly visible and shall state:



   "THE SALE OF TOBACCO OR NICOTINE PRODUCTS TO PERSONS UNDER EIGHTEEN
YEARS OF AGE IS PROHIBITED BY LAW".



(Prior Code, § 5-4-1)  (Ord. O-15-132, passed 3-10-2015)  Penalty, see §
114.99



§ 114.02  LICENSE FEE.



   The Mayor and City Clerk are hereby authorized to issue licenses to
sell the tobacco or nicotine products described in § 114.01 to all persons
carrying on any regular mercantile business who shall apply for the same and
shall pay into the treasury an annual license fee that is set by resolution
by the City Council.



(Prior Code, § 5-4-2)  (Ord. O-15-132, passed 3-10-2015)



§ 114.03  RESPONSIBILITY FOR AGENTS AND EMPLOYEES.



   Every act or omission of whatsoever nature, constituting a violation of
any of the provisions of this chapter, or of §§ 131.075 through 131.078, by
an officer, director, manager, or other agent or employee of any licensee,
shall be deemed and held to be the act of the licensee, and the licensee
shall be punishable in the same manner as if the act or omission had been
done or omitted by the licensee personally.



(Prior Code, § 5-4-3)  Penalty, see § 114.99



§ 114.99  PENALTY



   (A)   The Mayor may suspend, revoke, or issue a written reprimand to
any licensee issued under the provisions of this chapter, if the Mayor
determines that the licensee has violated any of the provisions of this
chapter or any of the provisions of §§ 131.075 through 131.078. In lieu of
suspension or revocation of a license, the Mayor may instead levy a fine on
the licensee. The fine imposed shall not exceed $750 for each violation. Each
day on which a violation continues or each sale of tobacco products which is
in violation shall constitute a separate violation.



   (B)   If the Mayor determines that a letter of reprimand is
warranted, or the license should be suspended or revoked, he or she shall
issue a written order within five days stating the reasons for the
determination, and shall cause a copy of the order to be served upon the
licensee within ten days. In the event a penalty is imposed, the order shall
specify the date by which the penalty shall be paid. If the penalty is not
paid by the specified date, the license shall be suspended for a time
determined by the Mayor. All penalties shall be paid at the Police Department.



   (C)   When any license shall have been revoked for any cause, no
license shall be granted to the licensee for the period of six months
thereafter for the conduct of the business of selling tobacco products as set
forth in § 114.01 in the premises described in the revoked license.



(Prior Code, § 5-4-4)

   Appendix A:  Application forms (Amusement, jukebox and raffle)




GAME ROOMS




§ 115.01  LICENSE REQUIRED.



   It shall be unlawful for any person, partnership, association, or
corporation to establish or operate any form of game room which offers to the
public electrically or manually operated amusement games, pool or billiard
tables, foosball tables, or any other electrically or manually operated
amusement device or table game in the city without obtaining a license as
herein provided.



(Prior Code, § 5-2-1)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 115.02  LICENSE CLASSIFICATIONS ESTABLISHED.



   (A)   Class A.  This class is established for AMUSEMENT CENTER,
which is any public place kept, used, maintained, advertised, and held out to
the public to be a place primarily for the offering of games of amusement or
amusement devices, including, but not limited to, billiard, pool, bagetello,
or pigeon hole tables, and any mechanical or electrically operated amusement
device. A place shall be deemed to be primarily for the offering of games of
amusement or amusement devices if more than 50% of the square footage thereof
is used for those purposes. Square footage shall include not only the space
devoted to the games and devices, but also a reasonable space allowance for
the patrons thereof. Classification for an amusement center under this
division shall be termed “A-1”. In addition to Class A-1 license for
amusement centers, other businesses which have more than eight amusement
devices, but which do not meet the requirements of an amusement center as set
forth above, shall be required to have a Class A license. Classification for
businesses of this nature shall be termed “A-2”.



   (B)   Class B.  This class is established for other public places
not primarily for the offering of games of amusement or amusement devices
which have fewer than eight of the same type devices listed under Class A on
the premises. No license is required if the amusement device is stored and
not available to the public.



(Prior Code, § 5-2-2)



§ 115.03  LICENSE APPLICATION.



   (A)   Any person, partnership, association, or corporation who
wishes to establish or operate amusement devices as regulated under this
subchapter shall make application for an amusement license, which application
shall state:



      (1)   The name, age, and address of the applicant if an
individual or partnership and, in case of a corporation or association, the
date and place of incorporation, corporate purposes, and the names and
addresses of officers and directors. If any individual applicant has a prior
felony conviction, the conviction will be disclosed in the application;



      (2)   The location and description of the premises or place
where the business is to be operated and the number of amusement devices to
be operated on the premises. The hours of operation shall also be stated;



      (3)   A statement whether the applicant has any similar
businesses or premises other than those described in the application and the
location and nature of the similar business, if any;



      (4)   A statement that the applicant will not violate any of
the laws of the state or of the United States or any provisions of the
ordinances of this city in the conduct of his or her place of business; and



      (5)   A statement of the rules of the house that will be
publicly posted on the premises for the conduct of the patrons and the
operation and management of the business.



   (B)   These provisions in this section are applicable to both Class
A and Class B applicants. Class A and B applications are to be made first to
the City Council, or its designee. The City Council, or its designee shall
hold a public hearing on each application prior to its recommendation to the
City Council, which will authorize the issuance or denial of the license.
Expansion from a Class B to a Class A license is treated as a new application
and is to be processed pursuant to this section. Expansion within a license
class is to be reviewed and approved by the City Council, or its designee.
The City Clerk formally will issue the license only when authorized by the
City Council.



(Prior Code, § 5-2-3)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 115.04  LICENSE TERM; FEE.



   (A)   Each Class A and Class B license shall terminate on April 30
next following its issuance. The annual fee for the license shall be $35 per
electrically or manually operated amusement game or device or table game
offered for use to the public on the premises of the business. Any license
issued after April 30 of any year shall be issued for a fee which shall be
set by prorating the yearly license fee of that particular operator over the
remainder of the license year. Any licensee may increase the number of
electrically or manually operated games or devices based on the aforesaid fee
of $35 per device, the fee being prorated over the remainder of the license
year. Any license shall be valid only for the premises specified in the
application. No portion of the license fee shall be refunded.



   (B)   Annual renewal of Class A and B licenses shall be accompanied
by the annual fee as set forth in the previous division. The annual renewal
shall be reviewed and approved by the City Council, or its designee. The
renewal request indicates any changes in operation that will be in effect for
the new license year, an inventory listing of the number of devices that are
to be operated on the premises, and a listing of any violations of this
subchapter which have occurred in the past license year.



   (C)   The license herein provided for shall be posted permanently
and conspicuously at the location of the premises.



   (D)   If the licensee shall move his or her place of business to
another location within the city, the license may be transferred to the new
location upon application to the City Clerk, giving the street and number of
the new location. The new location shall be approved by the City Council, or
its designee. The Council, or its designee may seek the advice of the City
Council or any board before granting the request.



(Prior Code, § 5-2-4)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 115.05  PROHIBITIONS AND RESTRICTIONS.



   (A)   No Class A-1 license shall be issued for any premises in or
within 200 feet of an area zoned as residential. All license holders must
operate the business in a B-2 or B-3 Business District as established by the
most current Zoning District Map of the city.



   (B)   Licensees under this subchapter shall permit no patron to
bring onto the licensed premises or possess any firearms or weapons or any
cannabis or controlled substance, as defined in ILCS Ch. 720, Act 600, § 3.



   (C)   Class A and Class B licensees who do not hold a valid license
to sell at retail liquor pursuant to Chapter 110 of this code shall not
dispense alcohol or allow any patrons to have in their possession or dispense
alcohol or any beverage containing alcohol. A finding of violation of this
division by the City Council, or its designee shall result in permanent
revocation of the license authorized by this chapter.



   (D)   Class A and Class B licensees shall eject any patron if the
patron has caused a disturbance, is engaged in disorderly conduct, or
violates the house rules. It shall be the responsibility of the licensee to
preclude patrons from loitering in or near the premises so as to create a
breach of the peace, create annoyance or disturbance of the comfort and
repose of any other person, or obstruct free passage of pedestrians or
vehicles on public thoroughfares.



   (E)   Class A and Class B licensees shall have adult supervision by
a person not less than 21 years of age on the premises at all times of open
operation.



   (F)   Licenses shall be issued only to those who are 21 years or
more of age or to corporations, all of the shareholders of which are 21 years
or older.



   (G)   Separate licenses shall be required if the license holder
operates one or more businesses at separate locations, each of which is
subject to the terms of this chapter.



(Prior Code, § 5-2-5)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 115.06  LICENSE NONTRANSFERABLE.



   Any license issued under this chapter shall be considered a personal
privilege granted to the holder thereof and not as a vested property right.
Any license issued under this chapter shall not be transferable by
assignment, inheritance, or any other method.



(Prior Code, § 5-2-8)



§ 115.07  REVOCATION OF LICENSE.



   Every license issued under this chapter is subject to the right, which
is hereby expressly reserved, to revoke the same should the licensee directly
or indirectly operate contrary to the provisions of this chapter, the
regulations of the city, or the laws of the state. The license may be revoked
by the City Council, or its designee after written notice to the licensee,
which notice shall specify the violations with which the licensee is charged,
if after a hearing the licensee is found to be guilty of the violation(s).
Ten days notice of the hearing shall be given in writing and sent to the
address of the licensee. At the hearing, the licensee and his or her attorney
may present and submit evidence of witnesses in his or her defense.



(Prior Code, § 5-2-10)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 115.08  HOURS OF OPERATION.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any Class A-1 licensee to operate any
hours except the following:



      (1)   During that portion of the year when the public schools
are in session, the following hours:



         (a)   Monday through Thursday, 3:30 p.m. to 11:00 p.m.;



         (b)   Friday, 3:30 p.m. to 12:00 midnight;



         (c)   Saturday, 12:00 noon to 12:00 midnight; and



         (d)   Sunday, 1:00 p.m. to 11:00 p.m.



      (2)   During that portion of the year when the public schools
are not in session, the following hours:



         (a)   Monday through Thursday, 12:00 noon to 11:00 p.m.;



         (b)   Friday and Saturday, 12:00 noon to 12:00 midnight;
and



         (c)   Sunday, 1:00 p.m. to 11:00 p.m.



   (B)   The above hours as set out in this section shall not limit the
operation of electrically or manually operated games, amusement devices, or
game tables which are located within premises which house a place of business
maintaining a liquor license and which, under the license, minors are
excluded from the premises. The businesses may utilize their electrically and
manually operated games, game tables, and amusement devices during the hours
they are allowed to operate under the liquor license. However, no liquor
licensee who is prohibited from having minors on his or her premises by any
local ordinance or state statute shall allow the use of his or her
electrically or manually operated games, game tables, and other amusement
devices by minors.



   (C)   The purpose of this section is to place the responsibility on
the license holder so that when the schools are in session, the license
holder does not allow a student(s) to be on their premises when the
student(s) is required to be in school.



(Prior Code, § 5-2-6)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 115.09  COMPLIANCE WITH HEALTH, BUILDING, AND FIRE CODES.



   All license holders under this subchapter shall fully comply with the
health, building, fire, plumbing, electrical, and all other codes of the city
and the state. The premises will conform to all ordinances adopted by the
city for zoning and building purposes.



(Prior Code, § 5-2-7)



§ 115.10  CITY COUNCIL DUTIES.



   The City Council, or its designee shall perform the duties set out in
this subchapter and enforce the provisions thereof. The Council shall conduct
all hearings on the revocation of licenses. The Council will review the
annual renewal applications and shall approve those that conform with the
purposes of this and other applicable ordinances and laws of the state.



(Prior Code, § 5-2-9)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)




JUKEBOXES




§ 115.25  LICENSE REQUIRED.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to have, keep, or permit so called
jukebox to be used in or upon any premises owned, occupied, or controlled by
the person for his or her gain or profit without having first obtained a
license signed by the Mayor and the City Clerk as hereinafter provided.



(Prior Code, § 5-3-1)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 115.26  APPLICATION.



   Any person desiring a license shall file with the City Clerk a written
application therefore setting forth the location of the building or room to
be occupied, and the number and nature of the boxes or machines for which a
license is desired, and shall pay to the City Clerk the license fee required.



(Prior Code, § 5-3-2)



§ 115.27  LICENSE FEE.



   The license above provided for may be granted for the term of one year
upon the applicant paying to the city the sum of $25 for each jukebox to be
licensed. The license year shall, however, begin on May 1 of each year, and a
license granted during any year shall be for the period from the granting
thereof until the first day of the following May. If the period shall be less
than six months, the fee for the license shall be $12.50 instead of $25, but
if the period shall be more than six months, the full $25 fee shall be
charged.



(Prior Code, § 5-3-3)




RAFFLES




§ 115.40  LICENSE REQUIRED.



   It shall be unlawful for any person or organization to operate a raffle
within the city limits without having a raffle license in accordance with the
terms of this subchapter.



(Prior Code, § 5-5-1)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 115.41  APPLICATION.



   Application for the license shall be made to the City Clerk in writing,
and shall contain all the information required by ILCS Ch. 230, Act 15, §§
0.01 et seq., known as the Raffles Act of the Illinois Compiled Statutes, and
all amendments thereto. Application shall be made on the form supplied to the
applicant by the City Clerk. If the applicant and the application conform in
all respects to the subchapter and the aforesaid statute, the City Clerk
shall issue the raffle license. Otherwise, the City Clerk shall deny the
application, citing the reason for the denial in writing on the application,
and return it to the applicant. No fee shall be charged for each application.



(Prior Code, § 5-5-2)



§ 115.42  LICENSE DURATION.



   Licenses issued pursuant to this subchapter shall be valid for a period
of up to one year with a maximum allowable number of raffles not to exceed
365 during that period. Term and number of raffles shall be so indicated upon
the application for raffle license. The license may be suspended or revoked
for any violation of this subchapter.



(Prior Code, § 5-5-3)



§ 115.43  REGULATORY PROVISIONS.



   (A)   The following provisions shall be followed in the operation of
each licensed raffle:



      (1)   The aggregate retail value of all prizes or merchandise
awarded in a single raffle shall be up to $100,000;



      (2)   The maximum retail value of each prize awarded in a
single raffle shall be up to $25,000;



      (3)   The maximum price which may be charged for each raffle
chance issued or sold shall be up to $25,000; and



      (4)   The maximum number of days during which chances for any
individual raffle may be issued or sold shall not exceed 120 days,
notwithstanding that in no case shall a license issued for more than one
raffle be valid nor shall chances be issued or sold for longer than the
period so stated on the license.



   (B)   In all other respects, the operation of each license raffle
shall conform to the aforesaid statute, and all amendments thereto.



   (C)   Fiducial bond shall not be required.



(Prior Code, § 5-5-4) (Am. Ord. O-11-029, passed 12-14-2011)




SHOOTING GALLERIES




§ 115.55  LICENSE REQUIRED.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct, run, operate, or
maintain for profit any form of public amusement known as a shooting gallery,
targets, or target range, or like form of public amusement without first
being licensed so to do by the City Council.



(Prior Code, § 5-11-1)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 115.56  LICENSE FEE.



   Every person so desiring to conduct, run, operate, or maintain for
profit any form of public amusement mentioned in § 115.55 shall pay in
advance to the City Clerk the sum of $5 per month for every month or part
thereof during which it is desired so to conduct, run, operate, or maintain
the same, provided that no person shall be so licensed, nor any license be
issued as hereinafter provided, for a less period or term than three months
and license fees shall be payable quarterly in advance.



(Prior Code, § 5-11-2)



§ 115.57  LICENSE CONTENTS.



   Licenses so issued shall be signed by the Mayor and attested under the
seal of the city by the City Clerk and shall state the nature of the
amusement thereunder licensed, the time for which it is granted, the name of
the person to whom it is granted, the building, room, or place intended to be
occupied, that the license shall be used and the privileges granted
thereunder shall be exercised at the place only and that the license shall
not be transferable nor assignable and shall be conditioned so that any
violation of this subchapter shall work a forfeiture of the license and all
sums of money which may have been paid thereon at the election of the City
Council.



(Prior Code, § 5-11-3)



§ 115.58  RESTRICTIONS AGAINST MINORS, GAMBLING, AND ALCOHOL.



   No person holding a license shall keep open the gallery or like
amusement place except during the hours from 7:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m. on week
days and shall keep closed on Sundays, nor shall suffer or permit any minor
under the age of 18 years to frequent or loiter about the premises so
occupied by him or her without the written permission or order of the parent
or guardian of the minor, nor shall sell, barter, exchange, or give away in
connection with the business or otherwise any intoxicating liquors, nor shall
suffer or permit any betting, gaming or riotous or disorderly conduct upon
the premises occupied by him or her.



(Prior Code, § 5-11-4)  Penalty, see § 10.99



APPENDIX A:  APPLICATION FORMS (AMUSEMENT, JUKEBOX AND RAFFLE)



   I.   Amusement center license application



   II.   Amusement license application

CHAPTER 116:  TRAILER CAMPS



Section




General Provisions




   116.01   Definitions



   116.02   License required



   116.03   Annual fee



   116.04   Application



   116.05   Revocation of license




Camp Requirements




   116.20   Camp plan



   116.21   Location



   116.22   Water supply



   116.23   Sanitation facilities



   116.24   Laundry facilities



   116.25   Sewage disposal



   116.26   Garbage receptacles



   116.27   Fire protection



   116.28   Control of pets



   116.29   Occupant register required; contents



   116.30   License to be posted



   Appendix A:  License application




GENERAL PROVISIONS




§ 116.01  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   CAMP.  Trailer coach camp.



   TRAILER COACH.  Any vehicle used or maintained for use as a conveyance
upon highways or city streets so designed and so constructed as to permit
occupancy thereof as a temporary dwelling or sleeping place for one or more
persons, having no other foundation than wheels or jacks.



   TRAILER COACH SPACE.  A plot of ground within a trailer coach camp
designed for the accommodation of one trailer coach.



   TRAILER HOME.  Any TRAILER COACH, but being placed on a foundation of
blocks, timbers, or some other foundation more stable and permanent than
wheels or jacks.



(Prior Code, § 5-10-1)



§ 116.02  LICENSE REQUIRED.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain or operate any trailer
coach camp unless the person shall first obtain a license therefore.



(Prior Code, § 5-10-2)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 116.03  ANNUAL FEE.



   The annual license fee for each trailer coach camp shall be $25.



(Prior Code, § 5-10-3)



§ 116.04  APPLICATION.



   (A)   Application for a trailer coach camp license shall be filed
with and issued by the City Clerk after approval of the application by the
City Council. Application shall be in writing signed by the applicant and
shall contain the following:



      (1)   The name and address of the applicant;



      (2)   The location and legal description of the trailer coach
camp;



      (3)   A complete plan of the camp showing compliance with §
116.20;



      (4)   Plans and specifications of all buildings and other
improvements constructed or to be constructed within the trailer coach camp;
and



      (5)   Further information as may be requested by the City
Council to enable it to determine if the proposed camp will comply with all
requirements and located in an area zoned for the purpose.



   (B)   The application and all accompanying plans and specifications
shall be filed in triplicate. The City Council shall investigate the
applicant and inspect the proposed plans and specifications. If the applicant
is found to be of good moral character and the proposed trailer coach camp
will be in compliance with all provisions of this chapter and all other
applicable ordinances or statutes, the Council shall approve the application,
and, upon completion of the camp according to the plans, shall issue the
license.



   (C)   Upon application for a transfer of the license, the City
Council shall issue a transfer if it finds that the transferee is of good
moral character.



(Prior Code, § 5-10-4)



§ 116.05  REVOCATION OF LICENSE.



   The City Council may revoke any license to maintain and operate a camp
when the licensee has been found guilty by a court of competent jurisdiction
of violating any provision of this chapter. After the conviction, the license
may be reissued if the circumstances leading to conviction have been remedied
and the camp is then maintained and operated in full compliance with law.



(Prior Code, § 5-10-15)




CAMP REQUIREMENTS




§ 116.20  CAMP PLAN.



   (A)   The trailer coach camp shall conform to the following
requirements.



      (1)   The camp shall be located on a well drained site,
properly graded to ensure rapid drainage and freedom from stagnant pools of
water.



      (2)   Trailer coach spaces shall be provided consisting of a
minimum of 1,000 square feet for each space which shall be at least 25 feet
wide and clearly defined. Trailer coaches shall be so placed on each space
that there shall be at least a 15-foot clearance between trailer coaches. No
trailer coach shall be located closer than ten feet from any property line
bounding the camp.



      (3)   All trailer coach spaces shall abut upon a driveway of
not less than 20 feet in width which shall have unobstructed access to a
public street, alley, or highway. All driveways shall be hard surfaced or
treated with gravel or crushed rock, or well oiled, well marked in the
daytime and lighted at night with 25-watt lamps at intervals of 100 feet
located approximately 15 feet from the ground.



   (B)   Each camp shall provide service buildings to house toilet
facilities, bathing facilities, laundry facilities and other sanitary
facilities, as hereinafter more particularly described.



   (C)   An electrical outlet supplying at least 110 volts shall be
provided for each trailer coach space.



(Prior Code, § 5-10-5)



§ 116.21  LOCATION.



   Trailer coach camps may be located in any district for which a license
is granted by the Council. Each boundary of the camp must be at least 200
feet from any permanent residential building located outside the camp unless
separated therefrom by a natural or artificial barrier or unless a majority
of the property owners according to area within the 200 feet consent in
writing to the establishment of the camp.



(Prior Code, § 5-10-6)



§ 116.22  WATER SUPPLY.



   An adequate supply of pure water for drinking and domestic purposes
shall be supplied to meet the requirements of the camp. The water supply
shall be obtained from faucets only. No common drinking cups shall be
permitted.



(Prior Code, § 5-10-7)



§ 116.23  SANITATION FACILITIES.



   (A)   Each camp shall be provided with toilets, baths, or showers,
slop sinks, and other sanitation facilities, which shall conform to the
following requirements:



      (1)   Toilet facilities for men and women shall be provided,
and they shall be either in separate buildings at least 20 feet apart, or
shall be separated if in the same building by a sound proof wall.



      (2)   Service buildings housing the toilet facilities shall be
permanent structures complying with all applicable provisions of the
ordinances of this city and statutes regulating buildings, electrical
installations, and plumbing and sanitation systems and shall be located not
closer than ten feet nor farther than 200 feet from any trailer coach space.



      (3)   The service buildings shall be well lighted at all times
of the day or night, shall be well ventilated with screened openings, shall
be constructed of moisture proof material, including painted woodwork, as
shall permit repeated cleaning and washing, and shall be maintained at a
temperature of at least 68F during the period from October 1 to May 1. The
floors of the service buildings shall be of water impervious material and
shall slope to a floor drain connected with the sewage system.



   (B)   All service buildings and the grounds of the camp shall be
maintained in a clean, sightly condition and kept free of any condition that
will menace the health of any occupant or the public or constitute a nuisance.



(Prior Code, § 5-10-8)



§ 116.24  LAUNDRY FACILITIES.



   The laundry facilities shall be provided in the ratio of one double
laundry tub and ironing board for every 20 trailer coach spaces. All
electrical outlet supply current sufficient to operate an iron shall be
located conveniently near the ironing board. The service building housing the
laundry facilities shall be a permanent structure complying with all
applicable ordinances of this city and statutes regulating buildings,
electrical installations, and plumbing and sanitation systems.



(Prior Code, § 5-10-9)



§ 116.25  SEWAGE DISPOSAL.



   Waste from showers, bath tubs, toilets, slop sinks, and laundries shall
be discharged into a public sewer system in compliance with applicable
regulations, or into a private sewer or disposal plant or septic tank system
of the construction and in the manner as will present no health hazard.



(Prior Code, § 5-10-10)



§ 116.26  GARBAGE RECEPTACLES.



   Tightly covered metal garbage cans shall be provided in quantities
adequate to permit disposal of all garbage and rubbish. Garbage cans shall be
located not farther than 200 feet from any trailer coach space. The cans
shall be kept in sanitary condition at all times. Garbage and rubbish shall
be collected and disposed of as frequently as may be necessary to ensure that
the garbage cans shall not overflow.



(Prior Code, § 5-10-11)



§ 116.27  FIRE PROTECTION.



   Every camp shall be equipped at all times with one fire extinguisher in
good working order for every ten trailer coach spaces located not farther
than 200 feet from each trailer coach space. No open fires shall be permitted
at any place which would endanger life or property. No fires shall be left
unattended at any time.



(Prior Code, § 5-10-12)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 116.28  CONTROL OF PETS.



   No owner or person in charge of any dog, cat, or other pet animal shall
permit it to run at large or commit any nuisance within the limits of any
trailer coach camp.



(Prior Code, § 5-10-13)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 116.29  OCCUPANT REGISTER REQUIRED; CONTENTS.



   (A)   It shall be the duty of the licensee to keep a register
containing a record of all trailer coach owners and occupants located within
the camp. The register shall contain the following information:



      (1)   Name and address of each occupant;



      (2)   The make, model, and year of all automobiles and trailer
coaches;



      (3)   License number and owner of each trailer coach and
automobile by which it is towed;



      (4)   The state issuing the licenses; and



      (5)   The dates of arrival and departure of each trailer coach.



   (B)   The camp shall keep the register available for inspection at
all times by law enforcement officers, public health officials, and other
officials whose duties necessitate obtaining the information contained in the
register. The register records shall not be destroyed for a period of three
years following the date of registration.



(Prior Code, § 5-10-14)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 116.30  LICENSE TO BE POSTED.



   The license certificate shall at all times be conspicuously posted in
the office of or on the premises of the trailer coach camp.



(Prior Code, § 5-10-16)  Penalty, see § 10.99



APPENDIX A:  LICENSE APPLICATION



   I.   Application for trailer camp license
