      (3)   Synthetic stimulant means any compound that mimics the
effects of any federally controlled Schedule I substances such as cathinone,
methcathione, MDMA and MDEA, including, but not limited to, any quantity of a
natural or synthetic material, compound, mixture, preparation, substance and
their analog (including salts, isomers, and salts of isomers) containing
substances which have a stimulant effect on the central nervous system, such
as:



         (a)   3-Fluoromethcathinone



         (b)   4-Fluoromethcathinone (other name: flephedrone)



         (c)   3,4-Methylenedioxymethcathinone (other name:
methylone, MDMC)



         (d)   3,4-Methylendeioxypyrovalerone (other name: MDPV)



         (e)   4-Methylmethcathinon (other names: mephedrone,
4-MMC)



         (f)   4-Methoxymethcathinone (other names: methedrone,
bk-PMMA, PMMC)



         (g)   4-Ethylmethcathinone (other name: 4-EMC)



         (h)   Ethcathinone



         (i)   Beta-keto-N-methylbenzodioxyolylpropylamine (other
names: butylone, bk-MBDB)



         (j)   Napthylpyrovalerone (other names: naphyrone, NRG-1)



         (k)   N,N-dimethylcathinone (other name: metamfepramone)



         (l)   Alpha-pyrrolidinopropiophenone (other name:
alpha-ppp)



         (m)   4-methoxy-alpha-pyrrolidinopropiophenone (other
name: MOPPP)



         (n)   3,4-methylemedioxy-alpha-pyrrolidinopropiophenone
(other name: MDPPP)



         (o)   Alpha-pyrrolidinovalerophenone (other name:
alpha-PVP)



         (p)   6,7-kihydro-5H-indeno(5,6-d)-1,3-dioxal-6-amine)
(other name: MDAI)



         (q)   Any compound that is structurally derived from
2-amino-1-phenyl-1-propanone by modification or substitution in any of the
following ways:



            1.   In the phenyl ring to any extent with alkyl,
alkoxy, alkylenedioxy, haloalkyl, or halide substituents, whether or not
further substituted in the phenyl ring by one or more other univalent
substituents;



            2.   At the three-position with an alkyl
substituent;



            3.   At the nitrogen atom with alkyl, dialkyl,
benzyl, or methoxybenzyl groups;



            4.   Or by inclusion of the nitrogen atom in a
cycle structure.



      (4)   Synthetic psychedelic/hallucinogen means any compound
that mimics the effects of any federally controlled Schedule I substance,
including but not limited to, any quantity of a natural or synthetic
material, compound, mixture, preparation, substance and their analog
(including salts, isomers, esters, ethers and salts of isomers) containing
substances which have a psychedelic/hallucinogenic effect on the central
nervous system and/or brain, such as:



         (a)   2-(2,5Dimethoxy-4-ethylphenyl)ethanamine (2C-E);



         (b)   2-(2,5-dimethoxy-4-methylphenyl)ethanamine (2C-D);



         (c)   2-(4-Chloro-2,5-dimethoxyphenyl)ethanamine (2C-C);



         (d)   2-(4-lodo-2,5-dimethoxyphenyl)ethanamine (2C-I);



         (e)   2-(4-Ethylthio)-2,5-dimethoxyphenyi)ethanamine
(2C-T-2);



         (f)   2-(4-lsopropylthio)-2,5-dimethoxyphenyl)ethanamine
(2C-T-4);



         (g)   2-(2,5-Dimethoxyphenyl)ethanamine (2C-H);



         (h)   2-(2,5-Dimethoxy-4-nitro-phenyl)ethanamine(2C-N);



         (i)   2-(2,5-Dimethoxy-4-(n)-propylphenyl)ethanamine(2C-P)
.



   (B)   Sale or delivery. It shall be unlawful for any person to sell,
offer for sale or deliver any product containing a synthetic cannabinoid,
stimulant or psychedelic/hallucinogen.



   (C)   Possession. It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly
possess a product containing a synthetic cannabinoid, stimulant or
psychedelic/hallucinogen.



   (D)   Use. It shall be unlawful for any person to be under the
influence of a synthetic cannabinoid, stimulant or psychedelic/hallucinogen.



(Ord. O-12-035, passed 2-14-2012)



§ 131.065  CANNABIS.



   (A)   The terms used herein shall be defined as set forth in the
Illinois Cannabis Control Act, ILCS Ch. 720, Act 550, § 3.



   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly to possess
cannabis within the city.



   (C)   Any person violating this section by knowingly possessing
cannabis in an amount of ten grams or less shall be subject to the provisions
of § 10.99 of this Code.



(Ord. O-16-177, passed 10-11-2016)




TOBACCO POSSESSION BY MINORS




§ 131.075  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   MINOR.  Any person under 18 years of age.



   PUBLIC AREAS.  Any street, sidewalk, or other public right-of-way or
place, park, or other public place including the quasi-public area in front
of or adjacent to any store, shop, restaurant, luncheonette, or other place
of business, and also including parking lots or other vacant property not
owned or under the control of the person charged with the violation of this
subchapter.



   PUBLIC SCHOOL.  A public school or school offering general education
courses the same as ordinarily given in a public school, or a private
preschool, play school, special curriculum school, and any other private
school.



   TOBACCO AND NICOTINE PRODUCTS.  Any substance containing tobacco leaf
or nicotine, or alternative nicotine products, including, but not limited to,
cigarettes, cigars, pipe tobacco, snuff, chewing tobacco, or dipping tobacco,
vapor cigarettes or e-cigarettes.



(Prior Code, § 7-11-1)  (Ord. O-15-135, passed 3-10-2015)



§ 131.076  USE OR POSSESSION BY MINORS ON PUBLIC PROPERTY.



   (A)   The use or consumption of tobacco or nicotine, or nicotine
alternative products by minors upon any public sidewalks, public
thoroughfares, public streets, public highways, public parks, or any property
of a public school, or any other public areas within the city limits is
hereby prohibited.



   (B)   The possession of any tobacco or nicotine, or alternative
nicotine products by minors while upon any public sidewalks, public
thoroughfares, public streets, public highways, public parks, or any property
of a public school, or any other public areas within the city limits is
hereby prohibited.



(Prior Code, § 7-11-2)  (Ord. O-15-135, passed 3-10-2015)  Penalty, see §
131.999



§ 131.077  RESTRICTIONS ON TOBACCO DISTRIBUTION.



   It shall be unlawful for any licensee, as set forth in Chapter 114 of
this code, or any person in the business of selling or otherwise promoting or
advertising tobacco or nicotine products, or any employee or agent of any
licensee or person in the course of the licensee’s or person’s business,
to distribute, give away or deliver tobacco products free of charge to any
person upon any public sidewalks, public thoroughfares, public streets,
public highways, public parks, or any property of a public school, or any
other public areas within the city limits.



(Prior Code, § 7-11-3)  (Ord. O-15-135, passed 3-10-2015)  Penalty, see §
131.999



§ 131.078  ENFORCEMENT BY SCHOOL DISTRICT PERSONNEL.



   The following appointed officials of any public school shall have
authority to sign all complaints and charge any violations of this subchapter
that take place upon school property: Principal, Assistant Principal, and
Dean of Students.



(Prior Code, § 7-11-4)



§ 131.999  PENALTY.



   (A)   Any person violating any provision of this chapter for which
no specific penalty is prescribed shall be subject to § 10.99.



   (B)   Any person found guilty of a violation of § 131.001 shall be
liable for a fine of not less than $25 nor more than $750.



(Prior Code, § 7-1-2)



   (C)   (1)   Any person who violates the provisions of §§
131.015 through 131.017 shall be subject to a fine not less than $25 nor more
than $750, except that the minimum fine for a violation involving a sale or
exhibiting obscene material to a person under the age of 18 years shall be
$100. Each day that the obscene material is offered for sale or exhibited
shall constitute a separate offense.



      (2)   Any person who, with knowledge of the nature of contents
thereof, sells, offers to sell, exhibits, or offers to exhibit to any other
person any obscene publication or other article, as judged with reference to
ordinary adults, shall be fined an amount not to exceed $200 for each offense.



(Prior Code, § 7-1-3)



   (D)   A person who violates a provision of §§ 131.030 through
131.032 is guilty of a separate offense for each day or part of a day during
which the violation is committed, continued, or permitted. Each offense, upon
conviction, is punishable by a fine not to exceed $750.



(Prior Code, § 7-7-4)



   (E)   Any person found in violation of §§ 131.045 through 131.048
shall be subject to a fine of not less than $25 nor more than $750. In
addition to or as an alternative to the imposition of the fine, the offender
may be ordered to perform public service work not to exceed 20 hours.



(Prior Code, § 7-9-5)



   (F)   (1)   Any person who violates any provision of §§ 131.060
through 131.063 shall be subject to a fine of not less than $25 nor more than
$750.



      (2)   Any person who keeps for sale, offers for sale, sells,
or delivers for any commercial consideration any item which that person
knows, or, under all of the circumstances, reasonably should have known, to
be drug paraphernalia, commits a business offense for which a fine of $500
shall be imposed for each item.



      (3)   Any store, place, or premises from which or in which any
item of drug paraphernalia is kept for sale, offered for sale, sold, or
delivered for any commercial consideration is declared to be a public
nuisance, and the City Attorney may commence an action in the Circuit Court,
in the name of the people of the city, to abate a public nuisance as
described in § 131.062, and request that the court enter:



         (a)   Temporary and permanent restraining orders to
enjoin any defendant from maintaining the nuisance; and



         (b)   Preliminary and permanent injunctions restraining
any defendant from removing or interfering with any property used in
connection with the public nuisance.



      (4)   All drug paraphernalia is subject to forfeiture.



      (5)   Property subject to forfeiture under this chapter may be
seized by any peace officer and may be made without process:



         (a)   If there is probable cause to believe that the
property is directly dangerous to health or safety and existing circumstances
do not allow reasonable time for the officer to obtain lawful process; or



         (b)   In accordance with the provisions of The Code of
Criminal Procedure, as amended.



      (6)   The presence of items which are deemed violative of §§
131.060 through 131.063 or are otherwise subject to its forfeiture provisions
in an inventory shall not subject the entire inventory to seizure or
forfeiture.



      (7)   Any person who shall violate any provision of § 131.064
shall, upon conviction, be fined in an amount not less than $250 nor more
than $750.



(Prior Code, § 7-10-5)



   (G)   (1)   Any violations of the provisions of §§ 131.075
through 131.078 shall be punishable by a minimum fine of $25 and a maximum
fine of $750. In the event a person violates the provisions a second or
subsequent time, the minimum fine shall be $50.



      (2)   The fines in division (G)(1) above are in addition to
administrative provisions for suspension, revocation or forfeiture of a
license issued pursuant to Chapter 114 of this code, and payment of the fine
shall not constitute an admission of guilt or innocence for purposes of the
administrative proceedings for suspension, revocation or forfeiture.



      (3)   In the event that a person is charged with a violation
of §§ 131.075 through 131.078 under an ordinance violation notice as a
first-time offender, the person may satisfy the penalty by paying the $25
fine in person or by mail within five days of being charged with the
violation. All penalties shall be paid at the Police Department.



(Prior Code, § 7-11-5)



(Am. Ord. O-12-035, passed 2-14-2012)

(Prior Code, Title 11)



§ 150.02  ZONING ORDINANCE ADOPTED.



   The city’s zoning ordinance is hereby adopted by reference and
incorporated herein as if set out in full.



(Prior Code, Title 9)  (Ord. O-11-017, passed 8-4-2011; Ord. O-11-021,
passed 9-13-2011; Ord. O-12-037, passed 5-8-2012; Ord. O-12-038, passed

§ 150.03  SUBDIVISION ORDINANCE ADOPTED.



   The city’s subdivision ordinance is hereby adopted by reference and
incorporated herein as if set out in full.



(Prior Code, Title 10) (Ord. O-18-12, passed 7-10-2018)




DANGEROUS BUILDINGS; ABATEMENT




§ 150.15  STATE CODE ADOPTED.



   Demolition, repair, enclosure, or other legal actions pertaining to
unsafe buildings should be conducted in accordance with the terms and
provisions of ILCS, Ch. 65, Act 5, 11-31-1, as the same may be hereafter
amended.



(Prior Code, § 4-4-1)  Penalty, see § 150.99




MOVING BUILDINGS




§ 150.30  PERMIT REQUIRED.



   Any person, firm, or corporation is hereby prohibited from moving a
residence, building, or structure upon or across a public sidewalk, public
thoroughfare, public right-of-way, public street, or public highway within
the city limits unless a moving permit is first obtained from the City Clerk.



(Prior Code, § 4-8-1)  Penalty, see § 150.99



§ 150.31  PERMIT REQUIREMENTS; ISSUANCE; FEE.



   (A)   A building moving permit shall be issued to a person, firm, or
corporation moving a residence, building, or structure only after each of the
following conditions have been met.



   (B)   (1)   Notification of the Chief of Police and Public
Service Superintendent regarding the time of the intended move and route of
the intended move;



      (2)   Notification of the Superintendents of both the
Municipal Electrical Utilities and the Municipal Water and Sewer Utilities
and payment of any utility relocation costs as may be assessed by the
superintendents;



      (3)   Provide the City Clerk with a certificate of insurance
showing proof that the applicant has in force a public liability insurance
policy with minimum limits of $100,000 per person, $300,000 per occurrence
bodily injury, and $50,000 per occurrence property damage for the purpose of
moving a building or structure over or on any public property or
thoroughfare; and



      (4)   Payment of a $25 permit fee to the City Clerk.



(Prior Code, § 4-8-2)  Penalty, see § 150.99



§ 150.99  PENALTY



   (A)   Any person violating any provision of this chapter for which
no specific penalty is prescribed shall be subject to § 10.99.



   (B)   Any person, firm, or corporation violating § 150.15 shall be
fined not less than $50 nor more than $1,000 for each offense. A separate
offense shall be deemed committed upon each day during or on which a
violation occurs or continues.



(Prior Code, § 4-4-2)



   (C)   Any person, firm, or corporation violating §§ 150.30 or
150.31 shall be fined not less than $25 nor more than $750 for each offense.



(Prior Code, § 4-8-3)



CHAPTER 151:  BUILDING CODE



Section



   151.01   Building Code adopted



   151.02   Permit required; exceptions



   151.03   Permit application



   151.04   Permit issuance; validity; revocation



   151.05   Inspection required



   151.06   Utility inspection at time of request for service



 



   151.99   Penalty



   Appendix A:  Schedule of fees



   Appendix B:  Permit application form



§ 151.01  BUILDING CODE ADOPTED.



   (A)   The 2000 International Building Code “IBC”, three copies
of which are on file in the office of the City Clerk, and all subsequent
editions, and all existing and future supplements, amendments, and appendixes
thereto, as published by the International Code Council, in cooperation with
the Building Officials and Code Administrators International, International
Conference of Building Officials, and the Southern Building Code Congress, is
hereby adopted as the Building Code for the city, with the exceptions set
forth in division (B) below.



   (B)   (1)   Chapter 1, Administration § 101.4 Referenced codes,
page 1 shall be deleted, except 101.4.5, Property Maintenance, shall be
adopted as the Property Maintenance Code.



      (2)   Chapter 1, Administration § 102.4, Referenced codes and
standards, page 2 shall be deleted. Referenced codes and standards shall be
used for reference purposes only.



      (3)   Appendices A through J, pages 699 - 731, may be used for
reference purposes only and shall not be mandatory.



      (4)   Appendix F, “Radon Control Methods” of the 2000
International Residential Code shall be mandatory for new construction as
defined therein.



(Prior Code, § 4-3-1)



§ 151.02  PERMIT REQUIRED; EXCEPTIONS.



   (A)   No building or structure regulated by the adopted code shall
be erected, constructed, enlarged, altered, repaired, moved, improved,
removed, converted, or demolished unless a separate permit for each building
or structure has first been obtained from the Building Inspector.



   (B)   A building permit shall not be required for the following work:



      (1)   One-story detached accessory buildings used as tool and
storage sheds, playhouses, and similar uses, provided the projected roof area
does not exceed 120 square feet;



      (2)    Fences not over seven feet high at the highest point
including the post;



      (3)   Oil derricks;



      (4)   Movable cases, counters, and partitions not over five
feet, nine inches high;



      (5)   Retaining walls which are not over four feet in height,
measured from the bottom of the footings to the top of the wall, unless
supporting a surcharge or impounding Class I, II, or III-A liquids;



      (6)   Water tanks supported directly upon grade if the
capacity does not exceed 5,000 gallons and the ratio of height to diameter or
width does not exceed two to one;



      (7)   Platforms, walks, and driveways not more than 30 inches
above grade and not over any basement or story below;



      (8)   Painting, papering, and similar finish work;



      (9)   Temporary motion picture, television, and theater stage
sets and scenery;



      (10)   Window awnings supported by an exterior wall of a
family dwelling, private garages, carports, and shed occupancies when
projecting not more than 54 inches; and/or



      (11)   Prefabricated swimming pools accessory to a family
dwelling occupancy in which the pool’s walls are entirely above the
adjacent grade and if the capacity does not exceed 5,000 gallons.



   (C)   Unless otherwise exempted and applicable, separate plumbing,
electrical, street opening, street access, and any other permit required by
the city will be required for the above exempted items.



   (D)   Exemption from the permit requirements of this chapter shall
not be deemed to grant authorization for any work to be done in any manner in
violation of the provisions of the adopted code or any other ordinances of
the city.



(Prior Code, § 4-3-2)  (Ord. 1976, passed 9-14-2010)   Penalty, see §
151.99



§ 151.03  PERMIT APPLICATION.



   (A)   The property owner or the contractor, if the work is performed
by a contractor, shall file an application for a permit on a form furnished
by the Building Inspector.



   (B)   Plans, engineering calculations, diagrams, and other data
shall be submitted in two sets with each application for permit. The Building
Inspector may require plans, computations, and specifications to be prepared
and designed by a licensed engineer or architect.



   (C)   The Building Inspector may waive the submission of plans,
engineering calculations, diagrams, and other data if the Building Inspector
determines that the nature of the work is such that reviewing of the
documents is not necessary to obtain compliance.



(Prior Code, § 4-3-3)  Penalty, see § 151.99



§ 151.04  PERMIT ISSUANCE; VALIDITY; REVOCATION.



   (A)   The application and supporting documents filed by an applicant
for a permit shall be reviewed by the Building Inspector. If the Building
Inspector finds that the work described in an application for a permit and
supporting documents conform to the requirements of the city’s adopted code
and other pertinent ordinances, then the Building Inspector shall issue a
permit to the applicant. A copy of the permit shall be filed with the City
Clerk.



   (B)   Permits issued by the Building Inspector shall expire by
limitation and become void after 365 days from the date of issuance.



   (C)   The Building Inspector shall, in writing, suspend or revoke a
permit issued under the provisions of the city’s adopted code whenever the
permit is issued in error or on the basis of incorrect information supplied,
or in violation of any ordinance or regulation of any of the city’s adopted
codes.



   (D)   The issuance of a permit shall not be construed to be a permit
for or an approval of any violation of any of the provisions of the city’s
adopted codes or of any ordinances of the city. The issuance of a permit
shall not prevent the Building Inspector from requiring the correction of
errors in any plans, specifications, and other data submitted with the
application.



(Prior Code, § 4-3-4)  Penalty, see § 151.99



§ 151.05  INSPECTION REQUIRED.



   (A)   Construction or work for which a permit is required shall be
subject to inspection by the Building Inspector and shall remain accessible
and exposed for inspection purposes until approved by the Building Inspector.



   (B)   It shall be the duty of the permit applicant to cause the work
to remain accessible and exposed for inspection purposes. Neither the
Building Inspector nor the city shall be liable for any expenses incurred for
the removal of material to allow for inspection or for the replacement of the
material removed.



   (C)   It shall be the duty of the person doing the work authorized
by a permit to notify the Building Inspector that the work is ready for
inspection. The request may be in writing or by telephone and must be
requested at least one working day before the inspection is desired.



   (D)   An inspection record card shall be posted on the premises so
as to allow the Building Inspector to make the required entries thereon
regarding inspection of the work.



   (E)   The inspector record card shall be maintained and available by
the permit holder until final inspection and approval has been granted by the
Building Inspector.



(Prior Code, § 4-3-6)



§ 151.06  UTILITY INSPECTION AT TIME OF REQUEST FOR SERVICE.



   (A)   Whenever an application is made for utility services, whether
for new services or for a new customer at a property already receiving
service, the city may require an inspection by the Code Official/Building
Inspector of the electric, water, and/or sewer connections for compliance
with all current building codes. The city may require repairs or other action
as a condition of receiving utility service where such is required under any
current building code adopted by the city and, upon seven days notice, may
suspend the delivery of utility services until the repairs or other actions
are completed. The city may immediately suspend any utility service where and
when conditions are such that there is an imminent threat of harm to persons
or property.



   (B)   The city shall not, on the basis of authority granted in this
§ 151.06, inspect any particular property sooner than 24 months from the
date of the last inspection. Nothing herein shall prevent the city from
conducting inspections on the basis of any other lawful authority.



   (C)   The fee for any inspection conducted under the authority of
this §151.06 shall be $25 which shall be added to the first invoice
following the commencement of the new utility service.



(Ord. O-18-17, passed 11-13-2018)



§ 151.99  PENALTY.



   A person, firm, or corporation violating any provision of this chapter
or the adopted code shall, on conviction, be fined not less than $25 nor more
than $750 for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed upon
each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues.



(Prior Code, § 4-3-8)



APPENDIX A:  SCHEDULE OF FEES




   I.   Schedule of fees




I.  SCHEDULE OF FEES.



   (A)   The fee shall be assessed as set forth in the table below. The
fee schedule shall also be assessed and applicable to demolition work as
defined in the adopted code.



   (B)   Whenever work described in the building permit application is
altered to cause additional valuation, the additional fee shall be the
difference between the original valuation and the valuation had the work been
included in the original application valuation.



   (C)   Fees for permits issued to the city are hereby waived.



   (D)   Fees for permits issued to schools, churches, or other
governmental entities will be reduced by 20%.  No fees shall be charged for
permits issued to non-for-profit organizations primarily engaged in providing
home repairs free of charge to low income homeowners.



   (E)   The payment of the permit fee established by the Building
Inspector shall be submitted along with the copy of the permit to the City
Clerk.  Whenever the fee does not accompany the copy of the permit, the City
Clerk shall render a bill for the fee.

CHAPTER 152:  PLUMBING CODE



Section



   152.01   Plumbing Code adopted



   152.02   Permit required



   152.03   Permit application



   152.04   Permit issuance; validity; revocation



   152.05   Licensed plumber required



   152.06   Inspection required



   Appendix A:  Schedule of fees



   Appendix B:  Permit application form



Cross-reference:



   Water distribution system construction, see § 53.10



   Fire protection system construction, see § 53.11

§ 152.01  PLUMBING CODE ADOPTED.



   The State Plumbing Code, and all subsequent editions and amendments
thereto, as published by the State Department of Public Health, are hereby
adopted by the city, in its current form, without addition, modification,
exception or amendment.



(Prior Code, § 4-1-1)  (Ord. 1929, passed 1-13-2009; Ord. O-15-138, passed
8-11-2015)



§ 152.02  PERMIT REQUIRED.



   (A)   No plumbing system of a building or structure regulated by the
adopted code shall be undertaken, constructed, enlarged, altered, repaired,
improved, removed, or converted unless a separate permit for each building or
structure has first been obtained from the city’s Plumbing Inspector.



   (B)   A plumbing permit shall not be required for the following work:



      (1)   For minor repairs which do not require changes, removal,
replacement, installation, or reinstallation in the piping of a plumbing
system to or from plumbing fixtures;



      (2)   For minor repairs of leaks in pipes, faucets, or traps,
for opening up of pipes, traps, or drains, and for the opening up of frozen
pipes;



      (3)   For the mere replacement of existing dishwashers,
garbage disposals, washers, or water-cooled air conditioners, unless the
replacement involves the relocation of the aforesaid fixtures; and/or



      (4)   For the installation of dishwashers, garbage disposals,
washers, or water-cooled air conditioners, unless the installation involves
the relocation of the aforesaid fixtures or modification of existing piping
system.



   (C)   Unless otherwise exempted, separate building, electrical,
street opening, street access, and any other permit required by the city will
be required for the above exempted items.



   (D)   Exemption from the permit requirements shall not be deemed to
grant authorization for any work to be done in any manner in violation of the
provisions of the adopted code or any ordinances of the city.



(Prior Code, § 4-1-2)



§ 152.03  PERMIT APPLICATION.



   (A)   The property owner of record or a licensed plumber who is
contracted to perform the work shall first file an application on a form
furnished by the Plumbing Inspector.



   (B)   Permit to install washing machines, water-cooled air
conditioners, dishwashers, and garbage disposals may be secured by the
dealers of the appliances although the dealers are not licensed plumbers.



   (C)   Plans, engineering calculations, diagrams, and other data
shall be submitted with each application for a permit. The Plumbing Inspector
may require plans, computations, and specifications to be prepared and
designed by a licensed engineer or architect.



   (D)   The Plumbing Inspector may waive the submission of plans,
engineering calculations, diagrams, and other data if the Plumbing Inspector
determines that the nature of the work is such that reviewing of the
documents is not necessary to obtain compliance.



(Prior Code, § 4-1-3)



§ 152.04  PERMIT ISSUANCE; VALIDITY; REVOCATION.



   (A)   The application and supporting documents filed by an applicant
for permit shall be reviewed by the Plumbing Inspector. If the Plumbing
Inspector finds that the work described in an application for a permit and
supporting documents conform to the requirements of the city’s adopted code
and other pertinent ordinances, then the Plumbing Inspector shall issue a
permit to the applicant. A copy of the permit shall be filed with the City
Clerk.



   (B)   Permits issued by the Plumbing Inspector shall expire by
limitation and become void after 365 days from the date of issuance.



   (C)   The Plumbing Inspector shall, in writing, suspend or revoke a
permit issued under the provisions of the city’s adopted code whenever the
permit is issued in error, or on the basis of incorrect information supplied,
or in violation of any ordinance or regulation of any of the city’s adopted
code.



   (D)   The issuance of a permit shall not be construed to be a permit
for or any approval of any violation of any of the provisions of the city’s
adopted code or of any ordinances of the city. The issuance of a permit shall
not prevent the Plumbing Inspector from requiring the correction of errors in
any plans, specifications, and other data submitted with the application.



(Prior Code, § 4-1-4)



§ 152.05  LICENSED PLUMBER REQUIRED.



   All work for which a permit is required shall be performed by a
licensed plumber of the state.



(Prior Code, § 4-1-6)  (Ord. O-15-138, passed 8-11-2015)



§ 152.06  INSPECTION REQUIRED.



   (A)   All work for which a permit is required shall be subject to
inspection by the Plumbing Inspector, and all work shall remain accessible
and exposed for inspection purposes until approved by the Plumbing Inspector.
The Plumbing Inspector must make a rough-in inspection before fixtures are
set and the plumbing work shall not be closed in, concealed, or covered until
after it has been inspected and approved.



   (B)   It shall be the duty of the permit applicant to cause the work
to remain accessible and exposed for inspection purposes. Neither the
Plumbing Inspector nor the city shall be liable for any expense incurred for
the removal of material to allow for inspection or for the replacement of the
material removed.



   (C)   It shall be the duty of the person doing the work authorized
by a permit to notify the Plumbing Inspector that the work is ready for
inspection. The request may be in writing or by telephone and must be
requested at least one working day before the inspection is desired.



   (D)   An inspection record card shall be posted as to allow the
Plumbing Inspector to make the required entries thereon regarding inspection
of the work.



   (E)   The record card shall be maintained and available by the
permit holder until final inspection and approval has been granted by the
Plumbing Inspector.



   (F)   New plumbing, water or sewer systems, or systems which have
been altered, extended, replaced, or repaired shall be tested in accordance
to the procedure established by the Plumbing Inspector. Plumbing work
requiring testing shall be uncovered and unconcealed until after it has been
tested and approved. The Plumbing Inspector may waive the testing requirement.



(Prior Code, § 4-1-7)  Penalty, see § 152.99



APPENDIX A:  SCHEDULE OF FEES




   I.   Schedule of fees




I.  SCHEDULE OF FEES.



   (A)    Fees shall be assessed in accordance with the provisions of
this section, divisions (A) and (B). The determination of fees owed under any
of the provisions of this section shall be made by the Plumbing Inspector.
Whenever extra inspections are made on account of inaccurate or incorrect
information or repair of faulty construction, an additional charge of $15 per
hour (with a $15 minimum) shall be made by the Plumbing Inspector for time
consumed in making extra inspections. Inspections made outside of regular
business hours shall be charged $25 per hour, two hour minimum fee, at the
convenience and availability of the Inspector. Whenever any work for which a
permit is required by this section has commenced without first obtaining a
permit, the fee for the permit shall be double the scheduled fee. Fees for
permits issued to the city are hereby waived. Whenever work described in the
plumbing permit application is altered to cause an additional fee, the fee
shall be at the same rate as established by the issuance of the original
permit. The payment of the permit fee established by the Plumbing Inspector
shall be submitted along with the copy of the permit to the City Clerk.
Whenever the fee does not accompany the copy of the permit, the City Clerk
shall render a bill for the fee.



   (B)   Fees. For each opening for a fixture or appliance whether for
immediate or future use:  $10 per opening, subject to a minimum fee of $25.



(Ord. O-18-25, passed 12-11-2018)

CHAPTER 153:  ELECTRICAL CODE



Section



   153.01   Definition



   153.02   Standards and specifications applied



   153.03   Electrical Code adopted



   153.04   Permit required



   153.05   Permit application and eligibility



   153.06   Permit issuance



   153.07   Inspection required



   153.08   Order to repair



   153.09   Liability for damages



   153.10   New subdivision construction



   153.11   Temporary service for construction



   153.12   Commercial underground service



 



   153.99   Penalty



   Appendix A:  Schedule of fees



   Appendix B:  Permit application form



§ 153.01  DEFINITION.



   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definition shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT.  Conductors and equipment (including but not
limited to conduit hollow or filled, raceway, trough, solid and flex tubing)
installed for the utilization of electricity supplied for lights, heat, or
power, but excluding:



      (1)   All conductors and other equipment installed for or by
the Municipal Utility and/or Jo-Carroll Energy, Inc.;



      (2)   All telephone equipment and lines operating at telephone
line voltages;



      (3)   All cable television equipment and lines operating at
cable television line voltages;



      (4)   All radio and television equipment for the transmission
or reception of wireless sounds, pictures, or signals; and



      (5)   Twenty-four volt temperature control wiring and 24-volt
temperature control equipment installed by a heating and/or ventilation
contractor.



(Prior Code, § 4-2-1) (Am. Ord. O-16-164, passed 1-12-16)



§ 153.02  STANDARDS AND SPECIFICATIONS APPLIED.



   The standards and specifications for the installation or alteration of
electrical equipment except as otherwise provided in this chapter shall be in
conformity with the provisions of this chapter, with the statutes of the
state, with any orders, rules, and regulations issued by authority thereof,
and with approved electrical standards for safety to persons and property.
Where no specific standards are prescribed by this chapter or by the statutes
of the state or by any orders, rules, or regulations issued by authority
thereof, conformity with the electrical provisions of other safety codes
approved by the American Standards Association shall be prima facie evidence
of conformity with approved minimum standards for safety to persons and
property.



(Prior Code, § 4-2-2)



§ 153.03  ELECTRICAL CODE ADOPTED.



   (A)   The National Electrical Code, Latest Edition, as published by
the National Fire Protection Association, is hereby adopted as the Electrical
Code of the city, and is incorporated herein.



(Prior Code, § 4-2-3) (Am. Ord. 1974, passed 7-13-2010)  Penalty, see §
153.99



§ 153.04  PERMIT REQUIRED.



   No person shall install or alter electrical equipment in the city
without first obtaining a permit from the City Clerk as detailed in this
chapter. When a permit is required and the work is started or proceeds prior
to obtaining the permit, the city may issue a stop work order and all work
must cease immediately until a permit is obtained.  The permit fees in this
case shall be doubled. Strict compliance, therefore, is required in
conformity with the National Electrical Code and all other applicable
regulations.



(Prior Code, § 4-2-4) (Am. Ord. O-16-162, passed 1-12-16) Penalty, see §
153.99



§ 153.05  PERMIT APPLICATION AND ELIGIBILITY.



   (A)   Any person desiring a permit required by this chapter shall
file with the Electrical Inspector an application therefore, in writing, in
which the application shall describe in detail materials and apparatus as are
intended to be used and the location by street and number where the work is
to be accomplished. Complete plans and specifications showing in detail the
location, nature, and character of all electrical work proposed to be done
under the permit shall accompany the application along with the proposed
permit fee and job bid.



(Prior Code, § 4-2-6)



   (B)   No required permit shall be issued to any person, except the
following:



      (1)   An electrical contractor who is licensed in accordance
with the provisions of this chapter.



      (2)   The owner/occupant of a single-family dwelling may, with
the assistance of any member of his or her immediate family, personally carry
on in his or her dwelling any work governed by this chapter without having to
be a licensed electrical contractor. The Electrical Inspector will interview
the owner/occupant to validate his or her capability of performing the work
in a manner assuring safety to persons and property. The owner/occupant shall
obtain a permit for the work, conform to all regulations of this chapter, and
provide complete plans, specifications, and descriptions of materials to be
used.



(Prior Code, § 4-2-7)



Penalty, see § 153.99



§ 153.06  PERMIT ISSUANCE.



   (A)   The permit shall be issued upon approval of the plans and
specifications by the Electrical Inspector and payment of the permit fees.



   (B)   The permit shall expire one year from the date of its issuance.



   (C)   The permit certificate issued shall be posted in plain view
inside the building for which the permit was issued near the entrance switch
or, if outdoors, inside the entrance switch.



(Prior Code, § 4-2-8)  Penalty, see § 153.99



§ 153.07  INSPECTION REQUIRED.



   (A)   The Electrical Inspector shall inspect all electrical
equipment installed or altered in the city and shall require that it conform
to the standards and specifications prescribed in this chapter.



      (1)   After the wires are drawn in the conduits or conductors
mounted, properly spliced and ground wire grounded, and before the wiring is
concealed, it shall be the obligation of the persons making the electrical
installation or alteration to notify the Electrical Inspector, who shall
inspect the work.



      (2)   Failure to obtain the inspection prior to covering the
included work shall be cause to reject the work until it is uncovered for
inspection purposes and to refuse to issue a certificate of inspection unless
and until it is uncovered for inspection purposes.



      (3)   Upon completion of any installation or alteration of
electrical equipment, it shall be the obligation of the persons making the
installation or modification to notify the Electrical Inspector, who shall
make the required final inspection of the work, and, if the work meets all
the standards prescribed by this chapter, he or she will issue a certificate
of inspection.



   (B)   Nothing in this section shall restrict the issuance of a
certificate by the Electrical Inspector for the use of electricity for
construction purposes.



(Prior Code, § 4-2-9)



§ 153.08  ORDER TO REPAIR.



   (A)   No person, being the owner, occupant, or lessee of any
building or other structure which is occupied or situated as to endanger
persons or property, shall permit the building or structure by reason of use,
installation, alteration, or repair or replacement of electrical equipment to
become susceptible to fire or become liable to cause injury to any person by
electrocution.



   (B)   If, during the course of his or her inspection or during the
course of supervision of the installation, alteration, repair or replacement
of electrical equipment, the Electrical Inspector shall find any unsafe
equipment or unsafe use of equipment, which equipment or use of equipment
renders the premises, building, or structure susceptible to fire or persons
in the area liable to electrocution, the Electrical Inspector shall notify
the owner, occupant, or lessee of the premises, building, structure, or
electrical equipment to repair, replace, remove, or abate the hazard. The
order to repair shall be served upon the owner, occupant, or lessee of the
premises, building, structure, or electrical equipment either personally or
by certified mail. The order to repair shall direct the repair, replacement,
removal, or abatement of the hazard within ten days, unless, in the opinion
of the Electrical Inspector, remedial steps cannot be completed in the time.



(Prior Code, § 4-2-10)  Penalty, see § 153.99



§ 153.09  LIABILITY FOR DAMAGES.



   This chapter shall not be construed to relieve from or lessen the
responsibility or liability of any party owning, operating, controlling, or
installing any electric wiring, devices, appliances, or equipment for damages
to persons or property caused by any defects therein, nor shall the city be
held as assuming any liability by reason of the inspection authorized herein
or certificate of approval issued as herein provided.



(Prior Code, § 4-2-11)



§ 153.10  NEW SUBDIVISION CONSTRUCTION.



   (A)   This section shall apply only to new residential subdivisions
and shall not apply to existing subdivisions where the electrical
distribution system has already been installed.



   (B)   Any subdivider developing a new residential subdivision that
will be served by the Municipal Electric Utility must have the electrical
distribution for the entire subdivision installed underground. The
underground electric distribution system will be constructed by and
engineered by the utility.



   (C)   The Municipal Electric Utility, hereinafter referred to as
“Utility”, will install a single-phase primary-secondary distribution
system (exclusive of underground individual service) with transformers and
service pedestals above grade level. The Utility reserves the right to leave
existing or to build new three phase main feeders, transmission and
sub-transmission lines above ground alongside and around the subdivision.



   (D)   The subdivider shall be obligated by this section to pay all
costs of a single-phase primary-secondary underground system based upon
material costs only.



   (E)   If the Utility finds obstructions or hindrances in any new
subdivision which prevent installation by normal plowing or trenching, such
as trees, rocks, drainage facilities, street crossings, or other similar
obstructions or hindrances, the subdivider shall pay the Utility all excess
installation costs incurred as a result of the obstructions or hindrances.



   (F)   If it is deemed necessary by either the subdivider or the
Utility that all or part of an underground electrical distribution system
shall be three-phase, then subdividers shall pay the Utility all excess
installation costs over and above the cost established herein.



   (G)   Street lighting in new subdivisions having underground
electric distribution shall be constructed with pedestal type lights and all
wiring shall be underground. The Utility shall design the street lighting
system and will install same, but the subdivider shall reimburse the Utility
the difference in cost between this system and a conventional overhead
lighting system, based upon material cost only. The street lighting system
shall belong to the Utility after installation.



   (H)   The subdivider shall provide the Utility with all easements
the Utility deems necessary for the underground electrical distribution and
street lighting system. The subdivider shall also insert a title covenant or
restriction in the owner’s certificate requiring each lot owner to install
an underground service to each house constructed within the subdivision. The
Utility will not install overhead service to any lot which is part of a
subdivision that is served by underground service.



   (I)   The Utility will not be obligated to start construction of the
underground electrical system until subdivider provides survey markers  for
lot corners showing grades of the easement areas and the grade level has been
established within four inches of final grade within the easement areas.



   (J)   Each lot owner in the subdivision shall pay for service
materials for underground service from the pedestal to the house. If the
service can be installed by normal trenching or plowing through unobstructed
soil, it will be provided by the Utility. All additional cost will be billed
to owner.



   (K)   The Utility shall not be obligated under this section until a
written agreement has been approved by the City Council and signed by the
subdivider.



(Prior Code, § 4-2-14)  (Ord. O-11-009, passed 6-22-2011)



§ 153.11  TEMPORARY SERVICE FOR CONSTRUCTION.



   A temporary meter for construction shall be supplied by the contractor
for the purpose of construction or remodel. Current specifications can be
picked up at the Electrical office. It is the developer’s responsibility to
ensure latest specifications are being utilized.



(Prior Code, § 4-2-13)  Penalty, see § 153.99



§ 153.12  COMMERCIAL UNDERGROUND SERVICE.



   Commercial underground services are owned and maintained by the
customer from a point of demarcation to the meter. Point of demarcation will
be determined on a case-by-case basis by the line foreman. Developer is
responsible for the construction of the concrete pad for the transformer.
Current specifications can be picked up at the electrical office. It is the
developer’s responsibility to ensure  latest specifications are being
utilized. Commercial overhead service shall be supplied and maintained by the
Utility to the service attachment point or weather head.



(Prior Code, § 4-2-12)



§ 153.99  PENALTY.



   A person, firm, or corporation violating any provision of this chapter
or the adopted code shall, on conviction, be fined not less than $25 nor more
than $500 for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed upon
each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues.



(Prior Code, § 4-2-15)
